IV enumerates the divine names which may not be erased, the names which are sacred and those of the same spelling which are secular; and prohibits the profane use of any of the sacred names.

V is concerned with errors in the writing of a divine name, the omission of lines; concentration and reverence when divine names are written by the scribe; procedure in cases where such names were written on a person’s body, an article of furniture, the horn of an animal or any utensil; the storage of disused sacred writings, and the scrupulous treatment due to borrowed books.

VI indicates the sections of the Torah which must be marked by blank spaces, the letters and words that are distinguished by dots above them in the text, places for the inverted nun, and quotes the textual variants in three scrolls in the Temple, and certain words whose orthography differs from their traditional form and reading.
VII contains a list of words whose pronunciation (ḳerë) is different from their written form (kethib).
VIII shows the variations in the parallel texts of Ps. XVIII and 2 Sam. XXII, and of Is. XXXVI-XXXIX and 2 Kings XVIII-XX.

IX prescribes which letters are to be ornamented, which are to be written larger than normal, words that are to be substituted in reading for those in the text, and sections which may not be translated in public readings.

X gives general rules for public readings from the Scriptures, the number of persons to be called to the Torah lection on different occasions, and the minimum number of adult males required for public religious functions.
XI regulates the length of the passages in public lections and translations, skipping from one part of Scripture to another, and the procedure in case of error in the sequence of the reading.

XII discusses the manner of reading the curses in Leviticus and Deuteronomy, songs and the Decalogue, the set readings for the New Moon and Ḥanukkah, the arrangement of the lines in the poems in Ex. XV, Deut. XXXII and Judg. V, and how Deut. XXXII is to be divided between six persons.
XIII tells how to write the Hagiographa in general and the scroll of Esther in particular, and gives the benedictions for reading from the Pentateuch and the hafṭarah.

XIV contains the benedictions for reading the Hagiographa and particularly the scroll of Esther, and the liturgical introductions to the readings; describes the persons qualified to act as readers of Scripture at the statutory services, the times for the reading of Esther, the Song of Songs and Ruth; and contrasts the degrees of sanctity of the Torah and other sacred scrolls.

XV discusses the use of the Assyrian script, Greek and other languages in religious books, the degrees of importance of the Rabbinical writings, and recommends to parents which occupations to choose for their children and which to shun.

XVI dwells on the importance of the Torah, the place of the ’Aggada, the many-sided interpretations of Scripture, and the depth of the knowledge of the ancient Sages. It also indicates divisions in the Pentateuch, the number of Psalms, and under what conditions the ḳedushshah is to be recited.
XVII prescribes the readings with some relevant rules for the New Moon, the major and minor Festivals, and Mondays and Thursdays.
XVIII lays down the regulations for the daily and Festival Psalms, the order of service on the Ninth of Ab, and various customs appertaining to fast days.

XIX continues the regulations for the Psalms, and gives the forms of the statutory prayers for the solemn days and Festivals, the announcement of the New Moon, and the benedictions and some customs for weddings and funerals.
XX details the ceremony on seeing the new moon, rules for the Ḥanukkah lamp, the benedictions, Psalms, prayers and lections on that Festival.

XXI names Nisan as a month of joy, describes the fasts, feast and customs in connection with Purim and the benedictions for the Torah and the scroll of Esther on that Festival, concluding with aggadic passages relating to the Patriarchs.
I. W. SLOTKI.

chapter.title: SOFERIM
CHAPTER I
chapter.p: RULE 1. It is not permitted to write [the sacred] books,1 tefillin and mezuzoth2 on skins of ritually unclean cattle or on skins of ritually unclean wild animals. Nor may they3 be sewn with their sinews, or [the parchment rolls of tefillin] be wound with their hair. It is an oral prescription delivered to Moses at Sinai that [all these] shall be written on the skins of ritually clean cattle or ritually clean wild animals, be sewn together with their sinews and [the tefillin rolls] wound with their hair. It is also an oral prescription delivered to Moses at Sinai that [the parchments] shall be ruled with a reed4 and the writing on the skin be done with ink. [This latter requirement] has support in Scripture, And I wrote them with ink in the book.5

RULE 2. R. Joshua the grits-dealer was asked: ‘Why is it permitted to write [sacred scrolls] on the skins of nebeloth and ṭerefoth?’ ‘I will give you an analogy,’ R. Joshua replied. ‘This is similar to the case of two men who were condemned to death by the State, one being executed by the king and the other by the executioner. Which of them is superior? He who was executed by the king.’6 ‘If so,’ he retorted, ‘they should be permitted to be eaten!’ ‘It is stated,’ replied R. Joshua, ‘Ye shall not eat any nebelah.7 Scripture has forbidden it, so what can I do for you?’ (From here it is inferred that it is permitted to write on skins of nebelah and on skins of ṭerefah and there is no need to consider the possibility of their having been pierced at the animal’s heart.)8
RULE 3. Skins9 for the [sacred] books, tefillin and mezuzoth may be bought anywhere, and one need not consider the possibility that they might be skins which were pierced at the animal’s heart.

RULE 4. The writing on ḳelaf must be on the side of the flesh, and on gewil it must be on the side of the hair, no deviation from this being permitted. It is an oral prescription delivered to Moses at Sinai that if one changed one for the other, [the scroll] may not be used for the lection [in the statutory services].
RULE 5. [The sacred texts]10 may not be written on difthera or erased paper;11 nor with coal,12 shoe-black, ink containing gum, vitriol or fruit-juice.13 Vitriol may not be added to the ink.

RULE 6. [The sacred texts] may not be written in [obsolete] Hebrew characters,14 or in the Aramaic, Median or Greek languages.15 If they were written in any other language or in any other characters they may not be used for the lection [in the statutory services], since they must be written in the Assyrian [script].

RULE 7. It once happened that five elders wrote the Torah for King Ptolemy16 in Greek, and that day was as ominous for Israel as the day on which the golden calf was made, since the Torah could not be accurately translated.

RULE 8. It also happened that King Ptolemy assembled seventy-two elders and placed them in seventy-two [separate] rooms without telling them the reason for which he had assembled them. He then went to each one of them and said to him,17 ‘Write for me [a translation of] the Torah of Moses your master’. The Omnipresent inspired them18 and the mind of all of them was identical, so that each on his own19 wrote the [same translation of the] Torah, introducing [the same] thirteen alterations20 as follows: ‘God created in the beginning’.21 ‘And God said I shall make a man in image and likeness.’22 ‘And He finished on the sixth [day] and rested on the seventh [day].’23 ‘Male and female He created him.’24 ‘Come let Me go down and there confound their language.’25 ‘And Sarah laughed among her relatives,26 saying.’ ‘For in their anger they slew oxen27 and in their self-will they digged up a stall.’28 ‘And Moses took his wife and his children and set them upon a carrier29 of men.’30 ‘Now the time that the children of Israel dwelt in Egypt and in the land of Canaan and in other lands31 was four hundred and thirty years.’32 ‘And he sent the elect of the children of Israel.’33 ‘And upon the elect of the children of Israel He laid not His hand.’34 ‘I have not taken one desirable thing35 from them.’ ‘The [beast] with small legs.’36 ‘Which the Lord thy God hath allotted to give light unto all the peoples under the whole heaven.’37 ‘Which I commanded should not be served.’38

RULE 9. [The sacred scrolls] may not be written in gold. It is related that in an Alexandrian39 scroll of the Torah all the divine names were written in gold, and when the matter came before the Sages they decided that it should be stored away.40

RULE 10. All the Torah is in Hebrew but it contains some Aramaic words.41 What is in Hebrew may not be written in Aramaic and the Aramaic words may not be altered; for example, Jegar-sahadutha and Galeed.42 Others hold that the rule applies only to Jegar-sahadutha and Galeed because they are two specifically Aramaic and Hebrew expressions respectively.43 If Hebrew words were written in Aramaic or Aramaic words in Hebrew, the scroll may not be used for the lection. The Aramaic [and Hebrew] words referred to are Jegar-sahadutha, Galeed and the like.

If ha’azinu hashshamayim44 was arranged like the Song of Moses45 or if the Song of Moses was arranged like ha’azinu; if continuous lines were written in broken ones or vice versa; [35b] or if the breaking up was not done according to the rule, the scroll may not be used for the lection.
RULE 11. If one finished [writing nearly] all the Torah and less than a column46 remained of the text, one need not hesitate to make of this a small column on its own.47

RULE 12. A [parchment] sheet [of the Torah scroll] containing six columns may be divided into two sheets;48 but one of five columns may not be divided, in order that it should not49 be separated into one of two50 and one of three columns. No one is allowed to write [a scroll of the Torah] unless one is able to read.51

RULE 13. A scroll of the Torah that was written by a Sadducee,52 an informer,53 a proselyte,54 a slave, a woman,55 a madman or a minor may not be used for the lection.56 This is the rule: Whosoever cannot act in religious matters on behalf of the public is not permitted to write a scroll of the Torah.57

RULE 14. If an open section was written as closed or vice versa, the scroll must be stored away. What is an open section? One which does not begin at the beginning of a line. And what is a closed section? [One which is separated from what precedes by a vacant] space in the middle of the line. And how much space must be left at the beginning of a line so that a section may be called ‘open’? A space in which a name of three letters may be written.58 And how much space must be left in the middle of a line so that a section may be called ‘closed’? A space in which a name of three letters may be written. If an entire section was completed at the end of a column, one vacant line must be left at the top [of the next column]; but if a vacant space in which a name of three letters may be written was left at the foot [of the column], one begins [the next column] from the top.
chapter.ftnote: (1) The scrolls of the Pentateuch used for the lections in public worship.
(2) These two nouns are added by GRA and M. For Hebrew and other terms, see the Glossary.
(3) The parchment sheets of which the scrolls are made up.
(4) To guide the hand of the scribe, the letters being written under the ruled lines.
(5) Jer. XXXVI, 18.
(6) Nebeloth and ṭerefoth are the effect of an act of God.
(7) Deut. XIV, 21. E.V. of anything that dieth of itself.

(8) This sentence is enclosed in brackets in some eds. It was a heathen practice to remove the heart from a live animal to be offered as a sacrifice; this, in Rabbinic law, rendered the entire animal, including its skin, forbidden as an idolatrous offering (‘A.Z. 29b, Sonc. ed., p. 145).
(9) Before they were dressed; but dressed skins may be bought only from trust-worthy persons who can testify that the dressing had been done in accordance with the law.
(10) Mentioned in Rule 1.
(11) Others, ‘palimpsest’. GRA omits ‘erased’.
(12) Or, ‘black pigment’.
(13) Others, ‘rain-water’, ‘wine-lees’.
(14) The script must be ‘Assyrian’ (the modern Hebrew square characters) and the language ‘the holy tongue’.
(15) According to Meg. 9a (Sonc. ed., p. 48) it is permitted to write the Torah in Greek although this is not allowed in the case of tefillin and mezuzoth.

(16) Presumed to be Ptolemy Philadelphus who reigned over Egypt 285-247 B.C.E. He arranged for the Greek Version, the Septuagint, to be made, as narrated in the next paragraph. [The Tractate gives two accounts of the translation, the present one being the later which reflects the harmful effects which the Septuagint had in arresting the development of exegesis among the Hellenistic Jews (cf. Weiss, Dor, I, p. 90).]
(17) lit. ‘to them’.
(18) lit. ‘put counsel in the heart of each one of them’.
(19) So GRA.
(20) Deviations from the traditional text. In the extant Versions of the Septuagint only some of these are found.
(21) Instead of In the beginning God created (Gen. I, 1) the Heb. of which might be misinterpreted to mean that a power named ‘Bereshith’ (in the beginning) created God.
(22) The Heb. text reads: Let us make man in our image, after our likeness (Gen. I, 26). The plural us and our might erroneously suggest a plurality of deities.
(23) For the Heb.: And He finished on the seventh day (Gen. II, 2) which could be understood to imply that God did some work on the seventh day.
(24) Instead of created them (ibid. V, 2) from which it might be inferred that man and woman were, from the first, two separate beings, contrary to ibid. II, 21.
(25) Instead of let us go down (ibid. XI, 7).

(26) i.e. she laughed in the presence of people and therefore incurred censure (ibid. XVIII, 12). The Heb. means ‘within herself’ as Abraham had done when he laughed … in his heart (ibid. XVII, 17) and had not been rebuked.
(27) So GRA, H and M. V incorrectly ‘a man’.
(28) Changing men (ibid. XLIX, 6) to ‘oxen’ and oxen to ‘stall’ in order to remove the stigma of murder from Jacob’s sons.
(29) So M. V and H read ‘carriers of men’.
(30) i.e. an animal conformable with the dignity of Moses, instead of ass (Ex. IV, 20).
(31) So M. V omits ‘and in other lands’. [The reading of the Septuagint is ‘in the land of Canaan and in the land of Egypt’.]

(32) Instead of the Heb. which omits ‘in the land of Canaan and in other lands’ (Ex. XII, 40), and implies that all the 430 years were spent in Egypt when, in fact, they could not have dwelt there more than 210 years (cf. Rashi to Meg. 9a).
(33) So GRA and Meg. 9a but omitted in V. ‘Elect’ is substituted for young men (ibid. XXIV, 5), the former being regarded as more suitable persons for the service.

(34) Here also ‘elect’ was substituted for the Heb. for nobles (ibid. 11). The alteration was not essential, but ‘elect’ which was mentioned earlier was preferred. It should be noted that in the total of thirteen alterations, this and the preceding are counted as one.
(35) A ‘desirable thing’ [which occurs in the Septuagint] for the Heb. ass (Num. XVI, 15) to avoid the suggestion that Moses did not take an ass but more precious objects.
(36) Instead of the Heb. for the hare (Lev. XI, 6) which is arnebeth, so as not to give offence to Ptolemy the name of whose queen was Arnebeth.
(37) The insertion ‘to give light’ (Deut. IV, 19) removes the possible misunderstanding that the heavenly bodies enumerated in the verse were intended by God to be objects of worship.

(38) Deut. XVII, 3 reads which I have commanded not. This might be taken to mean that God did not desire their existence and their creation was consequently due to a power beyond His control. It should be noted that the last two alterations are regarded as one in the enumeration because both deal with heavenly bodies as objects of worship.
(39) So M. V and H read ‘a scroll of the Torah of Alexander’ [i.e. Alexander Jannaeus (103-76 B.C.E.) according to Krauss, Lehnwörter, II, p. 55].
(40) lit. ‘it shall be hidden’; not to be used for the lection.
(41) lit. ‘translation’ (Targum).
(42) Gen. XXXI, 47, ‘the heap of witness’ in Aramaic and Hebrew.
(43) In the case of the other parts, however, although one language should not be changed for another, the scroll is not disqualified if a change was made (cf. N.Y. ad loc.).
(44) Give ear ye heavens, the opening words of Deut. XXXII, 1-43, which is arranged in the scroll as follows:
(45) Ex. XV, 1-18 written as:
or, according to others:

(46) So GRA and H. V reads: ‘If one finished all the column and left over less, one extends the wording so as to make’, etc. A reading in M is ‘if one finished all the book and left less than a column, one extends the writing so as to make’, etc.
(47) The extension of a short passage over a full column is done either by enlarging the characters or, according to others, by making each successive line shorter than the one preceding it.
(48) Each containing three columns.
(49) So GRA and N. Y. H and M read: ‘perhaps one might’.
(50) Not less than three columns may be contained in each sheet.
(51) M inserts: ‘one is not allowed to write unless [the parchment] was ruled; and if an unruled sheet was written on, it is disqualified’.
(52) An adherent of a sect which was opposed to the teachings and traditions of the Pharisees. M adds min, a Jewish heretic or Jewish-Christian.
(53) Against his fellow-Jews to the ruling Roman authorities. M adds משומד, an apostate.
(54) This refers to a ‘proselyte settler’ (ger toshab), one who does not observe the commandments but, on account of domicile in the land of Israel, has renounced idolatry.
(55) So GRA and M; not in V and H.
(56) For the unsuitability of the persons enumerated, cf. Giṭ. 45b (Sonc. ed., p. 199).
(57) So GRA. V reads: ‘everyone who writes it [must be a person who] may act on behalf of the public [in discharging a religious obligation]’.
(58) The view of Maimonides which has been adopted is that space must be left for three words, each of three letters (cf. Y.D. 275, §2).

chapter.title: CHAPTER II
chapter.p: RULE 1. Sufficient space must be left between words1 so that they can be distinguished, and between letters so that they be not mixed. If the letters were mixed or a break was made in the middle of a word, the scroll must not be used for the lection in the statutory services.2

RULE 2. Between lines there must be left the space of a line, between words the space of a letter, between letters that of a hairbreadth, and between columns the space of the width of a thumb. If [a word at]3 the end of a column was copied4 at the beginning [of the next column, the scroll] is disqualified. If the letters were mixed or if a break was made in the middle of a word, the lection may not be read from it.

RULE 3. It is permitted to insert5 between columns [part of] a word of five6 letters. One may not write two letters within7 the column and three without;8 but it is not so with a short word.9 If the [part of a longer word, however, forms] a short word of two10 letters on its own,11 it is forbidden [to insert it between the columns].12

RULE 4. In a Torah scroll the space13 of two finger-breadths must be left between columns, but in scrolls of the Prophets and ordinary Pentateuchs14 a space of one thumb-breadth only. In the lower margin of a Torah scroll the space of a handbreadth is left, and in the upper margin three fingerbreadths;15 but in scrolls of the Prophets and ordinary Pentateuchs three finger-breadths in the lower margin and two finger-breadths in the upper. In all these cases,16 if it is desired to extend [the margins] this may be done, provided they do not exceed [the space of] the written matter. Between the books17 in a Torah scroll a vacant space of four lines must be left, and in a scroll of the Prophets three lines.18

RULE 5. If one finished [writing nearly] all the book19 and one column of text remained, one need not hesitate to make a small sheet of it.20 At the conclusion of the [last] column [sufficient parchment] must be left to wind [round the scroll]. It is proper21 to attach a roller to the end of a scroll for winding, but there is no need to attach one at the beginning of a scroll. In a Torah scroll, however, rollers should be attached at both ends. A scroll22 is therefore rolled up towards the beginning but a Torah scroll23 towards its24 centre. A Torah scroll may not be opened by [holding on to] a sheet;25 and the height26 of such a scroll must be six handbreadths.

RULE 6. A sheet of a Torah scroll must contain not less than three columns and not more than eight. As regards the lines [in a scroll] a reason was given [for four different numbers]: corresponding to the journeys,27 forty-two; corresponding to the myriads of Israel, sixty; corresponding to the elders of Israel, seventy-two; and corresponding to the reproofs in Deuteronomy, [36a] ninety-eight; all depending on [the size of] the script.28

‘Corresponding to the journeys,’ as it is said, And Moses wrote their goings forth.29 ‘Corresponding to the myriads of Israel,’ as it is said, Write thou these words … and with Israel;30 as Israel numbered sixty myriads so may the lines of the Torah be sixty [in a column]. ‘Corresponding to the elders, seventy-two,’ as it is said, Gather unto Me seventy men31 … there remained … in the camp … of them that were recorded.32 ‘Corresponding to the reproofs, ninety-eight,’ as it is said, If thou wilt not observe to do all the words of this law that are written.33
In the case of ḳelaf parchments no limit was prescribed, and one may add [as many lines]34 as desired, provided only there are not less than three columns [to the sheet].35

RULE 7. If a sheet [of a Torah scroll] is worn out, one may not remove two [columns only]36 and replace them by two new columns; but three columns should be removed and replaced by three new ones, and the new columns must be written in the same size as the original script.

RULE 8. The width of a column [in a Torah scroll] must be such as to be recognizable at one glance,37 and in a small scroll not less than a handbreadth. R. Jose b. Judah says: It must not be less than the width of three fingers.
RULE 9. Half the length [of a column]38 must not be greater than its width, nor its width greater than half its length, but they must be exactly alike,39 and this is the most correct procedure.40
RULE 10. A Torah scroll may not consist of half gewil and half ḳelaf, but it may consist of half gewil and half ḳelaf41 of deers, although42 this is not the best procedure.

RULE 11. [A tear in a parchment sheet of a Torah scroll] may not be joined with glue, nor is it permitted to write on a patch, nor may [the sheets] be sewn together on the written side. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said in the name of R. Meir: [A torn sheet] may be joined with glue and it is permitted to write on a patch. It is forbidden, however, to do the sewing43 on the written side within but [it must be done] on the outside.

A space should be left [unstitched] at the top and at the foot [of the sheets] in order that the scroll be not torn [in use].44 This, however, was at once qualified by adding: from the foot towards the top and from the top towards the foot. It is an oral prescription delivered to Moses at Sinai that, if a Torah scroll was torn, a patch may be placed on its outside.

In the case of the double letters of the alphabet,45 the first ones46 are written at the beginning and in the middle of a word, and the second47 at the end. If this is reversed,48 the scroll is disqualified. If a scroll49 is torn, a patch may be placed on the inside and50 it is not [obligatory to attach it] on the outside.51
chapter.ftnote: (1) lit. ‘between name and name’.
(2) In V Rule 1 is enclosed within brackets, probably because it is included in the fuller version in the next Rule.
(3) So according to GRA.
(4) lit. ‘made’.
(5) lit. ‘place’.
(6) So N.Y. V, H and M read ‘four’.
(7) So N.Y. V and H have ‘at the end’.

(8) Because the greater part of the word must appear within the column. So N.Y. V, H and M read ‘and two between the columns’. GRA emends to ‘one at the end of the column and three between the lines’.
(9) Of two letters (N.Y.). One letter may be written between columns (H).
(10) So GRA. V, H and M, ‘three letters’.
(11) In a noun like שלחן (table), for instance, which consists of four letters, the last two can form the word חן (grace).
(12) The reading of GRA and N.Y.
(13) So M, H and N.Y. V repeats ‘space’ unnecessarily.
(14) Intended for study only and not for public lections.
(15) So H in agreement with Men. 30a (Sonc. ed., p. 195). V and M read ‘two parts of a handbreadth’.
(16) lit. ‘here and there’.
(17) lit. ‘between a book and a book’. The Torah scroll consists of five books.
(18) Both in the case of the major and minor Prophets (N.Y.).
(19) So N.Y. V, H and M read ‘books’. The reference is either to one book of the Prophets or to several written in one scroll.
(20) Cf. I, Rule 11.
(21) lit. ‘in the beginning’, ‘at the outset’.
(22) Of the Prophets, having its cylinder at the end of the scroll.
(23) Which has cylinders at both ends.
(24) So H, M and GRA. V omits the pronoun.

(25) Owing to its sanctity. It must be opened by manipulating the cylinders. Another reading for פותחין is פוחתין (H, cf. N.Y.) which gives the clause the meaning that when a Torah scroll is used for reading the lection not less than a full sheet, which contains not fewer than three columns, must be kept unrolled throughout the reading.
(26) lit. ‘length from top to bottom’.
(27) The reading of H and GRA. V and M have ‘in the journeys’.
(28) The larger the characters the fewer the number of lines in a column.

(29) Num. XXXIII, 2. As the expression of writing (wrote) occurs in the same context as the journeys (goings forth), the number of lines in a written column may be the same as the number of the journeys.
(30) Ex. XXXIV, 27. Write and Israel (numbering sixty myriads) occur in the same context.
(32) ibid. 26. The number of the elders is found in the same passage as the expression of writing (recorded, lit. ‘written’).
(33) Deut. XXVIII, 58, the words of this law refers to the reproofs numbering 98 and occurs with written in the same passage.
(34) N.Y. explains, ‘sheets’.
(35) i.e. the lines in a column, or according to N.Y. the sheets, should not be so many as to leave less than three columns for the last sheet of the scroll.
(36) So M. N.Y. (cf. Ṭur Y.D. 280) explains, ‘sheets’ instead of ‘columns’.
(37) i.e. not more than three Heb. words, each of ten letters, could be written in a line. If the column is wider, the reader experiences difficulty in passing from line to line.
(38) Of text. This is exclusive of the upper and lower margins. Others explain, ‘sheet’, instead of ‘column’.
(39) So GRA. The reading of V is: ‘he takes the middle course and so does it in’, etc.

(40) Some versions omit ‘half’ twice in this paragraph which agrees with B.B. 14a (Sonc. ed., p. 67): ‘A scroll of the Torah should be such that its length does not exceed its circumference nor its circumference its length [when rolled up]’. On this reading, the paragraph deals with the size of the scroll in its entirety.
(41) So Asheri (cf. N.Y.). V and H have the plural of ḳelaf.
(42) GRA and others. V reads ‘because’.
(43) GRA, H and M. According to V ‘the writing’.

(44) By leaving a part unstitched, the liability to tear when the scroll is rolled up would be reduced. GRA reads this paragraph as follows: ‘It is an oral prescription delivered to Moses at Sinai that a space should be left [unstitched] at the top and at the foot [of the sheets]. This, however, was at once qualified [by the Sages who questioned whether this was such an oral prescription or merely a rule] so that the scroll should not be torn [cf. Meg. 19b, Sonc. ed., pp. 118f]. If a Torah scroll was torn a patch may be placed on its outside’.
(45) The five letters כ׳, מ׳, נ׳, פ׳, צ׳ which have a different form as finals.
(46) i.e. the letters in the non-final form.
(47) The final letters.
(48) A final letter in the middle or at the beginning or vice versa.
(49) Other than a Torah scroll.
(50) So M. V reads ‘but’.
(51) The sentence is omitted in H, his reading being ‘if a scroll was torn’ instead of ‘if a Torah scroll was torn’.

chapter.title: CHAPTER III
chapter.p: RULE 1. It is permissible to join the Torah and the Prophets in one scroll, so R. Judah; but the Sages say: The Torah and the Prophets must be written in separate scrolls.1

RULE 2. Between a book of the Prophets and another, one should not leave the same empty space as between two books of the Torah, but in each case the space must be that which has been prescribed for it.2 Furthermore, [a book of the Prophets]3 must begin at the top.4

RULE 3. A Torah scroll5 may not be made into the separate books of the Pentateuch, neither into single books nor into two or three joined together, because it is forbidden to reduce a major sanctity6 to a minor sanctity.7 From scrolls containing sections of the Pentateuch, however, it is permitted to make up a Torah scroll. When may this be done? When the measurements8 and the numbers of the lines9 are alike.

RULE 4. It is not permissible to join together two sections of the Pentateuch or one and a half of them to form a single scroll.10 But if it was intended11 that additional scrolls be attached to them,12 it is permissible.

RULE 5. It is related that Boethus b. Zonin13 had eight books of the Prophets14 joined together in one scroll in accordance with a ruling of R. Eleazar b. ‘Azariah. Others maintain that he had them all in separate scrolls. It is also related that a certain person brought before the Sages a single scroll containing the Torah, the Prophets and the Hagiographa.15
RULE 6. This16 applies only to a codex,17 but in the case of a scroll18 the Torah and the Prophets must each consist of a separate parchment.

RULE 7. If a Torah scroll has spaces or stops [to mark] the beginning of verses, it may not be used for the lections.19 So also if a letter has been engraved or joined to another, the scroll may not be used for the lections.

RULE 8. A scroll [some of whose letters] are faded may not be used for the lections.20 R. Simeon b. Eleazar says: If the outline [of the effaced letters] is distinguishable, it is permitted [to rewrite them].

RULE 9. A scroll of the Torah in which a whole line is faded may not be used for the lections. If the greater part of a line is faded and the smaller part intact, the use of the scroll is permitted. If a Torah scroll contains an error, it may not be used for the lections. How many [errors disqualify it]? One in a column, is the view of R. Judah. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel says: Even if there be one error in three columns21 the scroll may not be used for the lections.

RULE 10. Not less than three columns of the Torah scroll [may be unrolled at one time during the reading], but there is no objection to the reading of ten [columns] in one [lection]. It is a religious precept that the most important member22 shall roll up the scroll.23 When one rolls up a Torah scroll he should roll it [so that it closes] at the seam24 and not at [the middle of] a sheet.25 A Torah scroll should [36b] be rolled up26 from without,27 but the [band]28 should be tied from within.29

When one hands a Torah scroll to another person it must be done with the right hand only, and he who receives it must also do so with the right hand only, because the Torah was delivered at Mount Sinai in this manner, as it is stated, At His right hand was a fiery law unto them.30

R. Shefaṭai31 said in the name of R. Joḥanan: If one reads the Scripture without a melody32 or learns the Mishnah without a tune,33 of him Scripture says, Wherefore I gave them also statutes that were not good.34

RULE 11. A scribe may not put upon the written part [of a Torah scroll] a reed-pen with ink on it; nor may he take hold of the sheets of parchment35 and thereby unroll [the scroll]; nor may he grasp them to extract the written sheets;36 nor may he remove a scroll from its [case] by shaking it out. All these [restrictions] are relaxed with the official revisers of Scripture scrolls. A Torah scroll may not be released from its case while it is lying on one’s lap37 because this is disrespectful treatment. It is not permissible to place a Torah scroll on one’s knees or lean on it with one’s elbows while reading; so according to the ruling of R. Nehemiah.

RULE 12. A Torah scroll may not be placed over a chair [with its sheets] hanging down while it is being read, in the manner of ordinary documents, because [sacred] books must not be treated with disrespect. The proper procedure is38 to hold it in the hands39 with reverence and so read it. [Sacred] books40 may not be thrown about41 nor may they be treated in [any other] disrespectful manner.

RULE 13. A scroll of the Torah may not be placed on a bed and [certainly]42 not at its foot or under it; nor may one sit on a bed on which a [Torah] scroll [happens to] rest. It is related that R. Eleazar once sat [unwittingly] on a bed on which lay a [Torah] scroll and [when he realized it] he jumped up as if a snake had bitten him. [Respect is shown for the Torah] because Scripture states, Ye shall keep My sabbaths, and reverence My sanctuary43—it is not the sabbaths that one reverences but Him who commanded [to keep them], nor is one to reverence the sanctuary but Him who commanded [to make] it.

It is obligatory to make beautiful ẓiẓith, beautiful mezuzoth, to write a beautiful scroll of the Torah with choice ink, with a fine reed-pen [written] by an expert penman44 on well-finished parchments, on deer skins,45 and to wrap it in precious silks; for Scripture states, This is my God, and I will glorify Him,46 which means, perform the commandments in a beautiful manner to His glory.47 Such is the interpretation of R. Ishmael. R. ‘Aḳiba expounds the text as meaning that one should expatiate on His excellencies. Abba Saul explains: Be like Him;48 as He is merciful and gracious so be thou merciful and gracious.

RULE 14. Foodstuffs may not be treated with disrespect, nor may they be thrown about. One may not sit on a basket containing dates or dried figs;49 but he may sit on a basket which contains pulse or on a cake of pressed figs, because it is customary to do so.50 Foodstuffs may not be used as a support51 or as a covering, nor may foodstuffs be eaten with the aid of foodstuffs,52 unless [the latter] are fit to be eaten.53 R. Eliezer b. Jacob says: Any fruit which has a stem or stalk54 may be used as a covering.55 R. Simeon b. Gamaliel says: Any foodstuff which requires processing may be used as a covering.56 R. Simeon b. Gamaliel also says: Any foodstuff which has a protection57 may be used as a covering. One who writes [Torah] scrolls may not turn over a sheet on its face58 because this is disrespectful treatment.
RULE 15. If one finished [writing nearly] all the [Torah] scroll and left over one column, there is no objection to his arranging it on a small sheet [on its own].59
Foodstuffs may not be used as a covering.60 R. Meir says: Any fruit which has a husk may be used as a covering. R. Judah says: Any fruit which has a stem or a stalk may be used as a covering.

RULE 16. Foodstuffs may not be eaten with the aid of foodstuffs unless they are consumed simultaneously. If a scroll cannot be covered with a cloth,61 it may be turned over on its writing.62 R. Joḥanan said: Whoever holds a Torah scroll without a covering63 will be buried without a covering.64 Buried without a covering! Is this thinkable? It means, Without the covering protection of that religious performance.65
chapter.ftnote: (1) So V, H, M. GRA adopts the reading of B.B. 13b (Sonc. ed., p. 66): ‘It is permissible to fasten the Torah, the Prophets and the Hagiographa [in one scroll]’.
(2) viz. four lines between books of the Torah, and three lines between books of the Prophets.
(3) If the preceding book ended at the foot of a column.

(4) Of the next column, the reason being that, if the books of the Prophets were separated one from the other, the beginning of each book would commence at the top of a column. This does not apply to Torah scrolls which may never be cut up into separate books.
(5) Which contains the five books of Moses.
(6) The Torah scroll in its entirety.
(7) A section of the Pentateuch.
(8) Of all the scrolls that are to be joined together.
(9) In each column.
(10) Because it might be mistaken for a proper Torah scroll.
(11) When these were written.
(12) To complete a Torah scroll.
(13) [A pious Jew at the end of the first cent. C.E., not to be identified with the Boethus named in ARN V.]
(14) Joshua, Judges, Samuel, Kings, Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel and the Twelve Prophets reckoned as one book.
(15) And, as recorded in B.B. 13b (Sonc. ed., p. 66), the Sages ruled that it was a proper scroll.
(16) That the Torah, Prophets and Hagiographa may be included in one scroll.
(17) Since, as a book for study, no one could attribute to it the sanctity of a Torah scroll.
(18) In that form only the contents could show whether it was a Torah scroll only.
(19) Because the Torah scroll must conform to the original form without any alterations.
(20) So H and GRA. V reads ‘one should not rewrite them’.

(21) The reading of GRA. In V and M, ‘even three errors in a column’. The reading of H is: ‘Three in a column is the view of R. Judah. Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel says: Even if there be one error in one column’.
(22) Of the congregation, or of those who have taken part in the reading.
(23) Thus showing honour to the Torah.
(24) So that if the scroll is pulled, only the seam will be affected.
(25) Which might be torn by the pull.
(26) So GRA. V and M: ‘it shall not be fastened from within, but it must be fastened from without’.
(27) i.e. the back of the written side, while the scroll is being held up by another person who is faced by the written side.
(28) Which is wound around the scroll to prevent it from unrolling.
(29) The knot facing the written side. In this way, when the next lection is to be read, the knot can be easily undone without having to turn the scroll over.
(30) Deut. XXXIII, 2.
(31) In Meg. 32a (Sonc. ed., p. 194) the name is Shefaṭiah.
(32) Indicated in the printed Pentateuch by the traditional cantillation.
(33) Which aids the memory.
(34) Ezek. XX, 25. An accompanying melody enlivens one’s studies, and endears the statutes which one learns. If such are described as not good it is because the melody is lacking.
(35) So H. V, ‘folds’.
(36) Which are rolled up; lit. ‘and bring forth the writing without’.
(37) lit. ‘one shall not slip a Torah scroll from one’s lap and release it’.
(38) lit. ‘but’.
(39) By means of a cloth since, according to Rule 16 below, it is forbidden to touch a Torah scroll with the bare hands.
(40) Not only Torah scrolls (Maimonides).
(41) lit. ‘from place to place’.
(42) Cf. N.Y. The addition of ‘certainly’ avoids an anticlimax.
(43) Lev. XIX, 30.
(44) [Reading with Bacher, Ag. d. Tannaiten, I, p. 254n לבלר אומן for לבלרין נאים (fine pen-men).]
(45) So GRA. V and H, ‘dyed skins’.
(46) Ex. XV, 2, I will glorify Him (ואנוהו) is connected homiletically with נאה, ‘beautiful’, and understood as ‘I will serve Him in a beautiful manner’.
(47) lit. ‘before Him’.
(48) He explains ואנוהו as the equivalent of אני והוא, ‘I and He’.
(49) Because they might be crushed and spoilt.
(50) Pulse or dried figs are not spoilt by sitting on them.
(51) For any object.
(52) Using them, e.g., in place of a spoon.
(53) Immediately after use and would not be thrown away.
(54) Whereby it can be lifted if it should happen to fall into the contents of the vessel which it covered.
(55) Since it would not be necessary to throw it away after use.
(56) In its raw state, since its use causes no deterioration.
(57) e.g. a shell.
(58) lit. ‘scroll’, with the writing downwards to protect it from falling dust while it is drying.
(59) Cf. I Rule 11 and II Rule 5.
(60) This and the following are repeated from Rule 14.
(61) lit. ‘on which there is no’. To protect the wet ink from dust while it is drying.
(62) This qualifies what was stated in Rule 14 in accordance with ‘Erub. 98a.
(63) lit. ‘naked’; this is regarded as disrespectful.
(64) i.e. a shroud.
(65). The reverential treatment of the Torah scroll is accounted an act of piety.

chapter.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter.p: RULE 1. The following divine names may not be erased,1 viz. Alef-lamed,2 Alef-daleth,3 Yod-he,4 Shaddai,5 Ẓeba’oth,6 ’Eheyeh ’asher ’Eheyeh.7 R. Jose says: Ẓeba’oth is a secular noun.8 R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: The Aguddah9 family, who were scribes in Jerusalem, used to erase Ẓeba’oth, because they treated it as a secular noun, as it is stated, Captains of hosts shall be appointed at the head of the people.10

RULE 2. If one writes Alef-lamed of the four letters [of Alef-lamed-waw-he]11 or Yod-he of the four letters [of Yod-he-waw-he]12 they may not be erased, because there are divine names corresponding to them.13 Shin-daleth of Shin-daleth-yod (Shaddai) or Ẓadi-beth-alef of Ẓadi-beth-alef-waw-taw (Ẓeba’oth) or Alef-he of Alef-he-yod-he (’Eheyeh) may be erased, because there are no divine names corresponding to them.

RULE 3. All prefixes and suffixes connected with a divine name may be erased. [Prefixes such as] in the Lord, like the Lord, to the Lord, and the Lord [represented respectively by the letters] beth, kaf, lamed, waw and suffixes such as our God, your God, their God [represented respectively by the letters] nun-waw, kaf-mem, he-mem and others of the same kind, may be erased. Some Sages say: The kaf-mem of ‘your [God]’14 must not be erased.

RULE 4. All ordinary nouns the letters of which are the same as those of a divine name may be erased.15 [For instance in] For God doth know that in the day ye eat thereof, your eyes shall be opened, and ye shall be as God,16 the first [divine name] is sacred and the second17 is secular; in For the Lord your God, He is God of gods,18 the first19 is sacred and the second20 is secular.

RULE 5. In Lord of lords,21 the first is sacred and the second is secular; in the God of Abraham22 it is sacred; in the God of Nahor23 it is secular; in the God of their father24 it is secular. In Thou shalt not revile God25 [the noun may bear] a sacred or secular meaning.26 R. Simeon maintains that the noun is sacred.27 In Forasmuch as I have seen thy face, as one seeth the face of God28 the noun is secular;29 in God’s camp30 the noun is sacred.

RULE 6. All the names [signifying God] mentioned in connection with Abraham are sacred, except one which is secular, viz. where it is stated, And he said: My Lord, if now I have found favour in thy sight.30a Others say that it is sacred.31 In And it came to pass, when God caused me to wander32 the name is secular.33 R. Ḥanina the brother34 of R. Joshua maintains that it is sacred [since the verse means] that, had it not been for God,35 they36 would long ago have caused me to wander.37

RULE 7. All [divine] names mentioned in connection with Lot are secular38 except the last, viz. And Lot said unto them: Oh, not so my Lord.39 All [divine] names mentioned in the story of Micah40 are secular. R. Jose says: When they begin with Yod-he41 they are sacred, but when with Alef-lamed42 they are secular except in the phrase the house of God was in Shiloh.43 All the [divine] names which occur in the story of Naboth are sacred except in the sentence Naboth did curse god44 and king.45 All the [divine] names which occur in the narrative of Gibeah of Benjamin46 are secular according to R. Eliezer, but R. Joshua says: They are sacred. R. Eliezer said to him, ‘Is it possible that the Omnipresent would promise [victory]47 and not fulfil?’48 R. Joshua replied, ‘The Omnipresent promises and fulfils’.49 [37a]

RULE 8. In I will tell [’El] of the decree50 the word ’El51 is sacred;52 but the Sages maintain that it is secular.53 In ’el God in Ẓion54 the first is secular55 and the second is sacred. In When he should go ’el God in judgment56 the first is secular and the second [’Elohim] is sacred. In the case of Immanuel57 and Immanu’el58 the first is secular59 and the second60 is sacred. The first must not be divided61 but the second is divided.62

RULE 9. [In the verses] And it came to pass when they63 caused me to wander, God, etc.,64 and Which god65 is like unto Thee66 the first67 are sacred and the second68 are secular. [The divine name in] Samaria shall bear her guilt, for she hath rebelled against her God69 is sacred. R. Nathan says: [In the phrase] in the house of his God70 it is sacred. In therefore turn thou to thy God71 it is sacred. In God standeth in the congregation of God; in the midst of the judges72 He judgeth73 it is used as sacred74 and secular.75 In God delivereth me to76 the ungodly77 the first is sacred and the second78 is secular. In For hath any said unto God: I have borne79 the first [’el] is secular and the second sacred.

R. Eleazar the son of R. Jose the Galilean said:80 [In the verses] And let my cry have no81 resting-place;82 It is in the power83 of my hand; And there shall be nought in the power of thy hand;84 When it is in the power of thy hand;85 Unto death,86 all [the words whose consonants are the same as those for God] are secular. In God hath given command to speed me87 it is sacred. In Forbear thee from meddling with God, who is with me88 it is sacred according to R. Jose b. Judah. In O God, the proud are risen up against me89 it is sacred but the reader must pause in reading [after God]:90 God, the proud are risen up against me.

[The terms] merciful and gracious, long-suffering and abounding in lovingkindness, king, kings, exalted, great, Most High, righteous and upright, pious, perfect, mighty, may be erased.91 He who curses himself or his neighbour by [any of] these92 incurs guilt. [If he curses] heathens or the dead no guilt93 is incurred. [If he curses] a judge or a prince he incurs twofold guilt;94 according to others he incurs threefold guilt for cursing a prince.95 If a person curses his father or mother with the Tetragrammaton96 he is liable to the penalty of stoning,97 but if only with the attributes he is liable to a warning.98

(2) Pronounced ’El (God).
(3) The first two letters of the divine name Alef-daleth-nun-yod (Lord).
(4) The first half of the Tetragrammaton and also constituting a name of God, Yah.
(5) Almighty.
(6) [Lord of] hosts.

(8) And may be erased.
(9) [H reads חגירה in agreement with j. Meg. 71d.]

(11) Meaning ‘God of’.
(12) The Tetragrammaton.
(13) אל and יה.
(14) And so also all other suffixes (cf. Y.D. 276, §9), because the divine name which precedes the suffix imparts sanctity to it (N.Y.).
(15) Since they possess no sanctity
(16) Gen. III, 5.
(17) as God; according to the Targum it means ‘as angels.’
(19) i.e. the first two, your God, He is God.
(20) of gods, signifying judges or princes.
(22) Gen. XXXI, 53.
(23) ibid.; Nahor did not worship the true God.
(24) ibid.; Terah (their father) was an idolater.
(25) Ex. XXII, 27.
(26) It may denote God or judges.
(27) V inserts ‘as it says’ within brackets, the words being redundant. [H omits and reads ‘Ishmael’ instead of ‘Simeon’.]
(28) Gen. XXXIII, 10.
(29) Because it refers to an angel or prince.
(30) ibid. XXXII, 3.
(30a) ibid. XVIII, 3. My lord was addressed to the leader of the three angels.

(34) [He reads ‘nephew’ in agreement with Shebu. 33b (Sonc. ed., p. 205). The correct form of the name is Ḥananiah, Bacher, Ag. d. Tannaiten, I, p. 385.]

(37) The verse will accordingly bear the following interpretation: And it came to pass, when they (the wicked men) caused me to wander, God of my father’s house was with me (to help me). [For various interpretations of the verse, cf. Midrash Rabbah, Genesis, LII, §11 (Sonc. ed., I, p. 457).]

(39) Gen. XIX, 18. Lot’s address to the angels is taken to end at not so, and then his petition to God begins, My Lord, behold, etc. [So the Targum and Shebu. 35b (Sonc. ed., pp. 205f).]
(40) Judg. XVIIf.
(41) The Tetragrammaton.
(42) The word for ‘God’.
(43) ibid. XVIII, 31.
(44) Referring to one of the strange gods introduced by Jezebel. E.V. God.
(45) 1 Kings XXI, 13.
(46) Judg. XXf.
(47) According to Judg. XX, 18, 23 God told Israel to wage war against Benjamin, which implied that they would be victorious.
(48) Israel was defeated on both occasions (ibid. 21, 25).

(49) The Israelites did not appreciate that on the first two occasions God only told them that they may go to war but promised no victory. Only on the third occasion were they assured that Benjamin would be delivered into their hands (ibid. XX, 28).
(51) Heb. אל with a difference of vowels may mean ‘God’ or ‘to’.
(52) The sense of the text being ‘I will tell God of the decree’.
(53) The text means, as in E.V., I will tell of the decree.
(54) Ps. LXXXIV, 8.
(55) ’El meaning before (E.V.).
(56) Job XXXIV, 23.
(57) Isa. VII, 14.
(58) ibid. VIII, 8.

(68) God in Gen. and Thee in Micah.
(69) Hos. XIV, 1.
(70) ibid. IX, 8.
(71) ibid. XII, 7.
(72) The Heb. has the divine name.
(73) Ps. LXXXII, 1.
(74) In God standeth.
(75) In the sense of ‘judges’.
(76) Heb. אל (to) which has the same consonants as the word for ‘God’.
(77) Job XVI, 11.
(78) ’el in the sense of ‘to’.
(79) ibid. XXXIV, 31.
(80) So M. V and H read ‘and R. Eleazar … said’.
(81) Heb. ’al, the same consonants as for the name of God.
(82) Job XVI, 18.
(83) Gen. XXXI, 29. The Heb. for power (’el) equals the divine name.
(84) Deut. XXVIII, 32.
(85) Prov. III, 27.
(86) ibid. II, 18; unto is ’el in Heb.
(87) 2 Chron. XXXV, 21.
(88) ibid.
(89) Ps. LXXXVI, 14.
(90) In the absence of the pause, the adjective proud might erroneously be taken as qualifying God.
(91) Although attributed to God, they do not possess the sanctity of the divine name.
(92) Using any of these attributes instead of the divine name.
(93) So M and N.Y. V and H read ‘guilty of one [offence]’.
(94) Since a judge or prince must not be cursed as any other person, and as men holding offices of responsibility.

(96) lit. ‘the distinguished name’.

chapter.title: CHAPTER V
chapter.p: RULE 1. If one wrote a sacred name twice,1 he retains the first and erases the latter.2 R. Judah says: If the first occurs at the end of a column, he erases the first and retains the second.3 [If he wrote] a secular noun twice,4 he retains the first and wipes away the latter.5 R. Judah says: If the first was at the end6 of a column, he wipes away the first and retains the latter.

RULE 2. If one writes Yehudah and omits the daleth, he inserts7 it above the line. If he intended to write the Tetragrammaton8 and wrote Yehudah9 instead,10 he alters the daleth into a he11 and wipes away the final letter he. If it was required to write Yehudah and he intended to write the Tetragrammaton, although he [inadvertently] inserted the daleth,12 he erases it13 and writes another Yehudah.

RULE 3. If it was required to write the Tetragrammaton but he intended to write Yehudah, although he did not insert the daleth14 he must wipe away [the entire word] and re-write the Tetragrammaton. R. Judah says: He should go over it with the reed-pen and so sanctify it. [The Sages] said to him: This is not the best procedure.

RULE 4. He who writes the divine name and made an error [by omitting] one letter should suspend it above [the line].15 R. Simeon of Shezur says: All the name may be suspended [if omitted] but a single letter of it may not be suspended. If one erred [by omitting] all the name, he should suspend it between the lines, according to the view of R. Judah. R. Meir says: He wipes away the writing that precedes and writes the name on the part which he wiped away. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said in the name of R. Meir: The name only may be suspended but the Tetragrammaton must not be written on an erasure. R. Ḥanina b. ‘Aḳabia says: The whole sheet16 must be stored away.17
RULE 5. If one wrote three18 times Alef-lamed by mistake in the phrase God delivereth me to the ungodly,19 he retains the first and erases the second.20

RULE 6. When one is writing the Tetragrammaton he may not respond even if the king greets him.21 If he was about to write two or three divine names successively,22 he may pause between them and respond. After dipping the reed-pen in ink, he may not start with the letters of a divine name23 but with the preceding letter.24 One who erases a single letter of a divine name transgresses a negative commandment. R. Simeon said:25 On account of this it is stated, Ye shall destroy their name out of that place. Ye shall not do so unto the Lord your God.26
RULE 7. It is permissible, however, to wipe away ink that dropped upon the writing,27 since one’s intention is only to rectify it.

RULE 8. If one omits a line in error, he may not suspend it between the lines, but inserts it in close proximity28 to the place29 of the error by erasing one [adjacent line] and inserting two30 in its place, or [by erasing] two lines and writing three;31 provided only that he does not erase three lines.32

RULE 9. It is not permissible to make a scroll of the Shema‘ or of the Hallel for children,33 but if the scribe intends to add to it, it is permissible.34 R. Judah permits the writing of a scroll from In the beginning35 to the story of the flood,36 and from the beginning of Leviticus to And it came to pass on the eighth day;37 but in the case of all the other books [of Scripture the writing of extracts is] forbidden.38

RULE 10. The following names are to be divided:39 Beth-el,40 Beth-’awen,41 Beer-sheba,42 Ẓofenath-pa’neaḥ, [37b] Poṭi-fera,43 Ben-’oni,44 Yedid-yah,45 Halelu-yah.46 R. Jose says: These must not be divided.47 All, however, agree that there must be no breaking up of ‘Ammi’el,48 ‘Amminadab,49 Ẓuri’el,50 Ẓurishaddai.51
RULE 11. The following names may not be broken up: Yisra’el, Ga’tham,52 Poṭifar, Nebukadneẓẓar.53

RULE 12. If a person writes a divine name on his body, he must neither bathe nor anoint himself54 (nor stand in an unclean place.55 If he must perform an obligatory immersion,56 he should wind a reed about it,57 descend and perform an immersion. R. Jose said: He may at all times descend and perform an immersion in the ordinary way)58 provided he does not rub it off.
RULE 13. [If one wrote a divine name] on the horn of a cow or on the legs of a bed,59 he scrapes it off60 and stores it away. [If he wrote it] on a stone, he detaches it and stores it away.61

RULE 14. If the seam of a sacred scroll was broken for the first time,62 it may be sewn up again;63 if a second time, it may be sewn up again; if a third time, it must not be sewn up again.64 If one cuts off a strip of a new scroll,65 it may [be used for ordinary purposes],66 but if it is cut off an old scroll,67 [its use is] forbidden. Worn-out scrolls, phylacteries and wraps of scrolls must be stored away.68

RULE 15. It is related of R. Ḥalafta that, when he visited Rabban Gamaliel, he found him sitting at his table with the Targum of Job69 in his hand and reading it. He said to him, ‘Master, will you permit me to tell you what my eyes saw?’ ‘Tell me,’ he replied. ‘I was watching Rabban Gamaliel the Elder, your father’s70 father, while he was sitting at the side of a building [in course of construction] on the Temple Mount, when a Targum of Job was brought to him. “Remove a course of stones,” he ordered the builder,71 “and bury this under it.” ’ R. Jose b. R. Judah said: They overturned a tub of mortar upon it.72 Rabbi said: There are two objections to the statement—firstly, how could mortar73 be available on the Temple Mount?74 Further, it is not permissible to destroy such writings75 with one’s own hands! [They should not be deposited in an unclean place] but in a deserted spot where they decay of their own accord.76

RULE 16. If one lends a Torah scroll to his friend, the latter may not lend it to another person. If one deposits a Torah scroll with his friend, the latter must unroll it once in twelve months.77 If he is capable of reading it, he may do so,78 but if he unrolled it for his own benefit,79 reading it is forbidden. Symmachos said: He unrolls a new scroll once in thirty days and an old one once in twelve months. R. Eliezer b. Jacob says:80 Both a new and an old scroll [should be unrolled] once in twelve months.81

RULE 17. All occurrences of the name Solomon in the Song of Songs are sacred82 except one which is secular. Which one is it? Behold, it is the litter of Solomon.83 Others say: Thou, O Solomon, shalt have the thousand.84

RULE 18. All references to ‘kings’ in Daniel are secular except one which is sacred. Which one is it? O king unto whom the King85 of kings, the God of heaven, hath given the kingdom, the power, and the strength, and the glory.86 Others say: My Lord,87 the dream be to them that hate thee, and the interpretation thereof to thine adversaries.88
chapter.ftnote: (1) lit. ‘he who writes a name of two sacred names’. H omits ‘a name of’.
(2) The first is retained because it was properly written; the second is erased because it was written in error.
(3) It spoils the appearance to leave a blank at the beginning of the top line of a column.
(4) lit. ‘two secular nouns’.
(5) While the ink is still wet.
(6) So GRA. V and H, ‘at the top’.
(7) lit. ‘suspends’ between the waw and the he.
(8) The four letters Yod-he-waw-he, lit. ‘the name’.
(9) יהודה.
(10) This is the reading of GRA and H. V omits ‘if he intended to write’,
(11) This is done by adding a short vertical line to the daleth.
(12) So H. V reads: ‘he did not write in it’.
(13) Following GRA. V and H ‘detains it’.
(14) So that the Tetragrammaton was written correctly but unintentionally so.
(15) Neither erasure nor wiping away of the written words is necessary.
(16) In which the omission of the Tetragrammaton had occurred.

(17) As with all sacred objects that are worn out or decaying, or are for any other reason unfit for further use. GRA revised the wording of this Rule to conform in the main with the text in Men. 30b (Sonc. ed., p. 196): ‘If the Tetragrammaton was omitted in error [and a number of the words following it already written], what had been written is erased, the erased words are suspended [above the line] and the Tetragrammaton is inserted in the space of the erasure; so R. Judah. R. Meir said: He wipes the writing away and writes [the Tetragrammaton] in the space. R. Jose said: Even the Tetragrammaton may be suspended [above the line]. R. Simeon of Shezur said: It is permissible to suspend all the Tetragrammaton [above the line] but not a part of it. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said in the name of R. Meir: The Tetragrammaton may not be written in a space which has been erased or wiped away, nor may it be suspended [above the line]; but the entire sheet is removed and stored away’.
(18) So GRA. V ‘twice’.

(19) Job XVI, 11. The text has the word twice, the first being the divine name and the second the preposition; inadvertently he wrote it three times, intending the first two to stand for ‘God’ (thus sanctifying both) and the third for ‘to’.

(20) So GRA and H. The first occurrences of ’el were meant to be the divine name and Rule 1 above applies. By quoting an illustration from Job, the inference to be drawn is that the regulation with respect to a Torah scroll holds good also of the Prophets and Hagiographa.
(21) All his attention must be concentrated on the sanctity of the divine name.
(22) E.g. The Lord, the Lord, God in Ex. XXXIV, 6.
(23) Because a pen full of ink may cause a blot.
(24) Which, if blotted, can be erased or wiped away.
(25) Citing the Scriptural basis of the regulation.
(26) Deut. XII, 3f, i.e. the name of God must not be erased.
(27) Even of a divine name.
(28) lit. ‘opposite’.
(29) So GRA. V and H omit ‘inserts in … place of’.
(30) The one omitted and the one erased.
(31) The two erased and the one omitted.

(32) In order to insert more than one missing line. The erasure of one or two lines is sufficient for the insertion of the omitted line without undue pressure on the space between the lines; but the treatment of more than one line in this manner would disfigure the entire column (N.Y.).
(33) Extracts from Scripture may not be made for study by children.
(34) From ‘but if’ to ‘permissible’ is an addition by GRA.
(36) i.e. to Gen. VI, 8. In each instance the extract is a connected theme.
(38) Only in the case of the Pentateuch were the two extracts mentioned allowed to be written for the instruction of children. V adds here, ‘if he intends to add to it, it is permitted’.
(39) Although each represents one name, it is to be written as two words.
(40) e.g. Gen. XII, 8.
(42) E.g. Gen. XXI, 31.
(43) ibid. XLI, 45. E.V. Zaphenathpaneah and Poti-phera.
(44) ibid. XXXV, 18.
(45) 2 Sam. XII, 25. E.V. Jedidiah.
(46) E.g. Ps. CXI, 1, ‘praise ye the Lord’. E.V. prints it as one word. V and H add: וחרה אף וחרה אפי, and the anger [of the Lord] was kindled, My wrath shall wax hot (Ex. XXII, 23; Num. XI, 10).
(47) But written as one word.
(48) A name meaning ‘God is with me’ (e.g. Num. XIII, 12). Another reading is עזיאל, ‘God is my strength’ (e.g. Ex. VI, 18).
(49) A name meaning ‘my kinsman is noble’ (e.g. ibid. 23).
(50) A name meaning ‘my Rock is God’ (Num. III, 35).
(51) A name meaning ‘my Rock is Shaddai’ (cf. Num. I, 6).
(52) A name occurring in Gen. XXXVI, 11, 16, 1 Chron. I, 36. E.V. Gatam.
(53) V and H unnecessarily repeat צמיאל, עוריאל, צורישדי.
(54) So that the name be not washed away.
(55) Out of respect.
(56) As, e.g., after a period of ritual impurity.
(57) To prevent the name from coming into contact with the water which might wash it away.
(58) The words in brackets are inserted by GRA who follows Shab. 120b (Sonc. ed., p. 597). V and H read: R. Jose permits, provided, etc.
(59) For magical purposes.
(60) [The correct reading is perhaps גודדד for גוררד, ‘he chops off (the horn or leg)’.]
(61) From respect for the divine name.
(62) lit. ‘one’.
(63) On the undamaged part of the sheet, near the writing, although the margins between the columns are thereby reduced.
(64) Because the margins would become too small.
(65) lit. ‘scrolls’.
(66) Being new, the scroll had not yet been consecrated.
(67) Which has been consecrated by the script.
(68) Having once been consecrated, they may no longer be used for ordinary purposes.
(69) This must have been an earlier work than the extant Targum. [The anecdote is related in Shab. 115a (Sonc. ed., p. 565) with some variants.]
(70) V rightly corrects ‘mother’s’ to ‘father’s’.
(71) V incorrectly ‘his children’.
(72) This sentence is added by GRA from Shab. 115a.
(73) Which is composed of earth and water.
(74) Where only a mixture of sand and lime was used.
(75) Books like the Targum of Job whose use was forbidden on account of their exclusion from the Canon.
(76) The objection to a written, as against an oral, Targum at the time was the fear that the same sanctity might be attached to it as to the Hebrew text.
(77) This sentence is inserted by GRA following B.M. 29b (Sonc. ed., p. 182).
(78) While the scroll is being unrolled in accordance with this Rule.
(79) So corrected by GRA.

(81) In the course of the discussion in B.M. 29b this is amended to ‘thirty days’ to differentiate the opinion of R. Eliezer from that of the first authority who is quoted above.
(82) Referring to God in the Rabbinical interpretation of the Book.
(83) Cant. III, 7.
(84) ibid. VIII, 12.
(85) Understood as referring to God.
(86) Dan. II, 37. E.V. O king, king of kings, unto whom, etc.

chapter.title: CHAPTER VI
chapter.p: RULE 1. A scribe must provide a distinguishing mark1 for the section2 beginning And it came to pass when the ark set forward,3 both at its beginning and at its end, because it is a book on its own. Others maintain that its proper place is in the section of the setting forward of the standards.4

RULE 2.5 The scribe must leave a prescribed space at the opening of the section which begins And the people were as murmurers;6 [and not only] at its beginning [but also] at its end, because it is a book on its own. Others hold that its proper place is in the section of the setting forward of the standards.

RULE 3. Ten [letters or groups of letters] in the Torah are marked by dots:7 In the Lord judge between me and thee8 there is a dot on the beth9 of ubeneka (and between thee). In and they said unto him,10 there are dots on alef-yod-waw of ’elaw (unto him). In and he knew not when she lay down, nor when she arose,11 the [second] waw in ubekumah (nor when she arose) is marked with a dot. In and kissed him,12 the entire word wayyishshaḳehu is marked by dots. In and his brethren went to feed their father’s flock,13 the letters of ’eth (the mark of the defined accusative) are dotted. In whom Moses and Aaron numbered14 the word Aaron is marked with dots. In or be in a journey afar off,15 the he in reḥoḳah (afar off) has a dot. In and we have laid waste even unto Nopha, which16 the resh in ’asher (which) has a dot. In and a several tenth part,17 in the section dealing with the first day of the festival of Tabernacles, the second waw in we’issaron (and a tenth part) has a dot. In the secret things belong unto the Lord our God; but the things that are revealed belong unto us and to our children for ever,18 the ‘ayin in ‘ad (for) has a dot.

RULE 4. R. Simeon b. Laḳish said: Three scrolls of the Torah were found in the Temple court:19 the Ma‘on20 scroll, the Za’aṭuṭë scroll, and the Hu’ scroll. In one of these they found the expression of ma‘on,21 and in the other two it was written, The eternal God is me‘onah22 (a dwelling place), so they adopted the reading of the two scrolls and discarded that of the one scroll. In another of the scrolls they found it written, And he sent the za‘aṭuṭë (nobles) of the children of Israel,23 and in the other two they found written And he sent na‘arë (the young men of) the children of Israel, so they retained the reading of the two and abandoned that of the one. In one of the scrolls hu’24 was written eleven times, but in the other two hi’25 was written eleven times, so they adopted the reading of the two and discarded that of the one.
RULE 5. Three expressions of lo’ are written lamed-alef26 but read as lamed-waw.27 They are: ’asher lo’28 jointed legs above their feet;29 ’asher lo’ ḥomah;30 and ’asher lo’ ye‘adah.31

RULE 6. The following [occurrences of lamed-alef (not)] which have to be read as lamed-waw (to, by, has) are found in the Prophets and Hagiographa: multiply;32 Hushai;33 said;34 thou hast multiplied;35 their affliction;36 He slay me;37 I keep silence;38 as the (wandering) sparrow;39 his friends;40 Zerubbabel;41 were fashioned;42 know ye;43 be gathered;44 name,45 [this last also] in the corresponding passage.46 [38a]
RULE 7.47 Four [occurrences of the name] Jeuel are to be read Jeiel; viz. and in Gibeon,48 the Ashterathite,49 the scribe,50 [and of the sons of] Elizaphon.51
RULE 8. The following words are to be read but are not written [in the text]: the children of;52 Euphrates;53 man;54 as;55 his sons;56 of hosts;57 come;58 thereof;59 unto me;60 to me.61
RULE 9. [With the following] it is the reverse;62 they are written [in the text] but are not to be read: Amnon;63 as he shall say;64 in (what) place;65 kinsman;66 let … bend;67 five.68
chapter.ftnote: (1) The traditional mark is an inverted nun.

(3) Num. X, 35. The section consists of the two verses, ibid. 35f.
(4) Num. II.

(5) This Rule is partly a repetition of the preceding, since the end of the section, ibid. X, 35f, is followed by the beginning of And the people were as murmurers (ibid. XI, 1); and partly incorrect since no mark is inserted at the end of the latter section. The entire Rule is to be deleted according to GRA.
(6) ibid. XI, 1.

chapter.title: CHAPTER VII
chapter.p: RULE 1. The following words are written without a waw,1 but are to be read with the waw: and offered it;2 said;3 and [they] said;4 and they spoke;5 shall they take away;6 and let them deliver;7 and eat;8 together;9 and they shall profane it;10 and they offered;11 was made;12 and took upon them;13 Hananiah;14 Malchijah.15 The reverse of this [occurs in the following words]:16 my feet;17 throw her down;18 and … commanded;19 straight before him;20 the fountain gate;21 and called him;22 and he assembled;23 took.24

RULE 2. The following are written with a he which is not pronounced: when I saw;25 and I brought;26 the lion27 in the Book of Samuel;28 was he found;29 and … saw;30 this [city];31 evil;32 [the] evil;33 gone down;34 and he shall come;35 and a line;36 and a line;37 thoroughly;38 them that love me;39 and … friend;40 deal;41 open;42 a lion;43 these;44 venison.45

The reverse is the case with the following:46 and multiplied;47 on the housetop;48 and they;49 be he;50 and … shal be;51 and behold;52 behold;53 planted;54 Gedaliah;55 and … she doted;56 the measure;57 and I shall be glorified;58 three;59 she considereth;60 she perceiveth;61 arise;62 remember;63 turn Thou us;64 thou hast declared;65 thou … hast cursed;66 Thou hast set;67 Thou hast made;68 is sore affrighted;69 the carved work thereof;70 with her harlotries;71 turn back;72 disclose;73 Thou [hast] made an hedge;74 and [he] saw.75

RULE 3. The following are written as one word and read as two words: fortune is come;76 a fiery law;77 consumed of the fire;78 what mean ye;79 and, behold, he;80 what they;81 Bani, of;82 of the Benjamites;83 the helpless;84 may He incite death;85 of the proud oppressors;86 out of the whirlwind;87 out of a whirlwind;88 were broken down.89

The reverse of the above are the following:90 when … were merry;91 of Benjamin;92 that … may be increased;93 out of the cave;94 by Myself;95 with their axes;96 from the daughter;97 like the ostriches.98

RULE 4. The following are spelt with a waw but read with a yod: prisoners;99 Abigail;100 I make thee … go up and down;101 chief men;102 I will … make … straight;103 I will … make them run away;104 on mine eye;105 cistern;106 in their march;107 set apart;108 wilt thou set;109 ye might provoke Me;110 make straight;111 who were set;112 that taught;113 Birzaith;114 will greatly rejoice;115 Dehites;116 bring forth;117 Harsith;118 Luhith;119 the entry;120 the strong;121 made to murmur;122 and Shahazim;123 and a royal diadem;124 and a thing of nought and the deceit;125 and the swallow;126 and the galleries thereof;127 and Tilon;128 Jehiel;129 and prepare ye;130 thy bosom;131 a side-structure;132 Jair;133 alienate;134 Jeiel;135 they wander up and down;136 let … cover them;137 they cause … to fall;138 to strive;139 singing;140 Laish;141 for fishers;142 dross;143 for a spoil;144 their furrows;145 Mephaath;146 from Naioth;147 stretched-forth;148 fruit;149 Nebai;150 Nephishesim;151 leave;152 ready dressed;153 Ephai;154 Ephrain;155 the second156 ready;157 their lads;158 her little ones;159 dung.160 [38b]

chapter.title: CHAPTER VIII
chapter.p: RULE 1. Variants1 between the poem2 of Psalm [XVIII] and Samuel3 are the following: and … spoke;4 and my deliverer;5 my God, my rock;6 my high tower, and my refuge;7 from mine enemies;8 for … compassed me;9 the waves of;10 the floods of;11 compassed me;12 I called;13 and … He heard;14 then … did shake;15 the foundations of heaven;16 yea, He was seen;17 and He made;18 pavilions;19 gathering of:20 coals of fire flamed forth;21 thundered from heaven;22 arrows;23 and discomfited them;24 the channels of waters;25 and … were laid bare;26 by the rebuke of the Lord;27 His nostrils;28 from them that hated me;29 a stay;30 He brought me forth also;31 according32 to my righteousness;33 I did not depart from them;34 and I was;35 toward Him;36 and I kept myself;37 according to my righteousness;38 according to my cleanness;39 man;40 Thou dost show Thyself pure;41 Thou dost show Thyself subtle;42 and … Thou dost save;43 but Thine eyes are upon the haughty, that Thou mayest humble them;44 and the Lord;45 by my God;46 who is God;47 save;48 my … fortress;49 who letteth … go forth;50 do bend;51 and Thy condescension;52 under me;53 I have pursued;54 and destroyed them;55 and I have consumed them;56 and smitten them;57 that they cannot arise;58 yea, they are fallen;59 for Thou hast girded me;60 under me;61 yea, them that hate me, that I might cut them off;62 they looked;63 even unto the Lord;64 as the dust of the earth;65 I did stamp them … I did tread them down;66 Thou also hast delivered me … my people. Thou hast kept me;67 dwindle away … as soon as they hear of me;68 and come halting out of their close places;69 my Rock of salvation;70 and bringeth down … under me;71 and that bringeth me forth … yea … above them that rise up against me … violent;72 the Tetragrammaton is placed first;73 I will sing praises;74 a tower of salvation.75

RULE 2. The following are variants between Isaiah76 and the text of Kings:77 Now in the four[teenth];78 Hezekiah;79 Rab-saris … to king Hezehiah … unto Jerusalem. And they went up and came to Jerusalem. And when they were come up, they came and stood by.80 And when they had called to the king … unto them.81 Sayest thou82 now … thou trustest;83 ye say … in Jerusalem;84 with … king;85 now … against this place … against this land and destroy it;86 the son of Hilkiah … with us;87 unto them … hath … to;88 and spoke … the word of;89 and hearken not … when he persuadeth;90 hath … ever delivered;91 Hena, and Ivvah have they delivered;92 the countries;93 but the people held their peace;94 the words of Rab-shakeh.95

And Shebna;96 the prophet precedes the son of Amoz;97 all the words of;98 unto them;99 to his own land;100 of Tirhakah;101 behold he is come out … again;102 what;103 O Lord, the God of;104 I have heard thee;105 against the Holy One;106 thy messengers;107 the choice;108 and I have entered into his farthest lodge;109 strange;110 in … times111 … should be laid waste;112 and confounded;113 and as corn blasted;114 that which springeth of the same;115 he came;116 will defend this city;117 and it came to pass that night;118 and smote;119 fourscore.120

His face;121 saying;122 I beseech Thee;123 heart;124 return … the princes of My people … I will heal thee;125 and I will add;126 for Mine own sake and for My servant David’s sake;127 take … and he recovered;128 and Hezekiah said unto Isaiah … the third day;129 this;130 that the Lord;131 will do the thing;132 go forward.133 Berodach134 … for he had heard;135 Hezekiah had been sick;136 hearkened unto them;137 all his treasure house;138 oil139 … the house of his armour140 … they are come;141 the word of the Lord;142 to Babylon;143 is it not so, if.144

chapter.title: CHAPTER IX
chapter.p: RULE 1. On the beth of bereshith1 there must be four crownlets,2 and the letters3 of the word must be extended above all the other letters, because by its means4 the world came into existence.5

RULE 2. The waw of gaḥon6 must be enlarged,7 because it is the middle of the letters of the Torah;8 darosh darash9 is the middle of the words of the Torah. Darosh is written at the end of the line10 and darash at the beginning of the next line.11
RULE 3. Wayyishḥṭ12 must be enlarged,13 because it is half of the verses of the Torah.14
RULE 4. Shema‘ Yisra’el15 must be written at the beginning of a line, and all its letters are to be enlarged,16 while ’eḥad17 must come at the end of [the same] line.18
RULE 5. The lamed of wayyashlikem19 must be long.20
RULE 6. The he of haladonai21 must be longer than any other he, because it is22 a word on its own.

RULE 7. The yod of teshi23 must be smaller than any yod in the Scriptures. The yod of yigdal24 must be bigger than any yod in the Torah.25 Yisra’el at the end of the Torah26 must be enlarged, while the lamed in it must be higher than any other lamed.

RULE 8. The following words27 are written but not read [in their written form]:28 It is written ba‘folim29 but we read baṭṭeḥorim;30 it is written yishgalennah31 but we read yishkabennah;32 it is written weroba‘ haḳḳab ḥiryonim33 but we read weroba‘ haḳḳab dibyonim;34 it is written memë shinehem35 but we read memë raglehem;36 it is written ḥorehem37 but we read ẓo’atham;38 it is written wayyesimehu lemaḥara’oth39 but we read lemoẓa’oth.40

If a person uses euphemisms in the section of forbidden marriages41 he is silenced.42 R. Jonah explained:43 [39a] [When one says]44 ‘the nakedness of his father’ or ‘the nakedness of his45 mother’. If a person says46 ‘and thou shalt not cause any of thy seed to be conceived by a Gentile woman’,47 he is silenced with a rebuke.

RULE 9. The incident of Reuben48 is read49 but not translated.50 The story of Tamar51 is both read and translated.52 The first [account of] the golden calf53 is read and translated,54 the second55 is read but not translated.56
RULE 10. Where [does the translator] begin? At Oh this people have sinned.57 The blessing of the priests58 and the stories of David59 and Amnon60 are neither read nor translated.61

RULE 11. The section dealing with the heavenly chariot62 must not be read as a hafṭarah. R. Judah permits it.63 R. Eleazar says: The section beginning Cause Jerusalem to know64 must not be read as a hafṭarah.65 It once happened that a person read the section beginning Cause Jerusalem to know [hear bominations] as a hafṭarah and R. Eleazar exclaimed, ‘Let that man go and investigate the abominations of his mother’.66 Enquiries were made about him and he was found to be illegitimate.

(4) This idea is also expressed in ’Othioth deRabbi ‘Aḳiba, quoted by M (p. 131): The world was created by means of the letter beth.
(5) So M. V reads, ‘for it (the world) will exist for ever’, the beth representing berakah (blessing). [Cf. Midrash Rabbah, Genesis, I, §9 (Sonc. ed., p. 9).]

(46) [Or, according to J. Rabbinowitz, Mishnah Megillah, p. 133. ‘And thou shalt not give any of thy seed (to a heathen woman) to become with child in idolatry,] instead of and thou shalt not give of thy seed to set them apart to Molech (Lev. XVIII, 21).
