chapter.title: CHAPTER X
chapter.p: RULE 1. Moses1 warned2 Israel that they should read out of the Torah3 on Sabbaths, Festivals, New Moons and the intermediate days of the Festivals;4 as it is stated, And Moses declared unto the children of Israel the appointed seasons of the Lord.5
RULE 2. Ezra ordained for Israel that they should read in the Torah on Mondays and Thursdays and in the afternoon service on the Sabbath.6

RULE 3. There is no difference between a Festival and the Sabbath7 save only in the matter of preparing food.8 There is no difference between the Sabbath and the Day of Atonement save only that a wilful violation of the former [is punishable] by men9 while a wilful violation of the latter [is punished] by kareth.
RULE 4. R. Judah said: At the place [in the Torah] where we leave off on the Sabbath morning we begin to read at the afternoon service, and on the following Monday, Thursday and Sabbath.

RULE 5. On Mondays and Thursdays10 and at the Sabbath afternoon service three men read [from the Torah].11 Their number must be neither reduced nor increased; nor is a hafṭarah read from [a book of] a Prophet. He who begins as well as he who concludes [the reading of the prescribed section of] the Torah recites the appropriate benedictions before and after his reading.12

On the New Moon and during the intermediate days of a Festival, four [persons read from the Torah]. Their number must be neither reduced nor increased. This is the general rule: On any day which has a musaf and is not a Festival, four persons read [from the Torah].

RULE 6. On a Festival five [persons read from the prescribed portion of the Torah]; on the Day of Atonement, six; and on the Sabbath, seven. The number must not be reduced but may be increased. On a Festival, for the violation of which only a negative precept is infringed, five persons [read in the Torah]; on the Day of Atonement, for the violation of which kareth is incurred, six; on the Sabbath, the violation of which is punishable by stoning, seven; and one concludes with [a reading from a book of] a Prophet.
The one who begins as well as the one who concludes [the lection] recites the benediction before and after his reading.

RULE 7. The accompanying benedictions of the Shema‘13 may not be repeated14 in congregational prayer, irrespective of whether they are said standing15 or sitting;16 nor may one act as reader in public worship;17 nor may [the kohanim] lift their hands;18 nor may the hafṭarah be read from the Prophet;19 nor may halts20 be made [at funerals]21 for men, how much less for women since no halts are made for women; nor may ḳaddish22 and bareku be said23—if less than ten adult males24 are present.

Our teachers in the West25 rule that seven [adult males26 are sufficient]27 and, as a reason for their ruling, they quote, When men let grow their hair in Israel, when the people offer themselves willingly, bless ye the Lord,28 [which implies that the number present must be the same] as that of the [Hebrew] words.29 Others hold that even six [adult males are sufficient for the purpose, since up to] bareku [the number of words] is six.

Furthermore, where there are nine or ten persons who have heard either bareku or ḳaddish and, after the service, one of them [who missed one of the benedictions] said bareku or ḳaddish, he has thereby performed [the duty of public worship].30

The Sages long ago issued an ordinance to Synagogue precentors to say after the prayer for redemption,31 Blessed be the name of the Lord from this time forth and for ever,32 and after that, ‘Bless ye the Lord Who is to be blessed’,33 so as to enable those who had not heard the benedictions34 to perform the duty of public worship; for R. Joḥanan said: Would that a man read his prayers all the day long.35

The congregations of the West and the congregations of the East36 have a custom to say it37 after ‘He Who maketh peace’38 in the three statutory prayers39 of the Eighteen Benedictions,40 as a provision for the benefit of those who arrived late and for those who leave early.41 [The verse from Psalms with the benedictions is also said] even after the public reading from the Torah.42
As regards the redemption of land,43 however, [the presence is required of] nine male adults and a kohen; and the same law applies to the redemption of a human being.44
chapter.ftnote: (1) In V and H a passage has been interpolated after ‘Moses’ which has no relation to the subject-matter. It seems to have been originally a marginal note explanatory of the meaning of hiḳni’, an unusual verb to be employed in the sense of ‘warn’. It reads as follows: Hiḳni’, i.e. ‘he warned’, as we have learned in a Mishnah (Soṭ. I, 1), hammeḳannë’ (of the same root as hiḳni’ which means), If [a husband] ‘warns’ his wife [not to associate with a certain man], R. Eliezer said: His warning is valid if it was given in the presence of two witnesses, though he makes her drink [the water of bitterness] on the evidence of one witness [who saw that she had secluded herself with the man after she had been given due warning], because a warning is not valid if given in the presence of less than two witnesses; for [only where there are two witnesses] would she be able to plead, ‘I was not warned’, but when [there was only] one witness she might dare to plead, ‘I was not warned’.
(2) For hiḳni’ some eds. read the normal verb hithḳin, ‘he established a custom, ordained’.
(3) In the service of the Synagogue.
(4) lit. ‘the secular [part] of the Festival’, the days intervening between the holy days which begin and end the Festivals of Passover and Tabernacles.
(5) Lev. XXIII, 44.
(6) [For this and other ordinances of Ezra, cf. B.Ḳ. 82a (Sonc. ed., p. 466) where the reason is given for these additional lections.]
(7) In regard to forbidden work.
(8) lit. ‘food of a person’. On a Festival, but not when it falls on the Sabbath, the preparation of food for the day by cooking is permitted.
(9) i.e. a court of law.
(10) During the morning service.
(11) The first of the seven portions into which the weekly sidra’ or section is divided for the Sabbath lection. On the specified occasions it is subdivided between three worshippers.
(12) For the benedictions, cf. P.B., p. 68.
(13) These are the ḳaddish, bareku and yoẓer ’or (P.B., pp. 37ff) which precede the Shema‘, and the three benedictions of the ‘Amidah which follow it (P.B., pp. 44ff) including the ḳedushshah.

(14) lit. ‘they must not break off in connection with the Shema‘ ’. The ruling applies to persons who had read the morning prayers in private and now wish to join in congregational worship. They do not repeat all the statutory morning prayers, but may repeat ‘broken off’ parts, viz. those specified in the preceding note (cf. N.Y. and Rashi to Meg. 23b). For other interpretations, cf. Meg. (Sonc. ed., p. 141, n. 1) [and J. Rabbinowitz, Mishnah Megillah, pp. 114ff].
(15) i.e. the benedictions which follow the Shema‘ said while the worshippers are standing.
(16) The benedictions which precede the Shema‘ said while the worshippers are sitting.
(17) In connection with any part of the prayers. Lit. ‘they do not pass before the [reading] chest’, to lead the congregation in the conduct of the service.
(18) To bless the people during the service; cf. P.B., p. 238a.
(19) As is the law in regard to the Torah itself; cf. Meg. 23b (Sonc. ed., p. 141).
(20) lit. ‘a standing and a sitting’.
(21) It was customary, when returning from a burial, to halt and sit seven times to praise and lament the dead.
(23) Even without the other statutory prayers.
(24) Who have attained their thirteenth birthday.
(25) The land of Israel which was west of Babylon.
(26) Who have not heard one of the benedictions indicated above.
(27) For the purpose of repeating the benedictions.
(29) Because the verse contains the word bareku (bless ye).
(30) Contrary to the ruling of the Rabbis of the West and the others who hold that seven or even six are enough.
(31) ‘O Rock of Israel,’ etc. (P.B., p. 44).
(32) Ps. CXIII, 2.
(33) Bareku, etc. (P.B., p. 37).
(34) Owing to their late arrival.
(35) Therefore it is permissible for the precentor to repeat the benedictions under discussion more than once for the benefit of those who did not hear him when he first read them.
(36) The land of Israel and Babylon respectively.
(37) The verse from Psalms followed by the benedictions mentioned.
(38) P.B., p. 54, forming the conclusion of the ‘Amidah.

(39) For the evening, morning and afternoon. This custom is contrary to the previous opinion which permits an interruption between the prayer for redemption and the ‘Amidah which immediately follows it. The originators of the custom forbid such an interruption.
(40) The actual number is nineteen, but it was eighteen when originally instituted.
(41) It is for their benefit that the repetition is not made at the end of the entire service.
(42) If persons came in as late as that.
(43) Which had been dedicated to the Temple.
(44) Cf. Lev. XXVII, 2ff, 16ff.

chapter.title: CHAPTER XI
chapter.p: RULE 1. One who reads the Torah [in public worship] should read not less than three verses,1 and he should not read for the interpreter2 more than one verse [at a time].3 In the case of [the lection from] a Prophet, however, three [verses at a time may be read];4 but if the three verses constituted three different paragraphs, he may read one verse at a time5—for instance, For thus saith the Lord; Ye were sold for nought6 … [39b] For thus saith the Lord God: My people went down aforetime into Egypt7 … Now, therefore, what do I here, saith the Lord.8
In a city where only one person is able to read [from the Torah scroll] he reads all9 the prescribed sections, provided he sits down between the reading of one section and the next.10

RULE 2. It is permitted to skip from place to place in [a scroll of] a Prophet,11 but not in a Torah scroll, because [the scroll of] a Prophet may be unrolled in public but not of the Torah.12 Similarly ruled R. Jeremiah in the name of R. Simeon b. Laḳish: A Torah scroll may not be unrolled in public.

R. Jose enquired: Suppose13 there was only a small section [which one wished to skip]!14 The real reason15 is that Israel shall hear the Torah in its proper order. But have we not learned: [The High Priest] reads [in public] aḥarë moth16 and ’ak be‘asor?17 [With these two sections] it is different,18 because they deal with the statutory order [of the reading] of the day.19 You can see the reason20 for yourself, because R. Simeon b. Laḳish ruled, ‘No part of the Torah may be21 read by heart’, and yet here22 [the High Priest] reads by heart.23

RULE 3. R. Jose gave the following instruction to Bar24 ‘Ula, the precentor of the Babylonian Synagogue [in Sepphoris]:25 When only one Torah scroll is available the unrolling26 should be done in front of the ark curtain,27 but when two scrolls are available you should carry the first [back to the ark] and then take out the other.28 To what extent [is skipping in the Torah permitted]? R. Jose said: As, for instance, the sections29 [read on the Day of Atonement] by the High Priest.30

RULE 4. If the precentor read in the Torah on a Sabbath for less than seven persons,31 having forgotten and thought that he had already read for32 seven persons, he should read again completing the number of seven, and call up an eighth as mafṭir; provided always that the lection33 consists of [a minimum of] twenty-one verses and allows three verses for each of the seven persons who are called up. And if a section consists of less [than three verses for each of the seven persons]34 an addition should be made to the section from the one following it.35

RULE 5. If a section consisted of four or five verses, he reads the whole of it, but with a section of six verses he may read and make a break36 because it has the [minimum] length for two readings. If on a Monday or Thursday, or the Sabbath afternoon service or the afternoon service of Festivals37 less than ten verses38 were read, he should repeat the reading to complete ten verses. From where [in the Torah] does one read in the afternoon service of a Festival [when it occurs on a Sabbath]?39 In the regular order where [the Torah reading] was interrupted before the Festival.40

RULE 6. If in the course of public reading he skipped a verse and omitted to read it, should he have read ten verses exclusive41 of the verse skipped, he need not go back; but if less than42 ten, he must go back and read ten verses in correct order so that none is left out. This is the case with [the reading of] a week-day,43 Sabbath afternoon and Festival afternoon;44 but on a Sabbath [morning] if he forgot and passed over a verse and then realized [his mistake], he must stop45 and re-read [the passage in full]. Even after one had read the hafṭarah in [a Book of] a Prophet and recited the musaf, he must stop forthwith and read [the Scriptural passage]. The musaf, however,46 need not be repeated.
chapter.ftnote: (1) The number corresponds to the three main divisions of the Bible: the Pentateuch, Prophets and Hagiographa; Meg. 24a (Sonc. ed., p. 143).
(2) Who translated and expounded the Heb. text into Aramaic for the congregation.
(3) So that the interpreter, who had no book before him, should not become confused.
(4) If desired. Since no instruction in law is involved in the lection from the Prophets as in the Torah, a mistake would not be serious.
(5) For the interpreter.
(6) Isa. LII, 3.
(7) ibid. 4.
(8) ibid. 5.
(9) ‘All’ is added by GRA, M and H.

(10) lit. ‘between reading and reading’. The number of times he sits down corresponds to the number of persons who are to be called up for the reading. This ruling applies to the time when only the first and last who were called up recited the benedictions before and after the reading. At the present time, when each person called up recites the benedictions before and after his portion, there is no need for the sitting down.
(11) Omitting the intermediate portions.
(12) The unrolling of which might disturb the congregation.
(13) GRA in agreement with j.Meg. IV, 5, 75b. V and H read ‘interpreted it, as for instance’.
(14) And consequently no unrolling is required. Why, then, should skipping in such a case be forbidden?
(15) lit. ‘but’ added by GRA. V and H omit.
(16) lit. after the death, designating the section Lev. XVI.

(17) lit. howbeit on the tenth, designating the section beginning Lev. XXIII, 27. These sections are far removed from one another and the Torah scroll must consequently be unrolled in public. Why is this permitted?
(18) Therefore unrolling in public is permitted.
(19) i.e. the Day of Atonement. As they form one subject, skipping from place to place is allowed.
(20) lit. ‘and you may know’.
(21) lit. ‘in every place one may not’.
(22) The section beginning And on the tenth day (Num. XXIX, 7).
(23) For the reason stated above.
(24) So j.Meg. IV, 5, 75b, the text of which is followed here. V has ‘Mar’.
(25) In Upper Galilee.
(26) When skipping is necessary from one passage to another.
(27) There is no need to return the scroll to the ark after the first reading had concluded and then take it out again for the second section.
(28) The present custom is to take both scrolls from the ark at the same time and to keep the second rolled and wrapped until the completion of the reading from the first.

(29) Which are not so far from one another as to cause the interpreter to stop and keep the congregation waiting while the scroll is being unrolled to the second section, and deal with the same subject, thus causing no confusion to the hearers.
(30) So GRA and H in agreement with j.Meg. loc. cit. The reading of V is ‘Jehoiada the priest’.
(31) lit. ‘readings or callings’, i.e. the lection was allocated to less than the minimum number.
(32) Or, ‘had called up’.
(33) lit. ‘the order’, the prescribed section for the reading of the day.

(34) This apparently refers to ancient Synagogues where only short portions of the Torah were read or where it was completed once in three years, not annually as is the present custom. Then the section for a Sabbath may sometimes have been very short.
(35) lit. ‘from another portion’.
(36) At the end of the third verse.
(37) On which occasion three persons are called to the reading of the Torah.

(38) According to some authorities, if nine verses were read no repetition of the reading is necessary (cf. ’Oraḥ Ḥayyim CXXXVII, §1 and commentaries ad loc.). Others maintain that in general ten is the minimum number.
(39) On a Festival which occurs on a week-day there is no reading from the Torah in the afternoon service.
(40) i.e. from the beginning of the lection of the next Sabbath.
(41) So GRA and H. V has ‘from’.
(42) lit. ‘within’.
(43) i.e. Monday and Thursday.
(44) Since the omitted verses will be read on the following Sabbath morning in the course of the lection.
(45) Added by GRA.
(46) So GRA. V inserts ‘because’ which cannot be justified.

chapter.title: CHAPTER XII
chapter.p: RULE 1. It is permitted to make a break1 in the blessings2 but not in the curses.3 R. Ḥiyya b. Gamda said: What is the reason?4 Because it is written [My son, despise not the chastening of the Lord,]5 neither cut thou up His correction6—do not cut them7 up into pieces.8

RULE 2. R. Levi said:9 The Holy One, blessed be He, said: It is not proper that My children shall be cursed while I am being blessed.10 R. Jose b. Abin said: It is not for this reason, but because one who stands up to read in the Torah must begin and conclude with something auspicious.11

RULE 3. Levi b. Paṭi enquired of R. Hanina, ‘What is the law in regard to the curses each of which begins with ’arur?12 Must they be read by one person only,13 and must a benediction be recited before and after them?’ He replied, ‘There is no [passage] that requires a benediction before and after its reading but the curses of Leviticus14 and Deuteronomy’.15

RULE 4. When Jonathan, a children’s teacher from Gufta,16 came down here,17 he saw a children’s teacher, R. Abuna, reading the Song of the Well18 and reciting the benedictions before and after it. ‘Is it proper,’ he asked him, ‘to act in this manner?’19 ‘Do you,’ the other retorted, ‘still require [a ruling] on this subject? All poems20 must be preceded and followed by benedictions.’

RULE 5. A question21 was asked of22 R. Simon. ‘There is no section’,23 he told them in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi, ‘which requires a benediction before and after its reading other than the Song at the Sea, the Ten Words,24 and the curses in Deuteronomy’.25

RULE 6. R. Abahu26 said: I have not heard [such a ruling],27 but it is feasible to apply it to the Ten Words. R. Jose b. Abin said in the name of Rabbi:28 The last ten verses in Deuteronomy29 require a benediction before and after they have been read.30

RULE 7. R. Isaac Seḥorah asked R. Isaac Nappaḥa, ‘What do we read [first]31 when the New Moon of Ṭebeth32 falls on a Sabbath?’33 [He replied,] ‘In the section of kalloth,34 while the mafṭir reads35 the passages relating to the Sabbath and the New Moon.36 If it falls on a week-day we call up on the first day37 three persons for the reading of the New Moon, the fourth reading that of Ḥanukkah, because that which is more frequent takes precedence.38 But since the reading of the New Moon was read first,39 [40a] three persons are to be called up on the second day for the reading of the Ḥanukkah passage,40 while the fourth reads41 the section of the New Moon, viz. uberashë ḥodshekem42 to the end of the passage.43 Why is this so?44 Because it was only on account of the New Moon musaf that a fourth person is added’.45

RULE 8. R. Jose b. Abin said: For the Song of Ha’azinu46 not less than six persons47 are to be called up, and your mnemonic sign48 is h z y w l k,49 which stands for ha’azinu,50 zekor,51 yarkibehu,52 wayyishman,53 lu,54 ki yadin … ‘ammo.55 It must also be provided with56 the space of a full line above it and of a full line below it. Corresponding to it the custom has been adopted to write in the Torah its number of lines.57

RULE 9. A mnemonic sign for the beginnings of the lines58 is the following: ha’azinu,59 ya‘arof,60 kise‘irim,61 ki,62 haẓẓur,63 ’el,64 shiḥeth,65 halaH,66 halo’,67 zekor,68 she’al,69 behanḥel,70 yaẓẓeb,71 ki,72 yimẓa’ehu,73 yesobebenhu,74 kannesher,75 yifros,76 the Tetragrammaton,77 yarkibehu,78 wayyeniḳehu,79 ḥem’ath,80 we’elim,81 wedam,82 shamanta,83 wayyenabbel,84 betho‘eboth,85 ’Elohim,86 lo’,87 wattishkaḥ,88 mikka‘as,89 ’er’eh,90 banim,91 ki‘asuni,92 begoi,93 wattiḳad,94 wattelaheṭ,95 ḥiẓẓai,96 weḳeṭeb,97 ‘im,98 umeḥadarim,99 yoneḳ,100 ’ashbithah,101 pen,102 welo’,103 we’ain,104 yabinu,105 ushenayim,106 waH,107 w’oyebenu,108 umishshadmoth,109 ’ashkeloth,110 werosh,111 ḥathum,112 le‘eth,113 weḥash,114 we‘al,115 we’efes,116 ẓur,117 yishtu,118 yehi,119 we’ain,120 maḥaẓti,121, ki,122 ’im,123 ’ashib,124 ’ashkir,125 middam,126 harninu,127 wenaḳam.128

RULE 10. R. Ze‘ira, quoting R. Jeremiah, in the name of Rab, said; The Song at the Sea129 and the Song of Deborah130 are written in the form of a half-brick over a whole brick,131 and a whole brick over a half-brick.132

RULE 11. The Song at the Sea consists of thirty lines [beginning with the words:] ’az,133 le’mor,134 werokebo,135 lishu‘ah,136 ’abi,137 shemo,138 shalishaw,139 ’aben,140 the Tetragrammaton,141 kameka,142 ’appeka,143 nozelim,144 ’oyeb,145 nafshi,146 beruṭaka,147 ’addirim,148 kamokah,149 pele’,150 beḥasdeka,151 kodsheka,152 ’aḥaz,153 ’Edom,154 kol,155 wafaḥad,156 ya‘abor,157 ḳanitha,158 leshibteka,159 yadeka,160 ba’,161 më.162

RULE 12. The mark for the Song of Deborah is ‘sixty-four lines’163 [beginning with the words:] wattashar,164 le’mor,165 ‘am,166 rozenim,167 laH,168 misse‘ir,169 ra‘ashah,170 mayyim,171 Sinai,172 ‘Anath,173 nethiboth,174 ḥadelu,175 ’em,176 ḥadashim,177 ’im,178 beYisra’el,179 ba‘am,180 ẓeḥoroth,181 ‘al,182 mash’abim,183 pirzono,184 the Tetragrammaton,185 ‘uri,186 ’Abino‘am,187 yerad,188 ba‘Amaleḳ,189 Makir,190 sofer,191 ken,192 beraglaw,193 ḥiḳeḳe leb,194 hammishpethayim,195 Re’uben,196 shaken,197 yashab,198 yishkon,199 ‘al,200 nilḥamu,201 ‘al,202 laḳaḥu,203 mimmesilotham,204 gerafam,205 nafshi,206 sus,207 Meroz,208 yoshebeha,209 the Tetragrammaton,210 Ya‘el,211 ba’ohel,212 nathanah,213 layyathed,214 ‘amelim,215 weḥalefah,216 shakab,217 kara‘,218 watteyabbeb,219 boshesh,220 marke-bothaw,221 hi,’222 shalal,223 ẓeba‘im,224 riḳmah,225 yobedu,226 bigburatho.227

(2) e.g. Lev. XXVI, 3-13.
(4) Why may not more than one person be called to the section of the curses?
(5) This is the first part of the verse which is not quoted in the text of the Tractate.
(6) Prov. III, 11, E.V. neither spurn.

Only with these passages, which are not restricted to a particular time, are the benedictions recited before and after they have been read; but with the ’arur curses, which were spoken by the Levites only (cf. Deut. XXVII, 14) and at the time when the Jordan was crossed (ibid. 2), no benedictions are to be recited.

(17) Tiberias where R. Abuna re-sided. The city is a on lower level, hence the verb ‘came down’.

(19) The rule is that the benedictions are recited only at the beginning and end of the entire section to be read. The Song of the Well, appearing in the middle of a section, should consequently require no benedictions before and after its reading.

(30) These verses, which describe the death of Moses, form a section of their own, because they were written by Joshua (according to R. Judah or R. Nehemiah) or, if written by Moses, they were dictated to him by God while he ‘wrote them down with tears’ (B.B. 15a, Sonc. ed., p. 72).
(31) In the second and third scrolls.
(32) Which always occurs in the week of Ḥanukkah.
(33) Three scrolls are then taken from the ark. The usual weekly portion is read in the first, and the passages for New Moon and Ḥanukkah in the second and third.
(34) E.V. made an end (Num. VII, 1). This designates the entire section, descriptive of the dedication offerings brought by the princes of Israel, which is prescribed for the reading of the day.
(35) In the third scroll.
(36) Num. XXVIII, 9-15. The present custom is always to read the section for the Sabbath and New Moon first, and then the passage for Ḥanukkah.

(38) The New Moon occurs monthly, Ḥanukkah once a year.
(39) On the first day of the New Moon.
(40) In the first scroll. Only two scrolls are taken out on a week-day during Ḥanukkah.

(45) On the other week-days of Ḥanukkah there is no musaf. This argument cannot be applied to the first day of the New Moon because it is the second day which begins the month. The first of the two days of the New Moon is the last day of the preceding month. V and H insert here a ruling which has no connection with this chapter and is practically identical with XIV, 2 below.

(46) E.V. give ear, designating the section Deut. XXXII, 1-43. For Ha’azinu (the reading of GRA) V and H read ‘the Levites’, because the poem was sung by the Levites in the Temple during the Sabbath musaf in six parts on successive Sabbaths.
(47) Because the Levites concluded it in cycles of six Sabbath divisions.
(48) For the words beginning each of the six parts. The divisions, according to Maimonides, emphasize the exhortations and arouse the people to repentance.

(195) Among the sheepfolds (16).
(196) Reuben (ibid.).
(198) Dwelt (ibid.).
(199) Abideth (ibid.).
(201) They fought (19).
(202) By (ibid.).
(203) They took (ibid.).
(204) In their courses (20).
(205) Swept them away (21).
(206) O my soul (ibid.).
(207) Horse [hoofs] (22).
(209) The inhabitants thereof (ibid.).
(210) The Lord [against the mighty] (ibid.).
(212) In the tent (ibid.).
(213) She gave (25).
(214) To the tent-pin (26).
(215) Workmen (ibid.).
(216) And struck through (ibid.).
(218) He sunk (ibid.).
(219) And peered (28).
(220) So long (ibid.).
(221) His chariots (ibid.).
(224) Dyed garments (ibid.).
(225) Embroidery (ibid.).
(226) So perish (31).

(227) In his might (ibid.). The last twelve words are according to the reading of GRA. V has instead only ten, which do not present a likely division of the lines and are not followed in current editions of the Hebrew Bible.

chapter.title: CHAPTER XIII
chapter.p: RULE 1. In regard, however,1 to the Song of David in Samuel2 and in the Psalms,3 the Sages have not prescribed a limit;4 but a skilled scribe spaces them out symmetrically5 according to the beginnings, the middle pauses, and the endings of the verses.6 A similar arrangement is also followed throughout the Psalms and in Job and Proverbs.
RULE 2. The scroll of Esther7 requires ruled lines8 as does the real9 Torah,10 because it is called ‘a scroll’.11

RULE 3. The ten sons of Haman12 and the kings of Canaan13 are written in the form of a half-brick over a half-brick and a brick over a brick.14 Such a structure15 does not endure.16 What is implied by ‘such’?17 Does it indicate a recommendation18 or an indispensable condition?19

RULE 4. R. Jose20 said to R. Ḥanina, the nephew of R. Hoshaiah, ‘Surely you remember that when we were standing in front of the shop of your uncle, R. Hoshaiah, R. Ba’ b. Zabda passed by and we put the question to him, and he replied that the condition was indispensable’.
RULE 5. R. Ḥiyya b. R. Adda of Jaffa, quoting R. Jeremiah in the name of R. Ze‘ira, said: The names of the ten sons of Haman and the word ten21 must be recited in one breath.

RULE 6. R. Jose b. Abin said: When they22 are written down, the word ’ish23 must be at the top of the column24 and each we’eth25 at the end [of the lines, a total] of eleven lines,26 and ‘asereth at the end of the column. Thus, in reading transversely, the columns27 appear laced and closely corded like transverse lacing [of a web].28 It symbolizes that when [the ten sons] fall there will be no rising for them.

The phrase ’aḥar haddebarim … Hammedatha29 was translated by R. Joseph as follows:30 ‘After these things did king Ahasuerus promote Haman the son of Hammedatha the Aggagite, son of Seraḥ,31 son of Buza, son of Aflutos,32 son of Deosis,33 son of Padom,34 son of Ma‘adi,35 son of Be‘alkon,36 son of Antamarus,37 son of Ḥarum,38 son of Hadoram,39 son of Shazar,40 son of Nagar,41 son of Parshandatha,42 son of Wayezatha, son of ‘Amaleḳ,43 son of the concubine of Eliphaz the firstborn of Esau; he advanced him and set his seat above all his princes and his servants, because pride goeth before destruction’.44
RULE 7. R. Ze‘ira said: The waw of Wayezatha45 must project like a boat-pole on the river Libruth.46

RULE 8. If a person holds a scroll of the Torah [in order to read it], there is a difference of opinion between two Tanna’im.47 One declared that he should open it, look [for the passage which is to be read], roll it up and then say the benediction;48 but the other declared that he should open it, look [for the required passage] and say the benediction.49 What is the reason?50 Because it is written, And when he opened it, all the people stood up;51 and what follows? And Ezra blessed52 the Lord, the great God.53 Whereby did he proclaim His greatness?54 Rab said: He proclaimed His greatness by pronouncing the Ineffable Name.55 Raba said: He proclaimed His greatness by the recital of the prescribed benediction.

What is the form of the benedictions?56 In an assembly of ten57 one says, ‘Bless ye the Lord Who is to be blessed’.58 In the case of an individual, when he rises early to read in the Torah, he says, ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, Who hast given us a Torah from heaven, everlasting life from the heights. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who givest the Torah’. Then59 he rolls up the scroll60 and says, ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, Who hast given us a Torah of truth and hast planted everlasting life in our midst. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who givest the Torah’.61

RULE 9. Similarly when one reads from the Prophets,62 a benediction is said as follows: ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, Who hast chosen good prophets, and hast found pleasure in their words which were spoken in truth. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who hast chosen the Torah and Moses Thy servant, and Israel Thy people, and the prophets of truth and righteousness’.63

RULE 10. And at the end [of the reading of the portion from the Prophets], one says the following benedictions: ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, Rock of all worlds, righteous through all generations, O faithful God, Who sayest and doest, Who speakest64 and fulfillest, all Whose words are truth and righteousness’. The people forthwith stand and say:65 ‘Faithful art Thou, O Lord our God, faithful are Thy words, ever faithful, living and enduring are Thy name and remembrance; and do Thou reign66 continually over us for ever and ever’. This point67 is one of the disagreements between the scholars of the East and West; the former give the response68 while sitting and the latter while standing. But wherever two Tanna’im or two ’Amora’im differ, and we are not certain with whom the halakah agrees, we follow him who maintains the stricter view. How much more then must we, in regard to the praise69 of the Life of all the worlds,70 which is a matter of the heart,71 teach our disciples as the rule to be practised that the halakah is in agreement with him who upholds the stricter view;72 as Scripture states, The Lord hath made every thing for His own purpose.73

RULE 11. After that74 the mafṭir resumes his recital75 and says, ‘Faithful art Thou, O Lord our God, and faithful are Thy words, and not one of Thy words shall return void, for Thou art a faithful76 God and King. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, the God Who art faithful in all Thy words’.

RULE 12. ‘Comfort,77 O Lord our God, Zion Thy city, for it is the home of our life, and save her that is grieved in spirit speedily, even in our days. [40b] Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who makest Zion joyful through her children.’

RULE 13. ‘Gladden us, O Lord our God,78 with Elijah the prophet, Thy servant, and with the kingdom of the house of David, Thine anointed. Soon may he come and rejoice our hearts. Suffer not a stranger to sit upon his throne, nor let others any longer inherit his glory; for by Thy holy name Thou didst swear unto him, that his light should not be quenched for ever. In his days Judah shall be saved, and Israel shall dwell safely; and this is his name whereby he shall be called: the Lord is our righteousness.79 Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who causest the horn of salvation to flourish for Thy people Israel.’80

RULE 14. ‘For the Torah, [for the divine service],81 for the prophets and for this holy82 … which Thou, O Lord our God, hast given us for holiness and for rest, for honour and for glory. For all these things, O Lord our God, we thank Thee, and continually bless83 Thy name, O God of our salvation. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who sanctifiest Israel and such and such a day.’84

An exception is made on the Sabbath when ‘Israel’ is not mentioned in the conclusion but only ‘Who sanctifiest the Sabbath’; because the Sabbath preceded Israel, as it is written, For in six days the Lord made heaven and earth, and on the seventh day He ceased from work and rested,85 and it is further said, See that the Lord hath given you the sabbath,86 which implies that the Sabbath had already been in existence.
chapter.ftnote: (1) In contrast to the poems dealt with in the previous Rule.
(2) 2 Sam. XXII.
(3) Ps. XVIII.
(4) For the number of lines in a column.
(5) In the form of stichoi.
(6) This rendering follows the text in M and H.
(7) Which is read on Purim.
(8) To guide the scribe in writing the letters which are suspended from them.
(9) lit. ‘its truth of’.
(10) Here denotes the Pentateuch.
(11) The text corrected by GRA. V has ‘scroll called’. ‘Scroll’ is lit. ‘book’, the word used in Esth. IX, 32. For another reason, cf. Meg. 16b (Sonc. ed., p. 100).
(14) Like the song of Ha’azinu (cf. above XII, 8).
(15) In which bricks and half-bricks rest one above the other and do not overlap.
(16) And so is symbolic of the fate of Haman’s sons.
(17) The statement ‘such a structure does not last’.
(18) As the arrangement is only a symbol, a deviation from it would not disqualify the scroll.
(19) A deviation would then lead to disqualification. The answer follows in the next Rule.

(20) The translation follows GRA and H in agreement with j.Meg. III, 7, 74b. V reads: ‘R. Jose b. Ḥanina, the brother of R. Hoshaiah, R. Abba b. Zabda surrounded thee, and we asked him this, and he said in the name of Rab that the condition was indispensable’.
(21) Esth. IX, 10.
(22) The names of Haman’s sons.
(23) Man, the last word of Esth. IX, 6.
(24) And at the beginning of the first line.
(25) Sign of the defined accusative which occurs ten times, each preceding the names of the ten sons.

(26) The first line consisting of ’ish on the right and we’eth on the left, the next nine lines having the name on the right and we’eth on the left, while the eleventh line has the name Wayezatha on the right and ‘asereth (ten) on the left.
(27) On the right (consisting of ’ish and the ten names), and the left (ten times we’eth and ‘asereth).
(28) The reading of V is corrupt and the translation follows GRA, N.Y. and Jastrow.
(29) Esth. III, 1, E.V. After these things did king Ahasuerus promote Haman the son of Hammedatha.
(30) R. Joseph is the reputed author of a later Aramaic translation of the Prophets and Hagiographa.

(31) A name derived from a root ‘to stink’. The object of the genealogy is to trace Haman, the symbol of the enemies of Jews throughout their history, through a chain of despicable men to Esau, the brother but enemy of the patriarch Jacob.
(32) Buza means ‘contempt’, and Aflutos is probably Plutos, a heathen god.
(33) Dionysus (?).
(34) Or, Pados (putrid?).
(35) Meaning ‘sickness’.
(36) The meaning is ‘cunning’.
(37) Signifying ‘crushed stones’.
(38) Or, Ḥuram, possibly the heathen god Ares.
(39) Or, Heridos, i.e. Herod who is known in history as a tyrant.
(40) Meaning ‘hip disease’
(41) Or, possibly, Negad (a whip).
(42) This and the following were also names of two of Haman’s sons.
(43) The ancestor of the people who were the first to attack Israel after their exodus from Egypt.
(44) The last four words come from Prov. XVI, 18. The translation of the paragraph embodies most of GRA’s emendations.
(45) Esth. IX, 9.
(46) i.e. the waw must be longer than the other letters. The ruling is quoted from Meg. 16b (Sonc. ed., p. 99). The river has not been identified.
(47) On the question whether the prescribed benedictions should be said while the scroll is open or rolled.
(48) Were one to say it while the scroll is open, people might erroneously assume that the benediction is written in the Torah (Meg. 32a, Sonc. ed., pp. 192f).
(49) Because nobody could be so ignorant as to be unaware that the benedictions do not form a part of the text of the Torah (Meg. loc. cit.).
(50) That the scroll must be open when the benediction is said.
(51) Neh. VIII, 5 referring to the scroll of the Torah.
(52) i.e. he said the prescribed benedictions.
(53) ibid. 6. As Ezra opened the scroll and blessed the Lord, so everyone who reads the Torah must have the scroll open when the benedictions are said.
(54) As implied in the words the great God.
(55) The Tetragrammaton.
(56) Before and after the reading in the Torah.
(57) A minimum of ten males over the age of thirteen is required for congregational worship.
(58) And then follow the benedictions given later for an individual in private reading.
(59) At the conclusion of the reading.
(60) This is a unanimous ruling. It is upheld even by the Rabbi who maintained that the scroll must be open when the first benediction is said.
(61) The benedictions now in use are shorter (P.B., p. 147).
(62) The hafṭarah which is read after the conclusion of the prescribed section of the Torah.
(63) Wehaẓẓedeḳ, the noun being preceded by he, the definite article. This is the version adopted by the Sefaradim, while the Ashkenazim omit the article (cf. P.B., p. 149).
(64) V reads medabber, without the article, as in the current version (P.B., loc. cit.).
(65) This is not the present usage when the reader proceeds to say the benedictions mentioned in Rule 11.
(66) So GRA. V reads ‘He will reign’, H ‘Thou wilt reign’.
(67) Whether the benediction is to be said while sitting or standing.
(68) To the reader, with the benediction.
(69) The benedictions.
(70) [On this designation of God, cf. Marmorstein, The Old Rabbinic Doctrine of God, I, p. 85.]
(71) V reads galuï (revealed), M and H taluï (dependent).
(72) Following the emended text of GRA.
(73) Prov. XVI, 4. There is consequently all the more reason why the stricter view should be followed, viz. that the blessings and praises of God be said while standing.
(74) After the people have concluded their benedictions (see the preceding Rule).
(75) lit. ‘subject’.
(76) The current version adds ‘and merciful’ (P.B., p. 149).

(77) This is the continuation of the benedictions after the hafṭarah. The version now in use (P.B., loc. cit.) reads ‘have mercy’ instead of ‘comfort’ (GRA emends accordingly), and ‘O Lord our God’ and ‘Thy city’ are omitted.
(78) From ‘with Elijah’ to ‘swear unto him’ is represented in V by ‘etc.’ M and H cite the benediction in full.
(79) ‘In his days … righteousness’ is a quotation from Jer. XXIII, 6 and is now omitted from the benediction.
(80) The present custom (in accordance with Pes. 117b, Sonc. ed., p. 603) is to conclude, ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord, the Shield of David’.
(81) M and H insert this phrase which is included in P.B.
(82) The ‘Sabbath’ or the name of the Festival is inserted here; and when a Festival coincides with the Sabbath both are mentioned.
(83) The P.B. version reads, ‘Thee, blessed be Thy name by the mouth of every living being continually and for ever’.
(84) For ‘such and such a day’ the name of the Festival is inserted.
(85) Ex. XXXI, 17.

(86) ibid. XVI, 29. The Sabbath was instituted at the creation of the world, and the use of the definite article in the second quotation indicates that it was a well-known institution at the time. The Festivals, on the other hand, were ordained after the people of Israel came into existence.

chapter.title: CHAPTER XIV
chapter.p: RULE 1. And why did [the Rabbis] enact all these [benedictions]?1 In order to establish a correspondence between the seven benedictions [of the hafṭarah] and the seven readers.2 You may also similarly explain the reason for the twenty-two verses read in the [Book of a] Prophet: twenty-two corresponding to the seven readers, each of whom must read [a minimum of] three verses, and one corresponding to the superintendent of the Synagogue services.

RULE 2. All that had been said3 applies only where the text was neither translated nor expounded; but where it was translated or expounded4 the mafṭir reads three, five or six verses in the Prophet, and this suffices.5

RULE 3. In the case of Ruth, the Song of Songs, Ecclesiastes,6 Lamentations and Esther,7 it is necessary to say the benediction, ‘Concerning the reading of the Megillah’,8 although it is included in the Hagiographa.

RULE 4. One who reads in the Hagiographa must say, ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, Who hast sanctified us by Thy commandments and hast given us command to read in the Holy Writings’.

RULE 5. [The Rabbis] enacted that, as regards [the reading of] the scroll of Esther, the benediction on the ‘season’ must be said;9 and after the conclusion of the reading the reader must say, ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, O God Who dost plead our cause, judge our suit and avenge our wrong, Who redeemest and savest us from the hand of all tyrants. Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, Helper and Saviour’.10 The benediction is said11 on account of the humiliation of the Torah, while others maintain that it is said on account of the humiliation of Israel.12

RULE 6. [The Rabbis] further laid down that it is also necessary to offer praise and thanksgiving [in the benediction] for the redemption and release.13 Then one concludes: ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord, God of vengeance, Who dost requite enemies according to their deeds, art a Shield to the righteous, and savest Thy people from the hands of their adversaries’. After that the righteous are lauded: ‘Blessed be Mordecai, blessed be Esther, blessed be all Israel’. Rab, however, declared that it is necessary to say, ‘Accursed be Haman and accursed be his sons’. R. Phinehas said: It is necessary to say, ‘Harbonah be remembered for good’.14

RULE 7. R. Berekiah, quoting R. Jeremiah who had it from R. Ḥiyya, who reported it in the name of R. Joḥanan, said: When R. Jonathan came to the verse, Whom Nebuchadnezzar … had carried away,15 he used to exclaim, ‘O the wicked Nebuchadnezzar, may his bones be crushed! the good is rewarded16 according to his goodness and the wicked according to his wickedness, as it is stated, The memory of the righteous shall be for a blessing; but the name of the wicked shall rot’.17

RULE 8. The mafṭir recites also the parts of the Shema‘.18 Of what Shema‘ has this been said?19 Of the one [recited when] the scroll of the Torah [is taken from the ark].20 How does one begin?21 Happy are they that dwell in Thy house.22 Then the mafṭir stands and recites, There is none like unto Thee among the gods, O Lord; and there are no works like Thine.23 Who is like unto Thee, O Lord, among the mighty? Who is like unto Thee, glorious in holiness, fearful in praises, doing wonders?24 Thy kingdom is a kingdom for all ages, and Thy dominion endureth throughout all generations.25 The Lord is King, the Lord hath reigned, the Lord shall reign for ever and ever.26 The Lord was pleased, for His righteousness’ sake, to make the teaching great and glorious.27 The Lord will give strength unto His people; the Lord will bless His people with peace.28 Thou art the Lord, even Thou alone; Thou hast made heaven, the heaven of heavens, with all their host, the earth and all things that are therein, the seas and all that is in them and Thou preservest them all; and the host of heaven worshippeth Thee.29
RULE 9. Thereupon30 the mafṭir steps forward,31 takes the scroll of the Torah and says, Hear, O Israel, chanting the first verse,32 and the people say it after him in response.

RULE 10. [The mafṭir] then elevates the Torah scroll and says: ‘One is our God, great is our Lord, holy and revered is His name for ever and ever’.33 Then he repeats: ‘One is our God, great is our Lord, holy is He. One is our God, great is our Lord, holy and revered is His name’. [This is said three times] corresponding in number34 to the three patriarchs; others hold that it corresponds to the three kedushshoth.35

RULE 11.36 ‘Thy righteousness also, O God, reacheth unto high heaven; Thou Who hast done great things, O God, who is like unto Thee?37 O Lord, Thy name endureth for ever; Thy memorial, O Lord, throughout all generations.38 Let all ascribe strength to God and give honour to the Torah. O magnify the Lord with me, and let us exalt His name together.’39 The Torah scroll must be elevated at Hear, O Israel, at the threefold declaration of the unity of God, and at O magnify the Lord with me.40

RULE 12. One must also say:41 ‘Magnified and hallowed,42 praised and glorified, exalted and extolled, uplifted, honoured and adored43 above all be the name of the supreme King of kings, the Holy One, blessed be He, in the worlds which He hath created, this world and the world to come, in accordance with His desire and the desire of all His people, the house of Israel. May His kingdom be revealed and made visible unto us speedily and at a near time; and may He build His house in our days, and be gracious unto our remnant and unto the remnant of His people Israel in His mercy and in the abundance of His lovingkindness, in peace and grace, kindness and compassion. May the Omnipresent do all this for us for the sake of His great name; and say ye, Amen’.44

RULE 13. After that he elevates the Torah scroll and says: ‘One is our God, great is our Lord, holy and revered is His name for ever and ever’. Then he begins to chant, ‘The Lord is God, the Lord is His name’. The congregation says it after him in response; then he repeats it twice and the congregation responds twice.45

RULE 14. The scroll of the Torah is immediately unrolled a space of three columns and is elevated so as to show the face of the script to the people standing on the right and on the left. Then it is turned round towards the front and towards the rear; for it is a precept for all men and women to see the script,46 to bend their knees and exclaim, ‘And this is the Torah which Moses set before the children of Israel.47 The Torah of the Lord is perfect, restoring the soul’.48 The mafṭir then hands it over to the superintendent of the Synagogue services who returns it to the first49 of those who are to be called to the reading, because it is not an honour for the Torah to be left alone.50 Similarly it is not proper for the precentor to stand alone before the reading-desk; so [two persons] should stand with him, one on his right and the other on his left, [the number] corresponding to that of the patriarchs.51 The pure-minded men of Jerusalem acted in this manner: When the Torah scroll was taken out of the ark and when it was returned they followed it as a mark of respect.

RULE 15. A minor52 may read in the Torah and translate it, but he may not read the parts of the Shema‘53 by reciting ‘Who formest light’;54 nor may he stand before the reading-desk,55 nor lift up his hands.56 A poḥeaḥ, that is one whose knees are exposed or whose clothes are torn, or one whose head is uncovered, may read the parts of the Shema‘. Others say that if a person’s knees [are exposed] or his clothes torn he may read the parts of the Shema‘, but one may not do so when his head is uncovered, since it is not permitted to utter the divine names [with uncovered head]. In either case he may translate, but not read in the Torah, nor stand before the reading-desk, nor lift up his hands.
RULE 16. A blind man may recite the parts of the Shema‘ and translate. R. Judah said: One who has never seen the light may not read the parts of the Shema‘.57

RULE 17. The minor of whom the Rabbis spoke58 is one who is under twelve years of age. A person who is above that age may read the parts of the Shema‘, but may not stand before the reading-desk nor lift up his hands59 until he is twenty years of age and bearded. If he has no beard, although he is twenty years of age, he is forbidden to do so because60 he looks like an eunuch. Others say that even an actual eunuch is permitted [to perform these acts]. If, however, a person has grown a beard even from the age of eighteen, he may stand before the reading-desk and lift up his hands.

RULE 18. As regards the scroll of Esther, all are qualified to read it except a deaf person, an imbecile and a minor. R. Judah declared a minor to be qualified. R. Levi said: The scroll of Esther must be read [on Purim] at night and repeated in the daytime, as it is stated, So that my glory may sing praise to Thee—i.e. by night, and not be silent61—i.e. by day. (Therefore it is customary to read it at the termination of the Sabbath of two [successive weeks].)62 [41a] When R. Meir once passed by a Synagogue he heard the reading of63 a section [of the scroll of Esther].64 ‘How long,’ he said to them, ‘will you be cutting up the Torah65 into sections?’66 [‘We do it’], they replied, ‘on account of my glory may sing praise unto Thee’, and he allowed them [to continue the practice]. People have adopted the practice of reading it on two67 Saturday nights of Adar until fifteen days of the month have elapsed. In what manner is it read? At [the termination of] the first Sabbath of Adar the people read together up to In that night,68 and on the next Saturday night they read from In that night up to and speaking peace to all his seed.69
In the case of the Song of Songs, it is read on the last [two] nights of the [Passover] Festival,70 half of it on the first night and the other half on the second night.

Ruth [is read] on the termination of the first day of Pentecost to [the end of] its [first] half, and concluded on the termination of the last day of the Festival. Others hold that with all the Festivals, we begin to read [the respective scrolls] on the Saturday night preceding them. People have also adopted the following procedure, viz. that no ruling is authoritatively laid down unless a custom71 had been definitely established.72 As regards the saying of the Rabbis that ‘a custom cancels a ruling’,73 it applies to a custom of the pious men of old; but a custom which has no support from the Torah is only like an error of judgment.74

RULE 19. As we read [the weekly portion] from the Torah and the hafṭarah from the Prophet in daytime, so it is obligatory to read the scroll of Esther in daytime;75 as it is stated, In the day that the enemies of the Jews hoped,76 on which it was taught in the Mishnah:77 The whole of the day is a proper time for the reading of the scroll of Esther.

RULE 20. There is no difference between scrolls [of Scripture] and tefillin and mezuzoth save that the scrolls,78 etc. If a tefillah had worn out, no mezuzah may be made of it;79 but if a mezuzah had worn out it may be made into tefillin,80 because in sacred matters ascent to a higher degree of sanctity is allowed but not descent to a lesser degree.
chapter.ftnote: (1) For the hafṭarah as specified in the previous chapter.
(2) The minimum number who must be called to the reading of the Torah every Sabbath.
(3) In the preceding Rule concerning the minimum number of verses to be read in the Prophet.
(4) So that much of the time of the worshippers was taken up by the translation or exposition.
(5) The reading is curtailed for the convenience of the congregation.
(6) Inserted by GRA and H.
(7) These books are read respectively on Pentecost, Passover, Tabernacles, the Fast of Ab and Purim.

(8) The full benediction is: ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, Who hast sanctified us by Thy commandments, and hast given us command concerning the reading of the Megillah’ (P.B., p. 276). The present custom is to say the benediction for the scroll of Esther only. The others are read usually from a printed book without a benediction.
(9) Like the benediction in the preceding note it begins with ‘Blessed art Thou … universe’ and concludes with ‘Who hast kept us in life, and hast preserved us, and enabled us to reach this season’.
(10) Cf. the version in P.B., p. 276.

(11) The reason for the benediction is given to explain why it must begin with ‘Blessed art Thou’, although it would appear to be a continuation of the benediction for the Megillah which includes this beginning.

(12) Whose vindication is celebrated. As it is independent of the Megillah, it must consequently begin again with the usual formula. For ‘Torah’, M and H read ‘the Divine Presence’ affronted by Haman’s plot against God’s people.
(13) From threatened destruction.
(14) He contributed to Haman’s downfall (cf. Esth. VII, 9). For the version now in use, cf. P.B., p. 277.
(15) Esth II, 6.
(16) lit. ‘to mix’ (drinks), hence ‘to serve drinks’ and, metaphorically, ‘retribution, recompense’.
(17) Prov. X, 7. This verse justifies the execration of Nebuchadnezzar and (in Rule 6) of Haman.
(18) This is explained below. The recitation of the Shema‘ is deemed to be a great honour which compensates for the lesser dignity conferred by the reading of the hafṭarah.
(19) The Shema‘ is recited several times during the service.
(20) Cf. the next Rule.
(21) The collection of Biblical verses recited when the Torah scroll is taken from the ark.
(22) Ps. LXXXIV, 5.

(25) Ps. CXLV, 13.

chapter.title: CHAPTER XV
chapter.p: RULE 1. There is no difference between scrolls [of Scripture] and tefillin and mezuzoth save that the scrolls may be written in any language,1 whereas tefillin and mezuzoth may only be written in the Assyrian script.2 Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: Even scrolls [of Scripture] were permitted by the Rabbis to be written only in Greek.3

RULE 2. Although Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel4 said, ‘Even scrolls [of Scripture] were permitted by the Rabbis to be written only in Greek’, the Sages did not agree with him. For Rabbi related:5 It once happened that Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel was standing at the side of a building [in course of construction] on the Temple Mount, when a Targum of the book of Job was brought before him. He ordered the builder, ‘Bury it under the course of stones’. But the Sages also maintained their ruling, because we have learned in the Mishnah:6 All holy writings7 may be saved from a fire8 irrespective of whether they are used in public reading9 or not;10 and although they are written in any language, they must be stored away.11 And why do we not read [some of these scrolls]? On account of [possible] neglect of the House of Study.12

The sheath of a scroll may be saved13 together with the scroll, and the tefillin bag together with the tefillin, although they contain money.14 To what place may one rescue them? To a closed alley.15 Ben Bathyra said: Even into an open alley.

RULE 3. Although the Sages have said that [some of] the Holy Writings may only be read from [the Sabbath] afternoon service onwards,16 yet they may be studied and expounded. If it is necesssary [to refer to] a word,17 one may take a scroll and examine it. As regards secular documents, however, although they have ruled lines,18 it is forbidden to read them [on the Sabbath].

RULE 4. Benedictions,19 in which many passages of the Torah were quoted,20 must not be saved from a fire [on the Sabbath].21 Hence it was declared: They who write down benedictions are like those who burn the Torah.22

It was related of a man who wrote benedictions that R. Ishmael went to examine him. As soon as he heard the sound of R. Ishmael’s steps, he seized a bundle of written sheets23 and threw it into a bowl of water. In the following words [did R. Ishmael] address him, ‘The punishment for the latter act24 is greater than for the former’.25
RULE 5. Why did he26 so address him? On account of the passages from the Torah which were quoted in them.27

For28 R. Simeon b. Yoḥai taught: He who occupies himself with [only the study of] Scripture indulges in an indifferent practice;29 with Mishnah it is a practice for which a reward is conferred; as for one who occupies himself with Shas,30 there is no worthier practice, provided he had first studied Scripture and Mishnah.31

RULE 6. Always run to the Mishnah more than to the Shas. R. Jose b. Abin said: [The preceding Rule only applies to the time] before Rabbi had edited32 the Mishnayoth, but now that Rabbi has edited the Mishnayoth run to the Mishnah more than to the Shas.33

RULE 7. [The Sages], however, said: Scripture has been compared to water, the Mishnah to wine, and the Shas to spiced-wine. The world cannot exist without water, it cannot exist without wine, and it cannot exist without spiced-wine; but a rich man enjoys all three of them. So, too, it is impossible for the world to exist without Scripture and without Mishnah, but it can never exist without the Shas.34

RULE 8. The Torah35 has also been compared to salt, the Mishnah to pepper, and the Shas to spices. The world cannot exist without salt, without pepper and without spices; but the rich man enjoys all three. So, too, it is impossible for the world to exist without Scripture, without Mishnah and without the Shas.

RULE 9. Happy is the man whose labour is in [the study of] the Shas. Not that he should skip Scripture and the Mishnah and come [direct] to the Shas; but he should learn Scripture and Mishnah with the object of coming to the Shas. Of such a person it is stated, The rich man’s wealth is his strong city, and as a high wall in his own conceit.36

RULE 10. Abba Gurion of Ẓadian37 said in the name of Abba Guria:38 A man should not teach his son to be an ass-driver,39 sailor, waggoner, shepherd40 or shopkeeper,41 because their occupations are robbery.42 R. Judah,43 however, quoting him,44 said: Ass-drivers are mostly wicked, but sailors are mostly pious.45 The best of physicians are [destined] for Gehinnom46 and the most worthy of butchers is Amalek’s partner.47 Bastards are mostly keen-witted,48 slaves are mostly arrogant,49 the children of reputed parents are mostly bashful, and children usually resemble the mother’s brother.

R. Simeon b. Yoḥai taught: Kill the best of the heathens in time of war;50 crush the brain of the best of serpents. The most worthy of women indulges in witchcraft. Happy is he who does the will of the Omnipresent.51 [41b]
chapter.ftnote: (1) For use in the Synagogue. Two such official translations are known: one in Aramaic, the Targum Onḳelos, and another in Greek made by Aquila under Rabbinic supervision.

(2) The Hebrew square characters are described as ‘Assyrian’ because they came into common use for religious writings after the return from the Babylonian exile (cf. Sanh. 21b, 22a, Sonc. ed., pp. 119ff and notes).
(3) [For the reason, cf. Meg. 9b (Sonc. ed., p. 50).]
(4) An eminent authority.
(5) Quoted in V, 15 (p. 236). The following statements in the name of Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel and the Sages respectively prove that both maintained their views.
(6) Shab. XVI, 1 (Sonc. ed., p. 563).
(7) The Pentateuch, Prophets and Hagiographa.
(8) On the Sabbath by being removed from one domain to another, although this is not permitted with ordinary objects.
(9) Such as the Prophets from which the hafṭarah is selected.
(10) viz. the Hagiographa.
(11) When they are worn out and no longer fit for use. Sacred writings must never be destroyed.
(12) On the Sabbath when lectures are delivered in the Houses of Study. By engaging in the reading of the books mentioned the public would neglect the lectures.
(13) From a fire on the Sabbath.
(14) Which otherwise would not be permitted to be moved.
(15) Where movement on the Sabbath is less restricted than in the public domain.
(16) When there are no public lectures in the Houses of Study (cf. Shab. 116b, Sonc. ed., p. 572).
(17) In Shab. loc. cit. the reading is ‘a verse’.
(18) Like sacred scrolls, and one is less likely to forget the Sabbath and insert notes or corrections.
(19) Such as those of the ‘Amidah (P.B., pp. 44-53) and the like.
(20) lit. ‘written’.
(21) They do not possess the same degree of sanctity as the scrolls of Scripture.
(22) Since these could not be saved if a fire broke out on the Sabbath.
(23) Containing benedictions and selections from the Torah.
(24) Destruction of the sheets containing sacred texts by water.
(25) Writing benedictions which included passages from Scripture.
(26) viz. R. Ishmael. So N.Y.; V reads ‘they’.
(27) i.e. the benedictions; and could not, therefore, be saved from a fire on the Sabbath.

(28) The following reason has no connection with the beginning of Rule 5. It refers back to Rule 2 above which lays down that one must not read certain books of the Scripture during the hours when lectures are delivered in the Houses of Study (N.Y.).
(29) lit. ‘a measure and no measure’.

(30) The Heb. letters shin samek, pronounced Shas, stand for ששה סדרים ‘the six orders’ of the Mishnah or of the combined Mishnah and Gemara. Here it evidently refers to the Gemara only. The corresponding passage in B.M. 33a (Sonc. ed., p. 206) reads ‘Gemara’. It has been suggested that the proper reading is ‘Talmud’ (cf. B.M. loc. cit., n. 6).
(31) It is accordingly proved that the study of Mishnah and Gemara, which necessarily includes the Scriptures, is of far higher importance than of Scripture only.
(32) lit. ‘sunk’, an unusual verb in such a connection. [Instead of שקע, H mentions a MS. variant קבע (fixed).]
(33) So N.Y. as required by the context. V, M and H read: ‘run to the Shas more than to the Mishnah.’
(34) Which includes all.
(35) The term here embraces the whole of the Scriptures.
(36) Prov. XVIII, 11.
(37) i.e. Bethsaida in Galilee.
(38) So GRA in agreement with Ḳid. 82a (Sonc. ed., p. 423). V reads ‘said’ after the first ‘Gurion’ and a second ‘Gurion’ for ‘Guria’.
(39) These, when sent on a long journey, hire themselves to others and so make a profit by using the time which belongs to the original employer.
(40) He feeds his flock in other persons’ fields.
(41) He gives false measure or sells adulterated goods.
(42) The descriptions are no doubt a reflection of the standards of the time.
(43) Differing from Abba Gurion.
(44) Abba Guria.
(45) The perils of the sea turn their thoughts to God.

(46) Because they may be guilty of causing loss of life through neglect or over-confidence; or, by trusting too much in their own skill, they deny the power of God [with this passage, cf. ARN XXXVI, 5, and notes].
(47) In his desire to avoid financial loss, he sells unwholesome meat and thereby spreads disease. ‘Amalek’ is the type of Israel’s enemies.
(48) They are like their cunning fathers who enticed their mothers.
(49) Reading גאים with GRA. V, M and H have נאים, ‘beautiful’, an improbable reading.

(50) [For the various forms of this saying, cf. Bacher, Ag. d. Tannaiten II, p. 86, n. 3. The qualifying phrase ‘in the time of war’ he regards as a later addition to soften the harshness of the utterance. It was called forth in a time of bitter oppression and is not to be taken as typical of Jewish ethics. On the subject, cf. J. S. Bloch, Israel and the Nations, pp. 204ff.]
(51) Because he is delivered from all worldly temptations.

chapter.title: CHAPTER XVI
chapter.p: RULE 1. R. Nehorai said: I abandon all professions in the world and teach my son only Torah,1 because a man enjoys part of its reward in this world while the principal remains intact for the world to come. The other professions, however, are not so. For should a person come to sickness, old age or suffering and is unable to carry on his work, he would die of starvation; whereas with the Torah it is not so, but it protects him from all evil in his youth and gives him a future and hope in his old age. What does it say in Scripture of his youth? But they that wait for the Lord shall renew their strength.2 And what does it say of his old age? They shall still bring forth fruit in old age.3
RULE 2. R. Joshua b. Levi said: With regard to the ’aggadta,4 he who writes it down has no share in the world to come,5 he who expounds it6 is cursed,7 while he who listens to it receives no reward.

R. Ḥinnena b. Papa taught:8 The Lord spoke with you face to face9—face implies two,10 to face also implies two, thus providing four expressions of ‘face’ [alluding to] Scripture,11 Mishnah, halakoth and ’aggadoth;12 an awestruck face for Scripture, a neutral face for Mishnah, a friendly13 face for Shas14 and a smiling15 face for ’aggadta.

RULE 3. R. Nehemiah, in the name of R. Jacob b. Jannai, remarked on the text, As in water face answereth to face:16 It is customary to have a master who desires to teach and a student who does not want to learn, or a student who desires to learn and a master who does not want to teach him; but in this case17 the Master desires to teach and the student to learn.18

RULE 4. R. Isaac Nappaḥa began his discourse as follows: Stay me with dainties19 refers to the well-founded20 halakoth; refresh me with apples refers to the ’aggadoth21 whose fragrance is pleasant like that of apples. For I am love-sick—R. Isaac said: In the past when money was plentiful22 one longed to hear a word of the halakah,23 but now that money is scarce24 one longs to hear25 a word of ’aggadah.26

RULE 5. R. Tanḥum b. Ḥanilai said: If the Torah had been given as a clear-cut code,27 no judge would have a locus standi28 in laying down a ruling;29 but now a judge has a locus standi,30 for if he declares a thing to be clean there are [authorities] who declare a thing in a similar condition to be unclean, and if he decides that it is unclean there are [authorities] who declare a thing in a similar condition to be clean.31

RULE 6. R. Jannai said: The Torah which the Holy One, blessed be He, gave to Moses was delivered to him in forty-nine aspects of uncleanness and forty-nine aspects of cleanness,32 as it is stated, And his banner33 (wediglo), the numerical value of its letters being forty-nine.

RULE 7. R. Abahu said in the name of R. Joḥanan: R. ‘Aḳiba had a distinguished34 disciple who knew how to interpret the Torah in forty-nine aspects of uncleanness and forty-nine aspects of cleanness, not one reason being the same as another.35 Consequently36 if those who rule a thing to be unclean are in the majority it is unclean, and if those who rule a thing to be clean are in the majority it is clean.37 Whence [did he learn] all these? [From his extensive studies], because he was learned in the Scriptures, expert in the Mishnah, distinguished in Talmud and brilliant38 in ’aggadah.

RULE 8. It was related of R. Joḥanan b. Zakkai that he did not neglect the study of a single passage of the Torah.39 He also studied [all] Scripture,40 Targum, Mishnah, halakoth and ’aggadoth.41 He learned everything. It was also related of him that he declared, ‘If all the heavens were sheets, all the trees quills and all the seas ink, they would not suffice for recording my wisdom which I acquired from my masters; and yet I have gained42 no more of the wisdom of the Sages than a fly [acquires] which dips in the great sea and deprives it of the tiniest drop’.43

RULE 9. From whom did he44 receive the Torah? From Hillel and Shammai. It was said of Hillel that he had not omitted to study any of the words of the Sages, even all languages, even the speech of mountains, hills and valleys, the speech of trees and herbs, the speech of wild beasts and cattle, the speech of demons45 and parables. Why [did he study] all these? Because it is stated, The Lord was pleased, for His righteousness’ sake, to make the teaching great and glorious.46

RULE 10. R. Joshua b. Levi said: I have never looked into a book of ’aggadta except once when I looked and found written therein that the one hundred and seventy-five sections of the Torah,47 in which occurs any expression of speaking, saying or commanding, correspond to the number of years of our father Abraham;48 for it is written, Thou hast ascended on high, Thou hast led captivity captive; Thou hast received gifts49 for the sake of the man,50 and it is also written, The greatest man51 among the Anakim.52 On this account the Rabbis instituted one hundred and seventy-five orders in the Torah [to be read in public worship] every Sabbath53 [as regularly as the] continual burnt-offering.54

RULE 11. The hundred and forty-seven psalms55 included in the Book of Psalms correspond to the number of years of Jacob.56 This is intended to teach you that all the praises which Israel offer to the Holy One, blessed be He, correspond to the number of years of our father Jacob. What is the reason?57 [Scripture states,] Yet Thou art holy, O Thou that art enthroned upon the praises of Israel.58

RULE 12. The hundred and twenty-three times that Israel respond with Halleluyah59 correspond to the number of years of Aaron.60 What is the reason?61 [Scripture states,] Halleluyah, praise God beḳodsho,62 which [is interpreted as] ‘with His holy man’, i.e. Aaron, the holy man of God.
Nevertheless63 I was afraid at night.64

65A minor who is not allowed to read portions of the Shema‘66 must not say ‘Holy’67 in the benediction Yoẓer privately;68 but with a congregation he may respond together with the others. An adult, however, who reads portions of the Shema‘ may say ‘Holy’ because it is in the order [of the Biblical text];69 but as for the ‘Holy’ of the ‘Amidah,70 since he would have to say ‘We will reverence and sanctify Thee’,71 it is not proper for him to say it if less than ten adults are present. A minor, furthermore, may not be counted in the quorum of ten72 for Bareku,73 the reading of the Torah and ḳaddish until he is thirteen years of age; but no examination74 is carried out in such cases.75.

(68) Yoẓer (Who formed) designates the first benediction before the Shema‘, beginning ‘Blessed’ (P.B., p. 37) and ending with ‘Creator of the luminaries’ (p. 39). The first ḳedushshah of the morning service is included in it.

(71) Which is a part of the congregational service (P.B., p. 160). This form, now used in the ḳedushshah for the Sabbath musaf, was used formerly, and in certain congregations to-day, on week-days.

chapter.title: CHAPTER XVII
chapter.p: RULE 1. The words of the wise are as goads … they are given from one shepherd;1 and one Shepherd2 has uttered them. Therefore they must be saved from a fire.3 A book of the ’aggadta, although not allowed to be written, must nevertheless be saved from a fire. What is the reason? It is a time to work for the Lord; they have made void Thy law.4
RULE 2. [The sequence of the Sabbath readings] is interrupted5 for New Moons, Ḥanukkah, Purim, fasts, ma‘amadoth and the Day of Atonement.6

RULE 3. In what manner are the interruptions made if the New Moon or the days of Ḥanukkah fall on a Sabbath? [In the former case] seven persons read the regular Sabbath section while the eighth reads that of the New Moon, viz. the two portions7 And on the sabbath day8 and And in your new moons;9 and if the first day of Ḥanukkah10 falls on a Sabbath, seven read [the section] of the Sabbath while the eighth reads, And it came to pass on the day that Moses had made an end11 up to so he made the candlestick.12

RULE 4. [42a] What13 is the procedure on Purim? If Purim falls on a Sabbath, seven read [the section] of the Sabbath while the eighth reads Then came Amalek.14 The three fast days15 are not observed on consecutive days but are separated [and observed] on Monday, Thursday and Monday. Our Rabbis in the land of Israel had the custom of fasting after Purim16 on account of [the victory over] Nicanor and his associates,17 and also because the commemoration of sad events is postponed rather than antedated.

RULE 5. [What was the procedure in the case of] ma‘amadoth? As it was taught:18 The men of the ma‘amadoth used to fast [as follows]: On every Monday for the sake of those who sail on the sea, as it is written, And God said: Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters;19 on Tuesdays for the sake of wayfarers, as it is written, And God said: Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together;20 on Wednesdays for the sake of children that they should not be attacked by croup, as it is written, And God said: Let there be lights,21 the written form being defective;22 on Thursdays they fasted for the sake of pregnant women and nursing mothers that they should not lose their children, as it is said, And God said: Let the waters swarm with swarms.23 On the Sabbath eve and at the conclusion of the Sabbath24 they did not fast from respect for the Sabbath. Some declare25 that at the twilight of the Sabbath eve an additional soul is given to every Israelite, and after the Sabbath it is taken from him.26 Another reason27 is that Christians28 should not say, ‘Because we rejoice on the Sunday they fast on it’. The Sages, however, said: In the period of the ma‘amadoth they were not concerned with the hatred of the Christians, but the reason is that it is written He ceased from work wayyinnafash,29 [which is homiletically interpreted] wai ‘al nefesh, ‘Woe for [the loss of the additional] soul’.

RULE 6. On Passover we read from the section of the Festivals in Leviticus;30 on Pentecost Seven weeks;31 on New Year In the seventh month on the first day of the month;32 on the Day of Atonement After the death.33 On the first day of Tabernacles we read from the section of the Festivals in Leviticus,34 and on the other days of Tabernacles the section of the offerings of the Festival.35

RULE 7. On Ḥanukkah we read the section of [the dedication of the altar by] the princes;36 on Purim, Then came Amalek;37 on the New Moon, And in your new moons;38 at the ma‘amadoth the account of the creation.39 On the fast days of the Ninth of Ab and the last seven days in connection with droughts,40 we read the section of the blessings and curses;41 but on other fast days And Moses besought,42 and we read as the hafṭarah Seek ye the Lord.43 Some say that no hafṭarah is to be read, but the people have adopted the custom of reading the hafṭarah.44 There must be no break in the section of curses because it is not proper to end with curses and to begin with curses.45

RULE 8. On Mondays and Thursdays and at the Sabbath afternoon service the regular portion of the week is read, and this is not reckoned as a part of the reading [for the succeeding Sabbath].46 [The reason47 is] because it is stated, And Moses declared unto the children of Israel the appointed seasons of the Lord,48 which implies that it is an ordinance that each [appointed section] shall be read in its season. Hence [the Rabbis] said: [The sequence of the readings] is interrupted for them all—for New Moons, Ḥanukkah, Purim, fasts, ma‘amadoth and the Day of Atonement,49 irrespective of whether these occur on a Sabbath, a Monday or Thursday, on which days there exists a regular sequence of readings.50 This sequence is interrupted51 and the [special sections] are read. You cannot, however, say of fasts or ma‘amadoth52 that they would fall on a Sabbath in order [to lay down the rule that] the normal sequence of the Sabbath [readings] is interrupted on their account. [For these can interrupt the sequence] of a Monday or Thursday only.

RULE 9. When a New Moon falls on the Sabbath, the eighth person who has to read And on the sabbath day and And in the beginnings of your months53 also reads, as the hafṭarah, Thus said the Lord God: The gate of the inner court that looketh toward the east.54 If [the New Moon] falls on a Sunday, he55 reads on the Sabbath preceding the New Moon And Jonathan said unto him: To-morrow is the new moon.56 On the New Moon itself, three persons read the section of the continual offering. The first person reads, And … spoke,57 Command,58 And thou shalt say.59 The second person reads, The one lamb,60 And the tenth part,61 It is a continual burnt-offering,62 And the drink-offering thereof,63 And the other lamb.64 The third person repeats and reads, It is a continual burnt-offering, And the drink-offering, And the other lamb, And on the sabbath day,65 This is the burnt-offering of every sabbath.66 [The reason for this arrangement is] because [the Rabbis] ruled that it is not permitted to read less than three verses in a section nor67 is it permissible to leave unfinished less than three verses at the end of a section.68

RULE 10.69 If two verses were read,70 and another section was begun,71 there must be no stop before three verses of the latter were read. And since [the third person] reads, … burnt-offering, And the drink-offering thereof, And the other lamb, And on the sabbath day, This is the burnt-offering of … sabbath,72 it follows that the third person reads five verses,73 while [the next] one reads the whole section of the New Moon, And in the beginnings of your months.74

RULE 11. On the New Moon it is necessary to say after May the glory75 the following: The Lord reigneth,76 O sing unto the Lord a new song;77 and after that, O give thanks unto the Lord, call upon His name78 and the six daily psalms;79 for80 R. Jose said, ‘May my lot be among those who include in their daily prayers81 those six psalms’. It has also been stated: Why did David mention Abraham, Isaac and Jacob82 in the psalm beginning, O give thanks unto the Lord, call upon His name? Because it has to be said daily.
