chapter.title: CHAPTER XVIII
chapter.p: RULE 1. Why has it been ordained that the psalms1 [prescribed for the Temple service] are to be said2 on every New Moon?3 [This is done in accordance with the view of] R. Simeon b. Laḳish. He enquired of R. Joḥanan whether it was permissible to recite the psalms4 in the absence of libations, and he replied, ‘We may deduce the answer from the following statement: On this and that [occasion]5 the Levites stood on the platform6 and recited, And He hath brought upon them their own iniquity’.7 R. Simeon b. Laḳish asked him, ‘Which is first, the psalm8 or the additional sacrifice?’9 He replied,10 ‘It is obvious that the psalm is read first’.11 For this reason12 the people have adopted the custom of saying psalms13 at their proper times;14 as we have learned in the Mishnah:15 ‘These were the psalms which the Levites used to recite in the Temple: On Sunday16 they used to recite, The earth is the Lord’s, and the fulness thereof; the world, and they that dwell therein.17 On Monday, Great is the Lord, and exceedingly to be praised,18 etc. On Tuesday, God standeth in the congregation of God,19 etc. On Wednesday, O Lord, Thou God to whom vengeance belongeth,20 etc. On Thursday, Sing aloud unto God our strength,21 etc. On Friday, The Lord reigneth; He is clothed in majesty.22 On the Sabbath, A psalm, a Song. For the sabbath day,23 [which is the psalm and song also]24 for the hereafter, for the day which will be wholly a Sabbath and [will bring] rest in life everlasting’. For whoever makes mention of a Biblical verse at its proper time is regarded [by God] as though he had built a new altar and offered a sacrifice upon it.

RULE 2. On Ḥanukkah [the psalm is] I will extol Thee, O Lord.25 On Purim it is Shiggaion of David,26 but others say it is O God, keep not Thou silence.27 On the first day of Passover it is, Praise ye the name of the Lord,28 and the same [is said during] the intermediate days of the Festival; but on the first [two] days of Passover one must [also] say May the glory of the Lord,29 while all the people stand. Then30 they sit and say all the prescribed psalms31 up to And blessed be His glorious name for ever;32 but on the last day of Passover the Great Hallel is said. And what is the Great Hallel? [42b] O give thanks unto the Lord, for He is good … O give thanks unto the God of gods.33 The people have adopted the custom of saying the Great Hallel, although this is not the proper thing to do.34

RULE 3. On the Feast of Weeks35 [the psalm is] Ascribe unto the Lord, O ye sons of might.36 On the ninth day of Ab [the reading consists] of four verses of Jeremiah, Hast Thou utterly rejected Judah? to For Thou hast made all these things,37 and the following two psalms, O God, the heathen are come into Thine inheritance38 and By the rivers of Babylon.39 Although it is usual40 to give precedence to the Holy Words41 over the words of [prophetical] traditions,42 in this case the latter43 takes precedence over the former.44

RULE 4. Some [congregations] read the Book of Lamentations in the evening45 while others postpone it to the [following] morning after the reading of the Torah, when the reader46 stands up, his head covered with ashes, his clothes torn,47 and reads it with weeping and lamentation. If he is able to translate it, well and good; but if he is unable he entrusts it to one who knows how to translate properly and [that person] does the translation, so that the rest of the people, the women and children may understand it; in that women are obliged to listen to the reading of the Book, how much more so does it apply to men.

Women have similarly the duty to read the Shema‘, the [‘Amidah] prayer and the Grace after meals, and to have a mezuzah [on their doors]. But if they are not acquainted with the holy tongue they are to be taught [to say them] in any language which they can understand and master. From this it was deduced that the man who recites the benedictions48 must raise his voice for the benefit of his young sons, his wife and daughters. It is, therefore, a logical deduction that every section of the Torah and the Prophet [prescribed for the readings] of the Sabbath should be translated for the people, the women and the children after the reading of the Torah. This is why it was ruled: On the Sabbath the people come [to the Synagogue] early and depart late. They come early to read the Shema‘, like the pious men of old, with the first glimpse of the sun; and they depart late to listen to the interpretation of the weekly section. On a Festival, however, they come late, because they have to prepare the food for the day;49 and they hasten to depart because it is unreasonable to interpret [the Torah or the Prophet] for them, it having been stated: Rab did not appoint an interpreter from [the beginning of the first day of] the Festival to the conclusion of the second day.50

RULE 5. There was likewise a beautiful custom in Jerusalem to train51 their young sons and daughters to afflict themselves on a fast day:52 at the age of eleven to the middle of the day, at the age of twelve the full day, and at the age of thirteen [the boy] was taken round53 and presented to every elder to bless him and pray for him that he may be worthy to study the Torah and engage in good deeds. In like manner,54 everyone who had a man superior to him in the town would rise from his place and go and bow down to him [requesting] that he pray on his behalf. This is meant to teach us that they55 were splendid men and their deeds were splendid, and that their hearts [were directed] towards Heaven. Furthermore, they did not leave their young children behind but took them to the Synagogue to encourage them in the performance of the precepts.

RULE 6. On the day when R. Eleazar b. ‘Azariah was appointed head of the academy, he began his discourse by saying: Ye are standing this day all of you … your little ones, your wives,56 the men came to listen, the women came to receive a reward for their journey,57 but why did the little ones come? That a reward may be given to those who bring them. From this the young daughters of Israel learnt the practice of coming to the Synagogue so that a reward may be granted to those who bring them while they would [in due course]58 also receive their reward.59

RULE 7.60 The reader on the Ninth of Ab61 says,62 ‘Blessed … the true Judge’.63 Some place the Torah scroll64 on the ground in a black wrapping and say, The crown is fallen from our head.65 The reading and the lamentations are carried out as with a man whose dead lies before him. Some change their [customary] places [in the Synagogue]; others descend from their benches, and all of them roll in ashes and do not greet one another throughout the night and also throughout the day until the people have finished their lamentations. During the recital of the lamentations it is forbidden to speak [any irrelevant] word, or to go outside [the Synagogue], lest one’s mind be diverted from the mourning; and it is obvious that no conversation with a Gentile is permitted.66
RULE 8. In the evening service67 no one can hear the other, because all pray in a whisper;68 therefore we say neither ‘Bless ye’69 nor ‘[Blessed] be the name’.70

chapter.title: CHAPTER XIX
chapter.p: RULE 1. In the morning service,1 however,2 after the psalms and the Scriptural verses, [the reader] in the Yoẓer benediction3 says ‘Bless ye’ in a low voice; but neither ‘Holy’4 nor ḳaddish is to be recited. In the afternoon prayer, however, both ‘Holy’5 and ḳaddish are said.

RULE 2.6 And on the New Year we say, O clap your hands, all ye peoples;7 on the Day of Atonement Bless the Lord, O my soul8 and Out of the depths have I called Thee, O Lord;9 on the Festival of Tabernacles In Judah is God known;10 on the Eighth Day [of Solemn Assembly] For the Leader … on the Sheminith.11 If one is not conversant with these psalms, he says I will give thanks unto the Lord with my whole heart,12 and that suffices.

RULE 3. On Passover, both in the [‘Amidah] prayer13 and over the cup of wine14 one must mention ‘On this Festival of holy convocation, this day of the Festival of Unleavened Bread’; and during the intermediate days of the Festival ‘This Festival of Unleavened Bread’.15 On the seventh day one says16 ‘On the Seventh Day of Solemn Assembly’, but no mention is made of ‘Festival’ since it is not an independent Festival.17
RULE 4. On the Feast of Weeks18 one says ‘On this Festival of holy convocation and this day of the Feast of Weeks’. The evening, morning and afternoon services consist of the same prayers.19

RULE 5. On the New Moon of Nisan20 one must mention21 ‘On this day of the New Moon’; and on the New Year ‘On this Festival of holy convocation,22 this day of the New Year, this Day of Memorial, a day of blowing the Shofar’, concluding with23 ‘King over all the earth, Who sanctifiest Israel and the Day of Memorial and the Seasons’.24

RULE 6. On the Day of Atonement no mention is made25 of ‘on the Festival Day’, because there is no Festival on a fast day; but one says, ‘On this day of holy convocation, on this day of the Fast of the Tenth,26 on this day of pardoning of iniquity’, concluding with27 ‘pardonest and forgivest our iniquities and the iniquities of Thy people Israel in mercy, and grantest remission for their transgressions, King over all the earth, Who sanctifiest Israel and the day of the Fast of Atonement, and the Seasons and the holy convocation’; but no mention is made of Festival and joy since there is no joy without par-taking of food.

RULE 7. As we laud [God] on the first day, the intermediate days and the last day28 of the Festival, so we laud Him [on the other] Festivals in the morning,29 afternoon and evening prayers.30 And how is He lauded! ‘Our God and the God of our fathers, do Thou make the glory of Thy kingdom manifest upon us’.31 This is followed by, ‘We pray Thee, O Lord our God,32 may … rise and come,33 etc. Bestow upon us’;34 and the conclusion of the prayer is, ‘Blessed art Thou Who sanctifiest Thy people Israel, the Festival of joy, the Seasons and the holy convocation’.

RULE 8. As the concluding words [of the benedictions] of the New Year and the Day of Atonement are different from those of other Festivals, so are the prayers of these days; and we do not include ‘remembrance’35 either in the first three36 or last three37 [benedictions of the ‘Amidah] except only on the two Festival days of the New Year and Day of Atonement38 and, even with these, permission was given with difficulty.39 If the New Year falls on a Sabbath, one does not say ‘A day of blowing the Shofar’ but ‘a day of remembrance of blowing the Shofar’, because the blowing of the Shofar does not take precedence of the Sabbath in country towns,40 this being a preventive measure.41

RULE 9. On the New Moon,42 the associations of elders, leaders and students were assembled in session43 from the time of the afternoon service onwards until the sun had set and the moon appeared in the night [sky].44 It is necessary to say [after the ceremonial meal] in the benediction over the wine,45 ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, Who createst the fruit of the vine. Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe, Who hast revealed the secret of the renewal of the moon, Who didst instruct and teach us46 the [courses of] the seasons, New Moons and Festivals47 and Who didst appoint men of understanding who determine the times [of the New Moons and Festivals]. Thou, our Rock, hast weighed and calculated the minutest divisions of time whereby those New Moons and Festivals are determined, as it is written, Who appointedst the moon for seasons; the sun knoweth his going down,48 and it also states, For as the new heavens and the new earth, which I will make’;49 and one concludes with ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who sanctifiest Israel and the New Moons’. [Then one says,] ‘O give thanks unto the Lord for He is good; on this day we all in Jerusalem rejoice and are happy in the All-present. May Elijah the prophet soon come to us; may the king Messiah cause to spring forth in our days the [happy] time like the years50 when the Temple will be rebuilt, and may joyous occasions multiply in Israel’; and the people answer and say ‘Amen’. [The prayer is then continued,] ‘May good tidings multiply in Israel, may happy days multiply in Israel, may disciples of the Torah multiply in Israel. Consecrated is the New Moon, consecrated at the beginning of the month, consecrated in its proper time, consecrated in its intercalation,51 consecrated according to52 the Torah, consecrated according to the halakah, consecrated in the celestial regions, consecrated in the terrestrial regions, consecrated in the land of Israel, consecrated in Zion, consecrated in Jerusalem, consecrated in all the habitations of Israel, consecrated by the order of our Rabbis, consecrated in the House of Assembly. O give thanks unto the Lord for He is good’. Then [the reader] says, ‘You are all blessed’. After every benediction, moreover, [the reader] says, ‘O give thanks unto the Lord for He is good’, except after the benedictions of the Levites.53

RULE 10. When he54 sings the praises of God he does so in the presence of the twelve notable men55 of the town and twelve ḥaberim56 corresponding to the twelve tribes, the twelve months and the twelve constellations.

RULE 11. Although [in the Grace after meals the prayer] ‘May … rise and come’57 has been said in [the benediction concluding with] ‘rebuildest Jerusalem’ and all58 the benediction of zimmun has been said over the cup59 [of wine], that cup being passed on to one’s wife60 to fulfil that which is stated, To cause a blessing to rest on thy house,61 nevertheless another cup of wine is brought over which is said the benediction ‘Who createst the fruit of the vine’ and afterwards ‘Who didst reveal’, etc.62 The same rule also applies63 to the benediction of bridegrooms and the benediction of mourners,64 because two sanctifications65 must not be pronounced over the same cup. Our Masters have adopted the practice of saying the benediction of bridegrooms66 in the morning over a cup of wine in the presence of ten men; and [in the presence of] new guests all the seven days;67 and similarly in the evening after68 the meal.

RULE 12. With regard to the benediction of mourners on the Sabbath, when mourning is suspended, it is said after the statutory service in the presence of the worshippers over a cup of wine; for R. Eliezer b. Hyrḳanos said:69 Solomon saw the greatness70 of those who bestow lovingkindness, and built two gates for Israel, one for bridegrooms and the other for mourners and excommunicated persons. On the Sabbath the inhabitants of Jerusalem used to congregate, ascend the Temple Mount and take their seats between these two gates to show kindness to these persons. Since the Temple was destroyed it was enacted that bridegrooms and mourners should go to the Synagogue so that kindness could be shown to them: to bridegrooms by recounting their praises and escorting them to their homes. To mourners [by comforting them as follows:] After the reader finishes the musaf, everyone goes behind the doors of the Synagogue, which are in front of71 the Synagogue, and there meets the mourners and all their relatives. The benediction72 is said followed by ḳaddish. The version ‘In the world that will be renewed in the time to come’73 is only said after the study of74 the Talmud and a Rabbinic discourse.75

chapter.title: CHAPTER XX
chapter.p: RULE 1. The benediction over the moon must not be said except at the conclusion of the Sabbath when one is in an exhilarated mood1 and well dressed. [43a] He directs his eyes towards the moon, places his feet together and pronounces the benediction ‘Who2 didst create the heavens by Thy word and all their hosts by the breath of Thy mouth. Thou didst set for them a fixed law and time that they should not change their ordained task. They are glad and rejoice to perform the will of their Possessor.3 They act loyally, for their4 action is truth. To the moon Thou didst say that it should renew itself with a precious light and a diadem of beauty for those who have been sustained from the womb5 who, like it, will be renewed in the future and glorify their Creator for the majesty of His kingdom. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who hallowest the New Moons’.6

RULE 2. Then one says three times, ‘An auspicious omen, an auspicious omen, shall it be for all Israel. Blessed be He Who formed thee, blessed be Thy Maker, blessed be thy Possessor, blessed be thy Creator’. Turning in the direction of the moon,7 he jumps three times and exclaims three times, ‘As I jump towards thee but do not8 touch thee, so if others should jump against me to hurt me may they not touch me. Let terror and dread fall upon them and may this be retrospective, Amen, Amen, Selah. Praise ye the Lord’. He then says ‘Peace’ three times to his fellow and goes home with a cheerful heart. That is [the conclusion of the regulations] concerning the interruptions for New Moons.9

RULE 3. What are the regulations respecting Ḥanukkah?10 The Rabbis said: On the twenty-fifth day of Kislew11 the Ḥanukkah lamp is kindled,12 and it is forbidden to use an old lamp;13 but if a person has only an old lamp, he must thoroughly heat it in fire;14 nor may [the Ḥanukkah lamp] be moved15 from its place before it is extinguished.16

RULE 4. The commandment to kindle it extends from sunset until the last person has left17 the street.18 And, although there is no actual proof,19 there is an allusion to it: The pillar of cloud by day [and the pillar of fire by night,] departed not.20 If it was lit in daytime, one must derive no benefit from it, nor may the benediction be said over it; for so [the Rabbis] said: No benediction is to be pronounced over the lamp before one enjoys its light. There is no need, however, to be concerned about changing the wick before it has been used up.

RULE 5. It is a religious precept to place the Ḥanukkah lamp by the door which is near to the public domain,21 in such a manner that the mezuzah should be on the right hand and the Ḥanukkah lamp on the left, to fulfil what is stated, How fair and how pleasant art thou22—how fair with the mezuzah and how pleasant with the Ḥanukkah lamp. The number23 of lights [for each night] is in accordance with the ruling of the School of Hillel,24 because in sacred matters one should proceed to a higher grade25 but not descend to a lower one,26 [and also because the number of lights should] correspond to the days [of the Festival] as they pass.

RULE 6. In what manner are the benedictions27 said? On the first day, the person who kindles [the lamp] says three benedictions while the onlooker says two. The person who kindles says, ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord,28 Who hast sanctified us by Thy commandments and hast given us command to kindle the light of Ḥanukkah’. Then29 he says, ‘We kindle these lights on account of the deliverances and the miracles and the wonders which Thou didst work for our fathers, by means of Thy holy priests.30 During all the eight days of Ḥanukkah these lights are sacred, and it is not permitted to make any profane use of them but we are only to look at them, in order that we may give thanks unto Thy name for thy wonders, Thy miracles and Thy deliverances’. [The third benediction is] ‘Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who hast kept us in life’.31 [Before this] he says, ‘Who wroughtest miracles for our fathers’.32 These benedictions are for the person who kindles the lights, but the onlooker says on the first day only two benedictions: ‘Who hast kept us in life’ and ‘Who wroughtest miracles’. From that day onwards the person who kindles the lights says, ‘To kindle’ and ‘Who wroughtest’, while the onlooker only says ‘Who wroughtest miracles’.

RULE 7. The precentor must say, ‘Thou art holy’33 on the eight days34 of Ḥanukkah, and similarly on New Moons and on the intermediate days of a Festival,35 because beside36 the continual burnt-offering37 is written in connection with them. And R. Hiyya learnt: On any day on which there is a musaf ḳedushshah is said except on Ḥanukkah on which ḳedushshah is said although there is no musaf on it, because Hallel is included [in the service]. Some maintain [that it is said] on Purim also, because the scroll of Esther is read on it.

RULE 8. In the benediction for Thanksgiving38 we include [on Ḥanukkah] ‘and thanks for the wonders and salvation of Thy priests which Thou hast wrought in the days of Mattathias, son of Joḥanan, High Priest, and the Hasmoneans his sons. So also, O Lord our God and God of our fathers, perform for us miracles and wonders, and we will give thanks unto Thy name for ever. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who art all-good’.39 The miracles [of the days] of Mordecai and Esther are also mentioned [on Purim] in the benediction for Thanksgiving. Both40 are likewise mentioned in the Grace after meals.41

RULE 9. The whole Hallel42 is recited during all the eight days of Ḥanukkah. During [the recital of] the first two43 chapters one may not return greetings, and there is no need to say that one must not give greetings. During [the recital of] the last two chapters one may give greetings out of fear;44 during the two middle chapters45 [greetings may be given] for the sake of peace or out of respect. The following are the first two chapters: Praise, O ye servants of the Lord46 and When Israel went forth.47 The two middle ones are: Not unto us48 and I love.49 The last two are: O praise the Lord50 and O give thanks unto the Lord.51 It is also necessary to say a benediction52 before them and read them melodiously. For R. Simeon b. Jehoẓadaḳ said:53 On eighteen days and one night the individual reads the whole Hallel and they are: the eight days of Ḥanukkah, the eight days of Tabernacles,54 the Festival of Solemn Assembly, the first Festival day of Passover and the night preceding it.55 In the Diaspora56 [the whole Hallel is read on] twenty-one days and two nights. The most proper way of performing the commandment is to read the Hallel psalms on the two nights [of Passover] in the Diaspora in the Synagogue,57 to say the benediction over them, and to recite them melodiously to fulfil what is stated, And let us exalt His name together.58 When, however, one reads [the Hallel] at home,59 there is no need to say the benediction because it has already been said in the congregational service.60

RULE 10. A scroll61 is then taken out62 and we read in the section of the princes,63 And he that presented his offering the first day was;64 and likewise for each day [the corresponding section of the offering] of that day,65 until the eighth day. On the Sabbath [during Ḥanukkah] one reads, And it came to pass on the day that Moses made an end66 up to so he made the candlestick.67 On the eighth day he reads from On the eighth day68 through all the sections69 until so he made the candlestick. On the Sabbath70 one also reads as the hafṭarah, Thus all the work … was finished.71

RULE 11. During the eight days of Ḥanukkah we read the following one day earlier:72 On the second day,73 On the third day,74 On the fourth day,75 On the fifth day,76 On the sixth day,77 On the seventh day,78 On the eighth day,79 so as to complete ten verses.80

RULE 12. When the New Moon of Ṭebeth81 falls on a Sunday, three persons read on the first day82 in the passage of the New Moon first, while the fourth reads the passage of Ḥanukkah, because that which is more frequent takes precedence,83 and so [the reading for the New Moon] precedes the other. On the second day, however, the order is not the same, but three persons read the passage of Ḥanukkah while the fourth reads that of the New Moon, because on the previous day the section of the New Moon had been read first.84 [This is the procedure] because R. Isaac Seḥorah asked R. Isaac Nappaḥa, ‘Which do we read [first]85 when the New Moon of Ṭebeth falls on a Sabbath?’ [He replied,] ‘In the section of kalloth Mosheh,86 while the mafṭir reads87 the passages relating to the Sabbath and the New Moon.88 If it falls on a week-day, on the first day [of the New Moon] three persons read [the passage] for the New Moon, the fourth reading that of Ḥanukkah; because that which is more frequent takes precedence. As, however, the section of the New Moon was read first,89 three persons are to be called up on the second day for the reading of the Ḥanukkah section,90 while the fourth reads91 the section of the New Moon, viz. And in your new moons to the end of the section.92 Why is this so?93 Because it is only on account of the musaf of New Moon94 that a fourth person is added.95 Behold [we have concluded the regulations respecting] the interruption which is made for the sake of Ḥanukkah.96

Rule 7 extends this practice to some of the less important days as specified below. It has also been suggested to read, instead of ’attah ḳadosh (‘Thou art holy’) ’eth haḳḳedushshah (‘the ḳedushshah’).

chapter.title: CHAPTER XXI
chapter.p: RULE 1. [Reverting to the sequence of the readings which] is interrupted for Purim.1 It is2 the custom of our Rabbis in the West to afflict themselves by fasting the three days of the fast of Mordecai and Esther3 intermittently, viz. after Purim on the Monday, Thursday and Monday.

RULE 2. And why do we not fast in the month of Nisan? Because on the first of Nisan the Tabernacle was erected4 and twelve princes offered their sacrifices during [the first] twelve days, a day for each tribe,5 and everyone held a festival on his day.6 Furthermore, in the time to come the Sanctuary will be rebuilt in Nisan, to confirm what is stated, There is nothing new under the sun.7

RULE 3. For this reason8 no supplications9 are offered on any of the days of Nisan and there is no fasting until Nisan has passed. The only exception is [the fast of] the firstborn who fast on the eve of Passover.10 The very pious also fast on that day on account of the unleavened bread, in order that they shall begin to eat it11 with relish.12 Scholars fast on Mondays and Thursdays [throughout the year] on account of the desecration of the name of God13 and for the honour of the Temple which was burnt.
RULE 4. To what does the foregoing apply? To fasting in private, but it is forbidden to proclaim a public fast until Nisan has passed.

On the first day of Adar a public proclamation is made regarding the shekels.14 Why on the first of Adar? Because it was foreseen, revealed and known before Him Who spoke and the world came into being that Haman would in time to come weigh [shekels] against Israel.15 He, therefore, forestalled him and instructed Moses that the shekels of Israel should precede Haman’s. It is required that Israel shall give their shekels before [43b] the Sabbath of Remember;16 and it is forbidden to say of them17 that they are ‘for a ransom’ [but must be given] for a freewill-offering. From the proceeds water and food should be supplied for their poor brethren on account of a sacrifice18 and gifts to the poor.19 Some supply bread and wine, others supply bread and fish; in any event not less than two gifts20 should be given, although they consist only of wheat and beans.
RULE 5.21 In villages and towns [the Megillah] is read on the fourteenth [of Adar], and in walled cities22 on the fifteenth of the month.

RULE 6. We read23 from Then came Amalek;24 and although it consists of only nine verses,25 we do not begin26 Now Jethro … heard,27 but the first [to be called up] reads three verses, viz. Then came Amalek … And Moses said … So Joshua did;28 the second reads And it came to pass, when Moses held up his hand … But Moses’ hands … And Joshua discomfited;29 the third reads And the Lord said … And Moses built … And he said: The hand upon the throne of the Lord: the Lord will have war.30 The scroll of the Torah is then put back in its place, and Blessed be the name of the Lord from this time forth and for ever31 and ḳaddish are said;32 because neither on New Moons, nor fast days, nor Mondays and Thursdays, nor on the intermediate days of a Festival, nor the eight days of Ḥanukkah, nor Purim is ḳaddish said until after the Torah scroll had been restored to its place, while the people stand and respond ‘Amen, let His great name’, etc.,33 with devotion and [still] standing. Furthermore, you have no reading that requires a ḳaddish before [the scroll] is put back except that of Sabbath and Festivals alone, [when it is said] before the hafṭarah is read in the Prophet.

RULE 7. R. Huna said: For three readings in the Torah34 not less than ten verses must be allotted.35 Hezekiah36 explained [the reason:37 The number] corresponds to the Ten Commandments. But have we not learned in a Mishnah:38 ‘On Sunday [the men of the ma‘amad read] In the beginning39 and Let there be a firmament’40 although they contain not more than eight verses?41 R. Iddi said: Kahana and Ashë differ [on the method of procedure],42 one holding that [the reader] goes back, and the other maintaining that he cuts.43 According to him who holds that ‘[the reader] goes back’, he repeats two verses;44 and according to him who maintains that ‘he cuts’, And there was evening and there was morning45 is a verse on its own.46 But have we not learned in [the same] Mishnah: ‘On Monday [the reading of the ma‘amad was] Let there be a firmament47 and Let the waters … be gathered together’?48 Now, according to him who holds that ‘[the reader] goes back’, he goes back over two verses, but according to him who maintains that ‘he cuts’, even if he does so, there are not ten49 verses!50 R. Polippa b. R. Pariṭ raised an objection before R. Jonah,51 ‘Behold the section of Amalek!’52 ‘This is different’, he replied, ‘since53 it is the prescribed portion for the day’.54 R. Eliezer b. R. Maḳom raised an objection:55 [It has been taught,] ‘He who reads the hafṭarah from the Prophet shall read not less than twenty-one verses’,56 but [if R. Huna’s ruling] is valid, twenty-three verses should be required, ten for the first three,57 ten for the second three, and three for the last one!58

RULE 8. Where the custom is to read the Megillah on two days59 it should be so read, [and where it is customary to read it] in the night and in the day, it should be so read; all depends on the practice of the country. Furthermore, all Israel must read it in the holy tongue.60

RULE 9.61 The greatest man among the Anakim62—among the Anakim refers to our father Abraham whose height was equal to that of seventy-four men; his eating and drinking were of a similar proportion, equal to those of seventy-four men; so too his strength. What did he do?63 He removed the sixteen64 sons of Keturah, built for them a walled city of iron and settled them in it. The sun never penetrated into it because it was exceedingly high, so Abraham handed to them disks of precious stones and pearls of which use will be made65 in the hereafter when the Holy One, blessed be He, will cause the sun and moon to be confounded, as it is written, When the moon shall be confounded, and the sun ashamed,66 because use will be made of these [disks as luminaries].

Og67 is identical with Eliezer,68 and [he was so huge that] he could hide Abraham’s feet in the palm of his hand. Once he was rebuked [by Abraham] and from fright his tooth fell out. Abraham picked it up and made ivory beds of it in which he slept. Others say that he made of it a chair which he used69 all his life. Who gave him to Abraham? Nimrod.70 Og went and built sixty cities, the smallest of which was sixty miles high, as it is stated, Threescore cities, all the region of Argob.71 And what did he eat? A thousand oxen and the same [number of] other animals, and his drink consisted of a thousand measures. A72 drop of his semen weighed thirty-six pounds.73

It was taught: What did our father Jacob do when his sons brought him the coat [stained] with blood?74 He did not believe them at all. Whence do we infer this? For it is written, But he refused to be comforted,75 because no consolations are acceptable for a living person. One, however, who is dead passes naturally from the mind,76 as it is stated, I am forgotten as a dead man out of mind.77 What then did he do? He proceeded to make a test with sheaves,78 writing upon them the respective names of the tribes, their constellations and the months, and said to them, ‘I order you to prostrate yourselves before Levi because he wears the Urim and Thummim’,79 but they did not stand up. ‘Before Judah who is king’, but they did not stand up; but when he mentioned Joseph to them, they all stood up and bowed before Joseph. But it was not yet quite clear that he was alive. So Jacob went to the mountains, hewed twelve stones, arranged them in a row, and wrote on each the name of its tribe, the name of its constellation and the name of its month. On one stone he wrote ‘Reuben, lamb, Nisan’80 and similarly on every stone. He began from Simeon and said to them, ‘I order you to stand up for Reuben’, but they did not stand up. ‘For Simeon’, but they did not stand up. ‘For every tribe’, but the stones did not stand up. As soon, however, as he mentioned the name of Joseph to them, they stood up at once and bowed before Joseph’s stone.81 For this reason, all the tribes were written on Joseph’s stone. Similarly, all Israel are called by Joseph’s name, as it is stated, Thou that leadest Joseph like a flock.82 So also all the heads of the families of the priests and Levites, [e.g.] Eliashib,83 because of the phrase lahashibo ’el ’abiw;84 Elḳanah,85 because Potiphar had bought him [as it is stated,] And Joseph ms brought down to Egypt, and Potiphar … bought him.86

When Rebekah left her father’s house87 she was three years old,88 because it is customary among kings, when a daughter is born to them, to hear of it after three days;89 but as her father did not hear [of her birth] he did not defile her up to that time; and now a miracle happened to her in that her father died so that he should not defile her, as it is written, Neither had any man known her,90 and by man only her father could be meant,91 for such was the practice of the Arameans to lie with their virgin daughters after they were three years of age,92 and then to give them away in marriage.93

Dinah was six years old when she bore Asenath from [her association with] Shechem,94 corresponding to95 the six years which Jacob served Laban in payment for the flock,96 thus completing97 the twenty years of his service. [The Archangel] Michael then descended and took her away to the house of Potiphar.
From here onward let the man of understanding increase knowledge.98
chapter.ftnote: (1) Cf. XVII, 2 where the subject was begun. Having been suspended in favour of other Festivals, it is here resumed.

The Passover ending on the twenty-first (in the land of Israel) or on the twenty-second (in the Diaspora), only eight or nine days of the month remain. As by far the greater part of the month was made up of festival days, the entire month is treated as a festival season in which fasting is prohibited.

(13) By the heathens who destroyed Jerusalem.

(21) The translation of this Rule follows the reading of GRA. V, M and H read: ‘On the fourteenth and fifteenth of Adar, tables of Ḥaberim (“associates”, i.e. men who observed levitical purity) were set up (for changing foreign currency into half-shekels); in the villages on the fourteenth and in the walled cities on the fifteenth’.

(28) ibid. XVII, 8-10.
(31) Ps. CXIII, 2.

(32) V inserts here in parentheses, as also M and H, ‘For there is no reading [of the Torah] which requires ḳaddish until after he restores [the scroll in the ark] except that of the Sabbath alone on account of the mafṭir and over the Prophet. After the scroll of the Torah is put in its place one says ṭaddish; and why ṭaddish? Only to teach’. GRA transposes this to the end of the Rule in an emended version.

(35) Three verses for each of the first two and four for the third.
(36) A Rabbi of that name.
(37) Why ten verses are required.
(38) Ta‘an. IV, 3 (Sonc. ed., p. 137).
(41) How then could R. Huna rule that a minimum of ten verses was required?
(42) As how to make ten verses out of eight.
(43) This is explained in the continuation.
(44) The second person repeats the last two of the three verses which the first had read. The two, together with the eight, make up the minimum of ten verses.
(45) The second part of each of verses 4 and 8 of Gen. I.
(46) So that verses 4 and 8 represent two verses each, bringing the number to ten.
(47) Gen. I, 6-8, three verses.
(48) ibid. 9-13, five verses.
(49) Added by GRA, omitted by V, M and H.
(50) There would only be nine, since And there was evening, etc., forms the whole of verse 13 and cannot be reckoned as two verses as in the case of verses 5 and 8.
(51) To R. Huna’s ruling.
(52) Ex. XVII, 8-16, read on Purim, which consists only of nine verses.
(53) So GRA, M and H. V reads: ‘he said, No, it is taught, it’.
(54) This reply could also have been given to the preceding objection, since in Gen. I, 6-13, if only verse 8 is divided into two, there would be nine verses, as in the section of Amalek.
(55) To R. Huna’s ruling.

(56) Meg. 23a (Sonc. ed., p. 140). From ‘but [if R. Huna’s ruling … to the last one]’ is added by GRA. V omits it but inserts in brackets: ‘It is permitted to skip in a Prophet but not in the Torah, because if [a reader] skipped even one verse by not reading it, and restored the scroll [to the ark] and recited ḳaddish, he must unroll it again, say the benedictions, and read that verse and the two verses which follow it’. This is a repetition of XI, 2, 6.
(57) In accordance with R. Huna’s ruling above that ‘for three readings … no less than ten verses must be allotted’.

(58) Since a minimum of three verses must be read for each person who is called up. No reply is given to the objection, but it is possible to provide the following explanation: Only when no more than three persons are called up is it necessary to allot ten verses, but when the number of persons is more than three, as, e.g., on the Sabbath when not less than seven persons must be called to the Torah, three verses for each person or twenty-one in all are sufficient.
(59) The fourteenth and fifteenth of Adar.
(60) In Hebrew.
(61) From this point to the end of the tractate is an aggadic addendum.
(62) Josh. XIV, 15.
(63) This is probably a reference to Gen. XXV, 6, But unto the sons of the concubines … Abraham gave gifts; and he sent them away … eastward, unto the east country.
(64) So GRA in accordance with Gen. XXV, 2-4. V, M and H incorrectly ‘seventeen’.
(65) So GRA. V, M and H read, ‘and they will be used’.
(66) Is. XXIV, 23.
(67) King of Bashan; Deut. III, 11.
(68) Abraham’s servant; cf. Gen. XV, 2, XXIV, 2ff.
(69) lit. ‘and sat in it’.
(70) Mentioned in Gen. X, 8ff.
(71) Deut. III, 4.
(72) So GRA. V, M and H read ‘and what was the’.
(73) V and H add ‘and so for all generations’, which makes no sense.
(74) Cf. Gen. XXXVII, 31ff.
(76) lit. ‘he is forgotten from the heart of his own accord’.
(77) Ps. XXXI, 13.
(78) GRA transposes the order of V, M and H by putting the test of the sheaves before that of the stones, and omits ‘according to the first opinion’.
(79) Cf. Ex. XXVIII, 30.
(80) The name of the tribe, constellation and month.
(81) The translation follows the text of GRA.
(82) Ps. LXXX, 2 where Joseph is a synonym of all Israel.
(83) Neh. III, 1.

(84) In the story of Joseph (Gen. XXXVII, 22), E.V. to restore him to his father. The name Eliashib is broken up in three parts corresponding in sound and meaning to these three Heb. words. From ‘For this reason’ to ’abiw is the reading of GRA. V and H have instead: ‘but from the mishmaroth, Eliashib the priest’.
(85) Connected with ḳanah, ‘he bought’.
(86) Gen. XXXIX, 1. V inserts in parentheses, And Pharaoh called Joseph’s name Ẓaphenath, paneah, etc. (ibid. XLI, 45), which has no relevance to the subject.
(87) Cf. ibid. XXIV, 59ff.
(88) V, M and H add ‘and three days’.
(89) H reads ‘after three years and three days’.
(90) Gen. XXIV, 16.
(91) From ‘he did not’ to ‘meant’ is GRA’s reading. V, M and H read: ‘therefore a miracle happened to her that she should not be defiled’.
(92) ‘After … age’ is inserted by GRA; omitted in V, M and H.
(93) V, M and H add: ‘on account of that which is written, Neither had any man known her, and by man only her father could be meant’.
(94) Cf. Gen. XXXIV.
(95) lit. ‘the number of’.
(96) ibid. XXXI, 41.

(98) From ‘completing the twenty years’ to ‘knowledge’ is GRA’s text. V and M have instead: ‘and he added twenty years, because he died. From this point onwards let the man of understanding increase knowledge. And Michael descended and led her to Potiphar’s house’.

chapter.title: INTRODUCTION
chapter.p: Semaḥoth (lit. ‘Joys’) is a euphemistic term for the older name of the tractate, ’Ebel Rabbathi (lit. ‘Great Mourning’). A tractate of this name is cited in the Talmud, M.Ḳ. 24a, 26b (Sonc. ed., pp. 148, 172) and Keth. 28a (Sonc. ed., p. 153), but is not completely identical with the present work.

The original Semaḥoth consisted of a collection of Baraithoth dealing with the laws of mourning for the dead prescribed by Judaism, compiled in Palestine by R. Eliezer b. Ẓadoḳ (first cent. C.E.). Later it was amplified and embellished by R. Ḥiyya, a Babylonian of the second century. It took its present form probably in the middle of the eighth century.

The tractate consists of fourteen chapters and, in addition to the laws of mourning, includes much aggadic material and several stories, e.g. the death of the Ten Martyrs (ch. VIII) and the son of R. Ḥanina b. Teradion (ch. XII). It opens with an aggadic passage of a less gloomy character, the compiler apparently feeling it desirable to begin on a brighter note.

Semaḥoth prescribes the regulations to be observed during the closing hours of a person’s life, from the time he is dying until after the burial, and the ceremonial mourning to be kept by his nearest kin during the seven and the thirty days which follow. The tractate may therefore be described as ‘The Mourner’s Manual’.

I venture the suggestion that, because mourners were forbidden to study the Torah during the seven days of strict mourning, the tractate with its aggadic embellishments served as a suitable text for reading and meditation.
I have to acknowledge my indebtedness to M. Higger’s invaluable edition of Semaḥoth which was of great help in the preparation of this work.
J. RABBINOWITZ.

chapter.title: PROEM1
chapter.p: And it came to pass at midnight, that the Lord smote all the first-born in the land of Egypt,2 etc.; and it is written, For all the first-born among the children of Israel are Mine, both men and beast; on the day that I smote all the first-born in the land of Egypt, I sanctified them for Myself.3 R. Joḥanan said: Although He smote them with the plague of death at midnight, the souls writhed within them until morning. A common proverb says, ‘If you give a morsel of bread to a child, inform his mother’.4 Likewise, the Holy One, blessed be He, said, ‘I will inform My children of the death by choking5 of which their enemies are dying. Let their souls await the morning [before expiring], so that My children shall look upon [the fate of] their enemies’.
chapter.ftnote: (1) The introductory passage bears no relation to the subject-matter of the tractate. The reason which the compiler may have had in mind in using it as a preface is mentioned in the Introduction. Higger (Introduction to his ed., p. 24) has demonstrated that this passage was originally the conclusion of Soferim which, in most MSS., preceded Semaḥoth. The tractate Soferim ends with an unpleasant subject and the author, following an ancient practice, added an aggadic passage of a more cheerful nature (cf. the repetition in the Bible of the penultimate verse of the books of Malachi, Lamentations and Ecclesiastes). The Proem is to be found in Pesiḳta Rabbathi XVII, ed. M. Friedmann, pp. 87a, b. Owing to the juxta-position of the two tractates, it was erroneously attached to Semaḥoth.
(3) Num. VIII, 17.
(4) Cf. Beẓah 16a (Sonc. ed., p. 81) where it is quoted, not as a proverb, but as a saying of Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel.
(5) GRA’s emendation of a verb in the text meaning ‘which silences’.

chapter.title: SEMAḤOTH
CHAPTER I
chapter.p: RULE 1. A dying man1 is regarded as a living entity in respect of all matters in the world: he holds [his brother’s wife] tied to the leviratical marriage,2 he frees [his mother] from the obligation of a leviratical marriage3 and enables her to eat terumah,4 and he [may also] disqualify her from eating terumah;5 he inherits and transmits;6 if one of his limbs is severed, it is regarded as a limb cut off from the living;7 if [part of his] flesh [is severed], it is regarded as flesh cut off from the living;8 and the blood of his sin-offering and guilt-offering is sprinkled for him until the time he dies.9

RULE 2. We do not tie up his cheek-bones,10 or stop up his apertures,11 or place a metal vessel or anything which chills on his navel;12 as it is stated, Before the silver cord is snapped asunder and the golden bowl is shattered, and the pitcher is broken at the fountain.13
RULE 3. We may not move him, or place him on sand or salt14 until he dies.15

RULE 4. We may not close the eyes16 of a dying man. Whoever touches and moves him is a murderer. For R. Meir used to say: He can be compared to a lamp which is dripping;17 should a man touch it he extinguishes it. Similarly whoever closes the eyes of a dying man is considered as if he had taken his life.
RULE 5. We do not rend the garments or bare the shoulder,18 or deliver a memorial address, or bring the coffin into the house until he dies.19
RULE 6. We do not summon the people20 or recount his good deeds. R. Judah said: If he is a scholar we recount his good deeds.21
RULE 7.22 In the town people do not greet each other.23 This applies only in a village,24 but in a large city it is permissible.
RULE 8. We do not carry out the mourning rites for one who came out [at birth] by pieces or with feet foremost, or for one born prematurely25 at eight months26 alive or at nine months dead.

RULE 9. For a non-Jew or a slave we do not occupy ourselves with his funeral rites, but we exclaim of him, ‘Alas lion!27 alas mighty man!’. R. Judah said: [We, for instance, exclaim], ‘Alas, Ṭabi!28 alas, faithful man who ate29 of his labour!’. They said to him,30 ‘[If so], what have you left [to be said] of worthy men [who are not slaves]?’ He replied, ‘If he was worthy, why should we not say it of him, since31 we do not receive condolence for [the loss of] male or female slaves?’

RULE 10. It is related that when R. Eliezer’s female slave died, his disciples came to comfort him. He entered the courtyard [to avoid them], but they followed him; he went into the house, but they followed him. He said to them, ‘I imagined that you would be scalded with tepid water, but now you are not even scalded with hot water.32 Have [the Sages] not said: 33We do not receive condolence for slaves because they are reckoned as animals?’34

RULE 11. And when Ṭabi the slave of Rabban Gamaliel died, he received condolence for him. They asked him, ‘Master, have you not taught us that we do not receive condolence for slaves?’ He replied, ‘My slave Ṭabi was unlike all other slaves; he was a worthy man’.

RULE 12. He also permitted Ṭabi to put on the tefillin. They said to him, ‘Master, have you not taught us that slaves are exempt from [the precept of] tefillin?’ He replied, ‘My slave Ṭabi was unlike all other slaves; he was a worthy man’.
RULE 13. We do not call male and female slaves ‘Father So-and-so, Mother So-and-so’. Those of the house of Rabban Gamaliel, however, were called ‘Father Ṭabi’ and ‘Mother Ṭabitha’.35
RULE 14. We confine the term ‘our father’ to the three Patriarchs,36 and the term ‘our mother’ to the four Matriarchs.37
chapter.ftnote: (1) Heb. gosēs, the term applied when the rattle in the throat indicates that a person is at the point of death.

(2) Cf. Deut. XXV, 5ff. Should the brother die while he himself is dying, the former’s widow is precluded from marrying until she is released by the latter from his obligation to wed her (cf. Ohol. I, 6, Sonc. ed., pp. 151f).

(3) If his father died and left no other children, his mother is free to remarry because the dying man is regarded as living. Even a child who survives one day frees his mother from the levirate. Cf. Nid. 43b (Sonc. ed., p. 303).
(4) If his mother is the daughter of a lay-Israelite married to a kohen, she may continue to eat terumah so long as he remains at the point of death.

(5) If she is the daughter of a kohen married to a lay-Israelite, she may not eat of the terumah belonging to her father which, on the death of her husband, she is permitted to eat when she returns to his home (cf. Lev. XXII, 12f). The reason is that, since her son is regarded as living, it would be contrary to the stipulation in Lev. and have no child.
(6) i.e. an estate. On inheritance and transmission, cf. B.B. 108a (Sonc. ed., p. 448).

(7) There is a legal difference if it is a limb severed from a living or dead body. If it was from a dead body, a piece of flesh from it, even the size of an olive, communicates defilement; but if from a living body it does not. Therefore, if one of the dying man’s limbs is severed, flesh from it does not defile because he is considered a living being.
(8) Flesh not necessarily from a severed limb.

(9) Where a man who brought a sin- or guilt-offering died before it was sacrificed, the animal for the former had to be killed and the latter turned into the fields to graze until it died naturally. But with a dying man who brought an offering, the ritual connected with his sacrifice was carried out completely.
(10) To prevent the jaw from dropping; cf. Shab. 151a (Sonc. ed., p. 771).
(11) To prevent air from entering.
(12) Shab. loc. cit. reads ‘on his stomach’, that it should not swell.
(13) Eccl. XII, 6. None of these acts may be done because they hasten death.
(14) For ‘salt’ GRA reads ‘a vessel that chills’; cf. Tosiftha Shab. XVIII, 18.
(15) So that the body should keep cool and not swell.

(16) Shab. loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 772). Closing the eyes of a corpse is a very ancient practice. According to Ibn Ezra the custom is alluded to in Gen. XLVI, 4, and Joseph shall put his hand upon thine eyes (cf. his commentary ad loc.). The custom was current among the ancient Greeks and Romans and is practised by the Egyptians [cf. Seyffert, Dictionary of Classical Antiquities, p. 101b, and Lane, Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians, ch. XXVIII]. A man, at the moment of death, was believed to behold the Divine Presence (cf. Job XIX, 27) and therefore it was unfitting that after that vision his eyes should look at anything mundane. Cf. A. Bender in Jewish Quarterly Review, VII (1895), pp. 102f.
(17) Shab. loc cit. reads ‘a lamp that is going out’.
(18) Cf. Rashi to M.Ḳ. 22b (Sonc. ed., p. 140). R. Meir of Rothenberg explains the word ḥoleẓin in the usual sense of ‘removing the shoes’.
(19) These things should be avoided so as not to frighten the dying person.
(20) Cf. 1 Sam. XV, 4, XXIII, 8 for this usage of the Heb. verb. Brüll adds the word ‘ayaroth (cf. Sanh. 47a, Sonc. ed., p. 311), ‘We do not summon the people of the townships’.
(21) Because he is accustomed to have his praises sung and it would not distress him in the circumstances.
(22) This Rule is not connected with the preceding, but speaks of a case where there is a dead person in the town.
(23) Because all must share in the mourning, and greeting is not permitted to a mourner.
(24) Where all learn quickly of the death.
(25) Heb. nefel, a child who dies within thirty days of birth.
(26) And cannot therefore survive.
(27) So H; V repeats ‘lion’.
(28) The faithful slave of Rabban Gamaliel (cf. Ber. 16b, Sonc. ed. p. 96).
(29) In Ber. ‘who worked for his living’.
(30) To R. Jose who, in Ber. (Sonc. ed., p. 97), suggested the praise to be made over a faithful slave.
(31) So H; V lacks ‘since’.
(32) The meaning is, I made it clear to you that I did not want to receive your condolence; cf. Ber. loc. cit.
(33) In Ber., ‘Have I not taught you’, etc.

(34) The text in Ber. reads: What do we say over them? As we say to a man on the death of his ox or ass, ‘May the Omnipresent repair thy loss’, so we say to a man on the death of his slaves, ‘May the Omnipresent repair thy loss’.
(35) Quoted from Ber. loc. cit. [The female slave Ṭabitha is mentioned in j.Nid. I, 4, 49b.]
(36) Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
(37) Sara, Rebekah, Rachel and Leah. This Rule is also culled, in a slightly different form from Ber. loc. cit.

chapter.title: CHAPTER II
chapter.p: RULE 1. We do not occupy ourselves in any respect with the funeral rites of one who committed suicide wilfully. R. Ishmael said: We exclaim over him, ‘Alas for a lost1 [life!] Alas for a [lost] life!’ R. ‘Aḳiba said to him, ‘Leave him unmourned; speak neither well nor ill of him’.2

We do not rend garments for him,3 bare the shoulder, or deliver a memorial address over him. We do, however, stand in a row4 for him and recite the benediction of mourners5 for him, from respect of the living [relatives]. The general rule is: With anything that makes for respect of the living we occupy ourselves, but with anything that does not make for the respect of the living, the public do not in any way occupy themselves.

RULE 2. Who [comes within the category of] ‘one who committed suicide wilfully’? He does not who climbed to the top of a tree and fell down and died, or he who went up to the top of the roof and fell down and died.6 But he who calls out, ‘Look, I am going to the top of the roof or to the top of the tree, and I will throw myself down that I may die’ [comes within the category]. When people saw him go up to the top of a tree or roof [for the purpose] and he fell down and died, he is presumed to have committed suicide wilfully; and with the person who commits suicide wilfully we do not occupy ourselves in any respect.
RULE 3. If a person was found strangled or hanging from a tree or lying dead on a sword, he is presumed not to have committed suicide wilfully, and none [of the rites] are withheld from him.

RULE 4. It is related of the son of Gorgias7 of Lydda that he ran away from school and his father pointed to his ear.8 In fear of his father he went and destroyed himself in a pit.9 They went and inquired of R. Ṭarfon who ruled: We do not withhold anything from him.10

RULE 5. It is related of a child in Benë Beraḳ11 that he broke a bottle on the Sabbath and his father pointed to his ear. In fear of his father he went and destroyed himself in a pit. They inquired of R. ‘Aḳiba who ruled: We do not withhold anything from him.
RULE 6. Hence the Sages ruled: A man should not point at the ear of a child, but either punish him immediately or keep silent and say nothing to him.
R. Simeon b. Eleazar said:12 With human nature,13 a child and a woman, the left hand should repulse them but the right hand bring them back.14

RULE 7. With those executed by a Court we do not occupy ourselves in any respect. Their brothers and relatives come and greet the witnesses and judges15 [as if to say], ‘We have no [ill feelings] against you in our hearts because you gave a true judgment’. They observe no [public] mourning16 for them but grieve, since grief is felt only in the heart.
RULE 8. R. Nathan said: There is no difference between silence and mourning.17
RULE 9. The ‘meal of comfort’18 is not eaten in their case, as it is stated, Ye shall not eat [anything] with the blood.19
[The judges of] a Court who ordered the execution of a man used not to eat anything on that day.20

[The condemned] are allowed to converse with their brothers and relatives; and not to delay matters21 they are given to drink wine containing frankincense22 so that they should not feel grieved. They are urged23 to confess, because he who confesses has a portion in the World to Come. We find it so with Achan to whom Joshua said, My son, give, I pray thee, glory to the Lord, the God of Israel, and make confession unto Him; and tell me now what thou hast done; hide nothing from me. And Achan answered Joshua, and said: Of a truth I have sinned against the Lord, the God of Israel, and thus and thus have I done.24 What is the meaning of and thus and thus? It teaches that he violated the ban twice.25 [44b] I have sinned, i.e. I and not my household, I and not my children. This teaches that he truthfully26 confessed. And whence do we know that his confession made atonement for him? As it is stated, And Joshua said: Why hast thou troubled us? The Lord shall trouble thee this day27—this day art thou to be troubled but thou shalt not be troubled in the World to Come; and it states, And the sons of Zerah: Zimri, and Ethan, and Heman, and Calcol and Dara: five of them in all.28 Do we not know that there were five of them in all?29 It teaches that Achan will be with them in the world to come.30

Similarly one who steals the tax31 or anything devoted [to the Sanctuary] is as if he shed blood; and not only is he as if he shed blood, but he is also as if he worships idols, was guilty of immorality and desecrates the Sabbath.32

RULE 10. We do not occupy ourselves with those who separated themselves from the community33 in any respect. Their brothers and relatives clothe themselves in white, wrap themselves in white and eat and drink and rejoice because an enemy of the All-present perished; as it is stated, Do not I hate them, O Lord, that hate Thee? And do not I strive with those that rise up against Thee? I hate them with utmost hatred; I count them mine enemies.34
RULE 11. We do not withhold mourning rites from those executed by the Government.35

When do we begin to count [the days of mourning] for them?36 From the time that [the relatives] despaired in their appeal [for the body to be delivered to them for burial], but not [given up the hope] of stealing it. For he who steals is as if he shed blood, and not only is he as if he had shed blood, but also as if he worshipped idols, etc.37

RULE 12. Mourning rites are not withheld in any respect from one who fell into the sea, or was washed away by a stream, or killed by a wild beast. When do we begin to count [the days of mourning] for such as these? From the time that hope of finding them has been given up. If they found a body limb by limb, we do not count [the days of mourning] until the head and greater part [of the torso] is found. R. Judah said: The spine and skull constitute the greater part [of the torso].

RULE 13. If one’s husband, wife, father or mother had been impaled38 in his city, one should not continue to reside there39 unless it is a city as big as Antioch.40 [Even then] one should not reside in the same side of the city but in another part. Until when is one so forbidden? Until the flesh is completely decomposed and the identity41 unrecognizable from the bones.

RULE 14. [Beth Shammai said:]42 If a man divorced his wife, he should not live in the same alley or courtyard as she.43 If the alley belonged to both of them, he transfers the door [of his house] to another side; and if the courtyard belonged to both of them, one vacates it on account of the other, and the woman vacates it on account of the man. This rule only applies if she has remarried44 and in the case of the [divorced] wife of a kohen even if she has not remarried.45 It further applies only if she is divorced after marriage and not after betrothal.46 Likewise one who has freed his sister-in-law from the levirate marriage47 does not vacate on account of her, because he does not feel attracted to her.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Heb. niṭṭelah, ‘[a life] carried away’. H reads nishlah with a similar meaning (cf. God takth away [yeshel] his soul, Job XXVII, 8). GRA emends to nithlah, ‘hanged’.
(2) lit. ‘do not bless him and do not curse him’.
(3) According to the Ṭur Y.D., §345, near relatives do not rend their garments.
(4) At the cemetery after the funeral those present divide themselves into two rows and the mourners pass between them to receive condolences.

(5) The condolence ended with the words, ‘Blessed be He Who comforteth the mourners’ (Keth. 8b, Sonc. ed., p. 40). Hence the term ‘benediction of mourners’; cf. J. Rabbinowitz, Mishnah Megillah, p. 119.
(6) It may have been an accidental fall.
(7) A variant is Gornos. [He is not mentioned elsewhere in Rabbinic literature.]
(8) i.e. he threatened to punish him.
(9) So GRA and H. V wrongly ‘with a garment’.
(10) He is buried with full rites.
(11) A town near Jaffa.
(12) Sanh. 107b (Sonc. ed., p. 736), Soṭah 47a (Sonc. ed., p. 246).
(13) Heb. Yeẓer, which means human instinct; cf. Lazarus, Ethics of Judaism, II, pp. 106f.
(14) One should not be too severe with them, not suppressing their desires but disciplining them.
(15) Cf. Sanh. 46a (Sonc. ed., p. 305).
(16) i.e. the seven days, thirty days and the twelve months.

(17) i.e. the silence of the mourners is itself a form of mourning. Hence the persons mentioned in the previous Rule must not even grieve. It is suggested that R. Nathan’s statement was originally a marginal note which found its way into the text.

(18) The first meal partaken by the mourners on their return from the funeral is termed ‘the meal of comfort [habra’ah]’; cf. 2 Sam. III, 35, to cause David to eat bread (lehabroth). It was prepared by friends and consisted of lentils and eggs (cf. Sanh. 63a, Sonc. ed., p. 430, n. 6) the round shape of which being a reminder of the revolving wheel of fortune.
(19) Lev. XIX, 26. This is homiletically interpreted to mean: where blood is shed (i.e. an execution has taken place) no ceremonial meal of mourners should be eaten. Cf. Sanh. loc. cit.
(20) Sanh. loc. cit.
(21) i.e. to avoid giving the appearance that the execution of justice is unduly protracted.
(22) To numb the senses; cf. Sanh. 43a (Sonc. ed., p. 279).
(23) lit. ‘they teach them’.
(24) Josh. VII, 19f.
(25) By taking from the devoted things on two occasions. Sanh. 43b (Sonc. ed., p. 284) explains that he took of the ban three times, twice in the days of Moses and once at Jericho.
(26) Of a truth (’omnam) is explained as be’emunah (‘truthfully’).
(28) 1 Chron. II, 6.
(29) Since five names are specified.

(30) Cf. Sanh. 44b (Sonc. ed., p. 291). Zimri, according to a tradition, is identical with Achan. As Achan is mentioned together with the other four, who are considered to be worthy men, it is an indication that his confession was accepted and with them he shared in the World to Come.
(31) i.e. eludes the customs; cf. B.Ḳ. 113a (Sonc. ed., p. 663), Tosiftha B.Ḳ. X, 8.
(32) [On this passage, cf. Büchler, Studies in Sin and Atonement, p. 198n.]
(33) According to Maimonides (Hil. ’Ebel, I, 5, cf. Ṭur Y.D., §345) the reference is to those who discarded all the religious precepts and ceremonies of Judaism.
(34) Ps. CXXXIX, 21f.
(35) i.e. the occupying power, viz. the Romans.
(36) Usually this begins from the moment the grave is filled in, but here the body of the victim was not handed over to the family for burial.
(37) This sentence is repeated from the last clause of Rule 9 and has no relevance to the present context.
(38) By the Roman authorities. Impaling was not a form of execution carried out by the Jews.
(39) On seeing him, people will recall the impaling of his relative, and that would be a slight on the memory of the victim.
(40) The ancient capital of Syria. Since it is a large city, the fact might not be generally known.
(41) lit. ‘the form’.
(42) GRA omits. For what follows, cf. Keth. 27b, 28a (Sonc. ed., p. 152).
(43) Lest he be tempted to cohabit with her.
(44) So GRA; V ‘they have married’. After remarriage with another she can never return to her first husband (cf. Deut. XXIV, 3f).
(45) A kohen may not marry a divorced woman, not even his divorced wife (Lev. XXI, 7).
(46) Cf. Kallah 1, n. 1.
(47) Cf. Deut. XXV, 5ff.

chapter.title: CHAPTER III
chapter.p: RULE 1. A child who lived only one day counts to his father and mother as a fully-grown man.1 [The words] ‘who lived only one day’ are not to be taken as an [irreducible] limit;2 even if only his head and the greater part of his body came out viable [he is so counted, but in their formulation of the law] the Sages speak of what actually happens.

RULE 2.3 [An infant] who is carried in the arms4 is buried by one woman and two men.5 Abba Saul said: [The burial may be done] by one man and two women. [The Sages] said to him: One woman may be alone with two men, but one man may not be alone with two women.6

[The people at the burial] do not stand in line on account of him and they need not recite the mourner’s benediction on account of him unless he was thirty days old. If he was thirty days old, he is accompanied [to the grave] by men and women and is carried in a case upon the arms7 up to the age of twelve months. If he was twelve months old, he is accompanied by men and women and is carried in a case on the shoulder up to the age of three years. R. Judah said: Should his father desire to honour him, they take him out in a coffin to the cemetery even before8 he is three years old.

RULE 3. If three years old he is taken out on a bier. R. ‘Aḳiba said: If he is three years old but his limbs are [developed] like those of an infant two years old,9 or if he is two years old but his limbs are like those of an infant three years old, he is carried on a bier. Simeon the brother of Azariah said: For anyone who is taken out on a bier the people show their distress.10 R. Meir said in the name of R. Eleazar b. Azariah: If he is known to the public at large they participate in connection with him [at the funeral], but if not, they do not participate in connection with him.

RULE 4. R. Judah said in the name of R. Eleazar b. Azariah: For the purpose of a memorial address it is sufficient that his neighbours [know him]. In the case of the poor a memorial address is delivered for a child of three,11 and in the case of the rich for a child of four. R. ‘Aḳiba said: In the case of the poor, for a child of six and in the case of the rich for a child of seven. The children of the rich are like the children of scholars and the children of scholars like the children of kings.12

RULE 5. In the case of a child of developed intelligence13 we dwell [in the memorial address for him] on his own [good] deeds, but if he has no such deeds we dwell on the deeds of his parents; and if his parents have no such deeds we dwell on the deeds of his relatives. In the case of a bride we dwell on the honour of her father or father-in-law, because she rises [in esteem] with him14 but does not fall with him. We may not ascribe merits to one who has none,15 but we may magnify those which he possessed.16

RULE 6.17 In Jerusalem there was a saying, ‘Perform actions [which can be lamented] in front of your bier’,18 and in Judea there was a saying, ‘Perform actions [which can be lamented] behind your bier’. For in Jerusalem they recounted in front of a dead man’s bier only the merits which he possessed; but in Judea they recounted merits which he possessed and did not possess. They, however, who walked behind the bier only repeated after them the merits which he possessed.19
[One who dies] between the ages of three and thirty [is mourned] like a bridegroom;20 between thirty and forty like a brother;21 between forty and fifty like a father.22

RULE 7. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: Between thirty and forty, if he has children or the majority of his own age have children, [he is mourned] like a father; if not, like a brother. Between forty and fifty, if he has children or the majority of his own age have grandchildren, [he is mourned] like a grandfather, if not like a father.23

RULE 8.24 If one dies under fifty, that is death by kareth;25 at fifty-two, that is the death of Samuel of Ramah; at sixty, that is the death referred to in the Torah, as it is stated, Thou shalt come to thy grave in ripe age;26 at seventy, that is the death of the hoary head, as it is stated, The days of our years are threescore years and ten;27 at eighty, that is the death of a vigorous old man,28 as it is stated, Or even by strength fourscore years.29 More than this is a life of trouble, for so30 Barzilai the Gileadite said to David, I am this day fourscore years old; can I discern between good and bad?31

RULE 9. If one dies after [an illness of] one day, that is a death by [divine] wrath;32 after two days, it is a precipitous death; after three days, it is a death by pestilence; after four days, it is a hurried death; after six days, it is the death decreed in the Torah;33 after seven days, it is a death of [divine] love; after a longer period, it is a death of suffering.

RULE 10. R. Ḥanina b. Antigonos said: An old man who eats forbidden fat34 or one who desecrates the Sabbath dies by kareth. And what is there to show us that they died by kareth? But he who dies after [an illness of] three days dies by kareth; after four by a hurried death; after six, it is the death decreed in the Torah; after seven it is a death of [divine] love; after a longer period it is a death by suffering.

R. Judah said:35 The pious men of former times used to suffer with stomach trouble for about twenty days before death in order to be cleansed of everything, so that they should come pure36 into the World to Come;37 as it is said, The refining pot is for silver, and the furnace for gold, and a man is tried by his praise.38 [45a].
chapter.ftnote: (1) With respect to mourning; cf. Nid. 44a (Sonc. ed., p. 303). The phrase ḥathan shalem, lit. ‘a complete bridegroom’, is based on ḥathan damim, a bridegroom of blood (Ex. IV, 25). For the idea that circumcision makes one ‘complete’, cf. Ned. 31b (Sonc. ed., p. 93).
(2) lit. ‘the end of the matter’.
(3) Cf. M.Ḳ. 24a (Sonc. ed., p. 151).
(4) lit. ‘goes out in the bosom’.
(5) For reasons of propriety. GRA inserts ‘but not by one man and two women’.
(6) A quotation from Ḳid. IV, 12 (Sonc. ed., p. 413).
(7) Cf. M.Ḳ. 24b (Sonc. ed., pp. 151f). Apparently not a full-sized coffin is meant.
(8) So GRA; V ‘until’.
(9) V wrongly in brackets ‘he is not carried on a bier’.

(10) [Heb. meḳallesin which in Rabbinic Heb. means ‘stamp with the foot’ as a sign of mourning (cf. Ezek. VI, 11).] The Talmud, which gives the name of the Rabbi as Simeon b. Eleazar, uses a different verb; cf. M.Ḳ. 24b (Sonc. ed., p. 151, n. 9).
(11) The child being a greater joy to poor parents who have few pleasures in life, and so his death is a greater loss.
(12) The children are praised in the memorial address to honour the parents.
(13) lit. ‘he knows how to transact [his affairs]’.
(14) viz. her father-in-law. The reading of GRA and H is adopted.
(15) lit. ‘we do not add from the start’. Cf. Ber. 62a (Sonc. ed., p. 390), ‘As the dead are called to account [for their deeds], so are funeral orators [who exaggerate the merits of the dead]’.
(16) lit. ‘we may add to the stock’.
(17) Cf. Shab. 153a (Sonc. ed., p. 781).
(18) Apparently the place of the people in a funeral procession differed according to local custom. In Jerusalem they walked in front of the bier, in Judea behind it. Cf. Tosiftha Pes. II, 16.
(19) The emended text of GRA and H is followed.
(20) Since he may be unmarried.
(21) He may be married but childless.
(22) As one mourned by his children.
(23) So GRA. V and H read: ‘have children [he is mourned] like a father; if not like a brother’.
(24) Cf. M.Ḳ. 28a (Sonc. ed., p. 182). In j.Bik. II, 1, 64C there are variants in the enumeration.
(25) Cf. J. Rabbinowitz, Mishnah Megillah, p. 54.
(26) Job V, 26; in ripe age is בכלח in Heb., the numerical value of the letters being sixty. Cf. M.Ḳ. loc. cit.
(28) lit. ‘of strength’.
(29) ibid.
(30) This is GRA’s reading; V and H have ‘and likewise Barzilai’ and insert ‘more than this is a life of trouble’ after the quotation.
(32) In M.Ḳ. 28a (Sonc. ed., p. 181) the reading is ‘a death by being hustled away’.

(33) A normal death. M.Ḳ. loc. cit. has ‘five’ instead of ‘six’, quotes Deut. XXXI, 14, Behold thy days approach that thou must die and explains: behold accounts for one (cf. Sonc. ed., loc. cit., n. 6), thy days accounts for two more, approach gives a further two, which makes five.
(34) Cf. Lev. III, 17.
(35) Cf. Midrash Rabbah, Genesis, LXVI, 2 (Sonc. ed., p. 549) and Shab. 118b (Sonc. ed., p. 583).
(36) So GRA; V and H ‘innocent’.
(37) [For the thought, cf. ARN I, 1, p. 1, n. 5.]
(38) Prov. XXVII, 21. [H quotes ibid. XVII, 3 as the proof-text.]

chapter.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter.p: RULE 1.1 For all [the nearest of kin] for whom a kohen defiles himself as commanded in the Torah2 [a mourner must observe mourning], viz. for his father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister and wife.3 R. ‘Aḳiba said: For relatives in the second degree4 he observes the periods of mourning and grieves,5 [but should he be a kohen] he does not defile himself.

RULE 2. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: He mourns for his father’s father and son’s son.6 But the Sages said: For whomsoever he mourns he should mourn with, and for whomsoever he does not mourn, he does not mourn with.7 If there is a doubt whether [the deceased] is a brother or not8 or whether he is his son or not, he mourns and grieves for him, but [if he is a kohen] he does not defile himself for him.

RULE 3. For his betrothed wife one does not mourn, grieve,9 or [if a kohen] defile himself.10 For his divorced wife, although he had children by her, he does not mourn, grieve, or [if a kohen] defile himself.
RULE 4. Which is [the period of] ‘grieving’? From the day of the death until the day of the burial, according to R. Meir; but the Sages said: ‘Grieving’ is only for one day.11
If a High Priest is married to a widow or an ordinary kohen to a divorced woman or one freed12 from levirate marriage, he mourns and grieves for her but does not defile himself.
RULE 5. For his betrothed sister, R. Meir said that [a kohen] defiles himself. R. Judah and R. Simeon said that he does not.13

RULE 6. For [his sister who was] ‘wounded’,14 R. Judah said that [a kohen] defiles himself. R. Meir and R. Simeon said that he does not. For a woman who was raped or seduced, all agree that [a kohen] does not defile himself. For an adolescent,15 all agree that he defiles himself.

RULE 7. The general principle laid down by R. Simeon is: He defiles himself for any one who is eligible [to marry] a High Priest, but may not defile himself for one who is not eligible [to marry] a High Priest.
RULE 8. Of all those regarding whom they said that a kohen defiles himself, the defilement is not voluntary but obligatory. R. Simeon said: It is voluntary. R. Joshua said: It is obligatory.16

RULE 9. It is related of Joseph, a kohen, that his wife died on the eve of Passover and he would not defile himself for her. His colleagues pushed him17 and defiled him forcibly. Defilement is not voluntary but compulsory.

RULE 10. Until how long is it one’s duty to defile himself for her? R. Meir said: The whole of that day;18 R. Judah said: Up to three hours. R. Judah said in the name of R. Ṭarfon: Until the top stone closes the grave.19

RULE 11. It is related that when R. Simeon b. Yehoẓadaḳ died in Lydda, his brother Joḥanan came from Galilee to defile himself for him after the top stone had closed the grave. They went and inquired of the Sages who said: He may not defile himself, but open the grave for him that he may view [the body].

RULE 12. It is related20 of a boy21 that he willed away his property to strangers and left his family out. They protested saying, ‘Let [his body] be examined’.22 They went and inquired of the Sages who said, ‘The body may not be examined; after the top stone has closed the grave, a corpse may not be moved from his place’. Another explanation is: Since he is dead, his hair has undergone change.23

RULE 13. An ordinary kohen who defiled himself for his near kin may not defile himself for strangers even on the same day.24 This rule applies only when there are sufficient to carry the bier and bury him, but if there are not sufficient to carry the bier and bury him, then he must defile himself.25 Should he have defiled himself and sufficient people come to carry the bier and bury, he must withdraw to a place of cleanness.

RULE 14. Should there be two roads [for his return from the cemetery] one short but [ritually] unclean and one long but [ritually] clean, if the other persons take the longer road he should go with them; and if they do not, he should take the unclean road out of respect for the people.26

RULE 15. While he stands and buries his dead he may, during the time he is standing in the grave, receive [a body] for burial from others;27 but once he has withdrawn from the grave he may not defile himself.

RULE 16. If he defiles himself [for a stranger] on the same day [as for another], R. Ṭarfon deems him culpable, but R. ‘Aḳiba frees him from culpability. If he defiles himself the next day, all are agreed that he is culpable, because he has rendered one day [of his mourning] void.28

RULE 17. A kohen must defile himself for his near kin even when they have a disqualification;29 for his son and daughter who are Nethinim30 or illegitimate;31 for his brother and sister who are Nethinim or illegitimate; but not for any issue he may have from a slave or a non-Jewess (nor from the issue he may have from another source).32
RULE 18. If there is a doubt whether [the deceased] is his brother or not or whether he is his son or not, he mourns and grieves but [if a kohen] he does not defile himself.33
RULE 19. How long is [the period of] ‘grieving’? From the day of the death until the day of the burial, according to the view of R. Meir; but the Sages said: ‘Grieving’ is for one day only.
RULE 20. A High Priest who defiles himself for the dead, lets the hair of his head go loose, or rends his garments,34 receives forty lashes.35

RULE 21. Any defilement contracted by a Nazirite from the dead and for which he must shave his head,36 if contracted by a High Priest he receives forty lashes for it; but [for those defilements for which] the Nazirite has not to shave his head, [if contracted by a High Priest], he does not receive forty lashes.37
RULE 22. A High Priest38 who defiles himself or enters a cemetery receives forty lashes.
RULE 23. If [a kohen] entered39 the residence of non-Jews40 or the territory of Gentiles41 or a beth happeras42 or goes outside the land [of Israel],43 he receives punishment for disobedience.44
RULE 24. If he enters a field wherein [the location of] a grave had disappeared, he is not culpable unless he traverses the whole of it.45

RULE 25. A kohen may defile himself by going outside the land [of Israel] for the purpose of [dealing with a non-Jewish Court in] a civil suit or a capital charge, to announce the new moon or intercalate the year, or to rescue his field from a non-Jew, even if he only goes to protest [against his taking possession of it].46

RULE 26.47 [He may go outside the land of Israel] to study Torah or to take a wife. R. Judah said: If he has nowhere else to study he may so defile himself, otherwise he may not. R. Jose said: Even though he has elsewhere to study he may defile himself, because no one is so meritorious as to be able to learn Torah from any man. It is related of Jose the Babylonian that he defiled himself by going outside the land [of Israel to study Torah] with R. Jose in Zidon.48

RULE 27.49 A kohen must defile himself for [the burial of] a bone from his father’s [corpse] of the size of a barleycorn,50 but he may not defile himself for a limb severed from a living person be it even that of his father.
