R. Judah said: At first [a kohan] may not defile himself for a limb severed from a corpse, be it even that of his father.

RULE 28. It is related of Joseph [the son of] Pisḳas51 who had a swelling on his foot that a doctor came to remove it. He said to him, ‘When you have left as much as a single hair, tell me’. He cut the abscess, and when he had left only as much as a single hair,52 he informed him. He called his son Neḥunia and said to him, ‘My son, until now it was your duty to attend to me, but now go your way; for the Sages said, “One must not defile himself for a limb that was severed from a living person, even if it be his father’s” ’.53 When the Sages heard of it they said, ‘Of such a man as he it has been stated, My soul is continually in my hand; yet have I not forgotten Thy law;54 [and it further states,] There is a righteous man that perisheth in his righteousness55 and there is a wicked man that prolongeth his life in his evil-doing.’56

RULE 29. If he found a meth miẓwah, he must attend to him and bury him. Which is a meth miẓwah.? When [he who finds the body] cries out and the inhabitants of the city cannot hear his voice; but if they can hear his voice, it is not a meth miẓwah.57

RULE 30. [The body remains] a meth miẓwah until sufficient people arrive to carry the bier and bury him; but once there are sufficient to carry the bier and bury him it is no longer a meth miẓwah. [45b]

RULE 31. If a High Priest58 and a Nazirite [found a meth miẓwah], R. Eliezer said that the High Priest should defile himself and not the Nazirite, because the latter must offer a sacrifice on his defilement59 whereas the former does not. But the Sages said: The Nazirite should defile himself even if he has to bring a hundred sacrifices, and let not the High Priest60 defile himself, because the one is consecrated from the womb and the other is not,61 and the consecration of the one is temporary62 and that of the other permanent.

RULE 32.63 All are agreed that [in the case of the High] Priest anointed with the oil of anointing64 and [the High Priest robed] in many vestments,65 the latter must defile himself.66 As between a [High Priest robed] in many vestments and a deputy [High Priest] who had been anointed,67 the latter must defile himself. As between a deputy [High Priest] and a memunneh,68 the latter must defile himself. As between a memunneh and a kohen anointed for war,69 the latter must defile himself. As between a kohen anointed for war and an ordinary kohen, the latter must defile himself.70 As between an ordinary kohen and a Levite, the Levite must defile himself.71 As between a Levite and a lay-Israelite, the latter must defile himself.72 If, however, the two [who find a meth miẓwah] are of equal status, the quicker of the two must defile himself; and if the two of them are [equally] quick, then whichever of them wishes to do so should defile himself.

RULE 33. If they found [the body] between a ploughed field and a fallow field, they bury him in the fallow field;73 between a ploughed field and a field sown with seeds, they bury him in the ploughed field; between a field sown with seeds and an orchard, they bury him in the field sown with seeds; between an orchard and a vineyard,74 they bury him in the orchard. If both are alike, they bury him in the nearer of the two; and if they are equidistant,75 they bury him in whichever of them they desire.

RULE 34. R. ‘Aḳiba said: This was the beginning of my ministration76 before the Sages. I once went out early and found the body of a man who had been killed. I took charge of him for a distance of three Sabbath-limits77 until I brought him to a place of burial and buried him. When I came and discussed the matter before the Sages, they said to me, ‘For each step you took it will be accounted to you as if you had committed murder’.78 I then argued from the less to the greater as a result of my experience:79 if when I intended to perform a meritorious act I rendered myself culpable, how much more so if I had not intended to perform a meritorious act!’ Whenever a person repeated this incident before R. ‘Aḳiba, he exclaimed, ‘This was the beginning of my ministration [before the Sages]’.
chapter.ftnote: (1) Cf. M.Ḳ. 20b (Sonc. ed., p. 130).
(2) Lev. XXI, 2f.
(3) So GRA and H. V reads ‘wife and sister’.

(4) i.e. his grandfather, grandchildren and nephews (Rashi to M.Ḳ. loc. cit.). In Sonc. ed., p. 130, n. 7 the enumeration is grandfather, grandmother, grandchildren and the brothers and sisters of parents.
(5) While waiting for the funeral to take place; cf. Rule 19 below.

(6) R. Simeon either interprets that R. ‘Aḳiba excludes the daughter’s son and the sister’s son, or differs from him in that he holds that one mourns only for these two relatives in the second degree.
(7) As one mourns in sympathy with one’s father on the death of his father, so should a father mourn with his son on the death of the latter’s son.
(8) Where the identity of the child at birth or in infancy became confused. j.Yeb. XI, 7, 12a cites an actual case.
(9) ‘Or grieve’ is added by GRA and H.

(10) The duty of mourning, etc., for a wife devolves upon the husband only when she can be termed his kin (Lev. XXI, 2). The betrothed woman does not come in this category and the divorced wife has lost that status (cf. Sanh. 28b, Sonc. ed., p. 171). See also Yeb. 22a (Sonc. ed., p. 132), 29b (Sonc. ed., p. 183).
(11) Cf. Zeb. 100b (Sonc. ed., pp. 483f).

(12) Although such marriages are forbidden (Lev. XXI, 7, 14, the levirate woman being treated in Rabbinic law as a divorced woman), yet if contracted they are valid; but being irregular, they come under the prohibition of ibid. 2 (priests in general) and ibid. XXI, 11 (the High Priest). Cf. Yeb. 90b (Sonc. ed., p. 616), ‘but he may not defile himself for his unlawful wife’.
(13) Lev. XXI, 3, and for his sister a virgin, betrothal being a form of marriage; cf. Yeb. 60a (Sonc. ed., pp. 400f).
(14) lit. ‘struck by wood’, viz. one who lost her hymen as the result of a blow; Yeb. loc. cit.
(15) i.e. over the age of twelve years and six months.
(16) The phrase for her he defiles [E.V. may he defile] himself (Lev. XXI, 3) is to be understood as an obligation; cf. Zeb. 100a (Sonc. ed., p. 480).
(17) He forced him to make contact with the corpse; Zeb. loc. cit.
(18) i.e. of the death. The funeral generally took place on the same day.
(19) Cf. Nazir, Sonc. ed., p. 202, n. 5.
(21) A minor under thirteen years and one day, who could not legally dispose of his property.
(22) i.e. let the body be exhumed and his age ascertained from the presence or absence of signs of puberty.
(23) Therefore the examination cannot produce decisive evidence of age.
(24) Cf. Nazir 42b (Sonc. ed., pp. 154f).
(25) Then it is a case of meth miẓwah (v. Glos.).
(26) This is the reading of H.V has ‘respect for the Name’.
(27) As he is engaged in burying his dead, the new burial merely prolongs his uncleanness; cf. Nazir 42b (Sonc. ed., p. 155).
(28) i.e. he has to begin afresh the seven days of mourning.
(29) If they are his children by marriage to a divorced woman, etc. (cf. Lev. XXI, 7).
(30) The name given to the descendants of the Gibeonites whom Joshua made hewers of wood and drawers of water (Josh. IX).
(31) The issue of an incestuous marriage.
(32) The clause in brackets is omitted by GRA. It may, however, refer to the issue of one who left the community.
(33) Repeated from the latter part of Rule 2, and Rule 19 is repeated from Rule 4.
(34) Cf. Lev. XXI, 10.
(35) Cf. Tosiftha Mak. IV, 17.
(36) Cf. Num. VI, 9.
(37) Cf. Nazir 49b (Sonc. ed., p. 184). If, e.g., the Nazirite came in contact with a corpse or the flesh of a corpse of the size of an olive.
(38) This Rule virtually repeats Rule 20 and is deleted by GRA.
(39) So GRA and H. V reads ‘although they entered’.
(40) Who do not conform to the laws of uncleanness and he is therefore liable to contract defilement.
(41) i.e. a district in Palestine which is inhabited only by non-Jews.

(42) The noun peras denotes ‘half’ the length of a furrow. A beth happera is defined by Jastrow as ‘an area of a square peras, especially a field, of a square peras, declared unclean on account of crushed bones carried over it from a ploughed grave’.
(43) Where the laws of uncleanness are not observed by the inhabitants.
(44) Unlike the forty stripes which is the punishment for certain offences, this penalty is left to the discretion of the Court and is consequently a Rabbinical form of punishment.
(45) Then he must have come in contact with it.
(47) ibid.
(48) In Phœnicia.
(49) The text of this Rule is in disorder and the translation follows the text of GRA.
(50) Cf. Nazir 43b Sonc. ed., p. 159, n. 2).
(51) Cf. j.Nazir VII, 1, 55d. The text here is corrupt and the reading of GRA which agrees with the Talmud is followed.
(52) i.e. the swelling was hanging from the foot as by a hair.
(53) Joseph was a kohen.
(55) Although Joseph was in danger of dying under the operation, he remembered to warn his son of the law of defilement which devolved upon a kohen.
(56) Eccl. VII, 15.
(57) Yeb. 89b (Sonc. ed., p. 610), Nazir 43b (Sonc. ed., p. 158).
(58) So GRA in agreement with Nazir VII, 1 (Sonc. ed., p. 177).
(59) Num. VI, 9ff.
(60) So H; V reads ‘an ordinary kohen’.
(61) A man becomes a Nazirite by choice.
(62) For the term of his vow.
(63) For the varying degrees of sanctity indicated in this Rule, cf. Nazir 47a (Sonc. ed., p. 177). The translation follows the emended text of GRA.

(64) All High Priests, beginning with Aaron, were consecrated with oil. During the reign of Josiah this ceremony ceased because the king had concealed the flask of special oil used for the ceremony (Hor. 12a, Sonc. ed., p. 85).

(65) During the Second Temple the High Priest was not anointed, and was only distinguished from the ordinary priests by wearing a larger number of vestments when officiating, eight as against their four. Hence he was designated ‘in many vestments’; cf. J. Rabbinowitz, Mishnah Megillah, p. 64.
(66) He being of lower sanctity, the duty of attending to a meth miẓwah devolves upon him.

(67) A kohen who acted as deputy of the High Priest when disqualified by uncleanness to officiate. When the High Priest returned to duty, the deputy did not revert to the rank of ordinary priest but retained the status of a High Priest with all the privileges of that office with two exceptions (cf. Meg. I, 9, Sonc. ed., p. 51). He was known as kohen she‘abar. See J. Rabbinowitz, Mishnah Megillah, p. 65.
(68) Superintendent of the Temple Service, identified with the Segan, the deputy High Priest; cf. Sanh. 19a (Sonc. ed., p. 97, n. 1).
(69) A priest appointed to accompany the army into battle (Deut. XX, 2; cf. Soṭah VIII, 1, Sonc. ed., p. 207).
(70) Because the law against defilement exempts him in other contingencies (Lev. XXI, 2f).
(71) Because the Levite is under no restriction in this matter.
(72) Since the Levite would be precluded from attending to his duties in the Temple for a period.
(73) To interfere as little as possible with agriculture (B.Ḳ. 81b, Sonc. ed., pp. 463f).
(74) Kerem is the reading of GRA and H in agreement with j.Nazir VII, 1, 56b.
(75) So H; V incorrectly ‘and if they are not alike’.
(76) H in conformity with j.Nazir VII, 1, 56a reads tashmishi.
(77) A Sabbath-limit is two thousand cubits.
(78) He should have buried the corpse on the spot; B.Ḳ. 81a (Sonc. ed., p. 459).
(79) The next sentence is translated from the text of j.Nazir loc. cit., and the last word of the chapter is again changed to tashmishi. The text of V is in disorder.

chapter.title: CHAPTER V
chapter.p: RULE 1. A mourner is forbidden to do work1 throughout the seven days2 [of mourning], he, his sons and daughters,3 his male and female slaves and his cattle; and as he4 is forbidden to do work, so too others are forbidden to do work for him.

RULE 2. They may do work for him in connection with perishable things; they may gather his harvest for him, operate his wine-press for him and bung5 his casks. If his olives had been turned,6 R. Judah says that he may put on the first7 beam and after his mourning he completes the work. R. Jose said to him, ‘But they are perishable things! He may complete [the whole operation in his mourning]’.

RULE 3. With regard to his flax [which is ready] for lifting from the retting and his wool [ready] for lifting from the dye-bath, if there are others [to do the work] they should lift it,8 but if not he may lift it in private.9

RULE 4. If his cask [of wine] is [ready] for bunging, R. Judah says that they cover it with shingles10 and after the mourning he completes [the work]. R. Jose said to him, ‘But it is perishable ! He11 may complete [the whole operation in his mourning]’.

RULE 5. They may besprinkle his white field12 but may not13 sow it; they may sow for him a strip [of field] for a crop of flax when his turn for watering rights comes, according to R. Eliezer; but the Sages said: If he had not already sown it with flax, he should sow it with another kind [of crops], and if he does not sow it that week, he can sow it the following week.14
RULE 6. If he is a baker in the town and there is no other, he may do the work in private out of respect15 for the public.

RULE 7. R. Simeon b. Yoḥai16 said: If he is a hair-dresser or a bath-attendant in the service of the public, and a Festival is close at hand, he may do the work in private out of respect for the public.

RULE 8. If he is engaged in cutting a person’s hair and people come and tell him, ‘Your father is dead’, he should complete the work; this applies whether he is the hair-dresser or he is having his hair dressed. Workmen who have undertaken to do work for a mourner are forbidden to do it in his house but may do it in their own. R. Simeon b. Yoḥai17 said: A workman hired by the day is forbidden18 to do work in either [place]; a workman on a contract basis19 is forbidden [to do it in the mourner’s] house, but may do it in his own home. If it is work in connection with objects attached to the ground, it is forbidden [to do the work in either place];20 in another town it is permitted in either case.21

RULE 9. A mourner overtaken by his days of mourning22 may ease [his hair] with a shearing-knife or a clipping-tool,23 but not with a scissors; and if his clothes are soiled he may wash them in cold water but not in urine.24

RULE 10. A mourner and an excommunicated person who are travelling on the road are permitted to wear their shoes, but as soon as they reach a city they must remove them. The same rule applies [to everybody] on the Ninth of Ab25 and on a public fast day.26

RULE 11. An excommunicated person who died has to be ‘stoned’27—not that they place a high heap of stones upon him, as in the case of Achan28—but the messenger of the Beth Din takes a stone and places it on the coffin in order to fulfil the duty of ‘stoning’ in his case.29

RULE 12. An excommunicated person may not read a passage of Scripture to others nor may others read it to him; he may not teach nor may others teach him; but he may read Scripture and study for himself so as not to forget his learning.30
RULE 13. He may be hired to work and others may hire themselves to him for work; not for his profit, but in order not to close the door before him.31

RULE 14. One who is placed under excommunication by his city is not32 considered to be under it in another city; [46a] one under the ban to the disciples is not under the ban to the Sages; one under the ban to the Sages is under the ban to the disciples; one under the ban to all the people is not under the ban to the Nasi’;33 one under the ban to the Nasi’ is under the ban to all the people.
RULE 15. If one of those who had placed a person under the ban dies, should he have given authority to his colleagues [to annul the ban], they free him, otherwise they do not.34
RULE 16.35 No ban holds for less than thirty days, and no ‘reproof’36 for less than seven days.
RULE 17. Rabban Gamaliel said: Any one against whom the Sages pronounce excommunication,37 even if they later received him back, does not leave the world in peace.38
chapter.ftnote: (1) Cf. M.Ḳ. 15b (Sonc. ed., p. 92) where by an interpretation of Amos VIII, 10 and by the process of analogy this rule is arrived at.
(2) Cf. ibid. 21b (Sonc. ed., p. 135) where the reading is ‘the first three days’. See, however, Tosafoth ad loc., s.v. mikk’an, where it is explained that this refers only to a very poor man.
(3) If they reside with him and are dependent upon him (Nachmanides).
(4) The reading of GRA and H.
(5) Reading gafin with H.
(6) For maturing before pressing or milling.
(7) i.e. press them once.
(8) GRA reads ’otho for V’s ‘immo.
(9) M.Ḳ. 11b (Sonc. ed., p. 63). ‘In private’ means behind closed doors.
(10) To prevent the wine from turning sour.
(11) So GRA for V’s ‘they’.
(12) i.e. a bright, shadeless vegetable or grain field, the opposite of an orchard (Jastrow).

(13) H reads שלו for שלא, ‘his white field in order to sow it’. GRA emends: ‘but do not sow; and they may sow a field of flax for him in his turn for watering rights, according to R. Judah’, reading (so also H) רביעה for רביעית. Farmers took turns in drawing on the water-supply.

(14) GRA reads: ‘if he cannot sow it on this watering turn, he can sow it on the next’. The Sages differ from R. Eliezer on both points, viz. they forbid the sprinkling of a white field and sowing flax during the mourning.
(15) GRA reads צורך, ‘needs’ instead of כבוד, ‘respect of’.
(16) GRA reads ‘Gamaliel’ in agreement with M.Ḳ., loc. cit.
(17) GRA reads ‘Eleazar’.
(18) Because he has the right to repudiate his bargain at any time.
(19) i.e. a piece-worker.
(20) Because it is generally known that they are working for the mourner.
(21) It is not generally so known.
(22) i.e. he suffered one bereavement immediately after another.
(23) GRA reads ‘or with a razor’ in accordance with M.Ḳ. 17b (Sonc. ed., p. 112). These instruments remove only a little of the hair and are not usually employed for hair-cutting.
(24) Used as a bleaching agent.
(25) The day of mourning for the destruction of the Temple when every Jew has to regard himself as a mourner.
(26) Proclaimed in a time of drought.
(27) Cf. M.Ḳ. 15a (Sonc. ed., p. 88).
(28) Cf. Josh. VII, 26.
(29) Cf. M.Ḳ. loc. cit., and ‘Eduy. V, 6 (Sonc. ed., p. 35) in the case of Eliezer b. Ḥanok.
(30) Cf. M.Ḳ. 15a (Sonc. ed., p. 90).
(31) ‘Not’ is added by GRA and H; i.e. to encourage him to amend his ways to enable him to live.
(32) GRA and H insert ‘not’.
(33) The President of the Grand Sanhedrin.
(34) Cf. M.Ḳ. 16a (Sonc. ed., p. 99).
(35) ibid.
(36) As in the case of Miriam (Num. XII, 14f). ‘Reproof’ is a sharp reprimand; e.g. ‘How impudent is that fellow!’, cf. M.Ḳ. 16b (Sonc. ed., p. 102).
(37) lit. ‘stretch forth’; GRA and H insert ‘hand’ after the verb.
(38) Cf. ibid. 17b (Sonc. ed., p. 110), ‘Whenever the Sages set their eyes against one [the result was] either death or poverty’.

chapter.title: CHAPTER VI
chapter.p: RULE 1.1 A mourner is forbidden to read the Pentateuch, Prophets and Hagiographa;2 he is also forbidden to study Mishnah, Talmud, halakoth and ’aggadoth. He is under the prohibition to bathe, anoint [the body], put on sandals3 and cohabit. He is obliged to cover his head and overturn his couch.4

It is related of Rabban Gamaliel5 that when his wife died he bathed on the first night. His disciples said to him, ‘Master, have you not taught us that a mourner is forbidden to bathe?’ He replied, ‘I am not like other men, I am delicate’.

RULE 2.6 If people greet him, he should say to them, ‘I am a mourner’. On the first day and on the second day he should say to them, ‘I am a mourner’, but on the third day he may return their salutation in a low voice, although he may not greet them.7

RULE 3. On the first day he does not put on the tefillin;8 on the second day he puts them on and if people come to comfort him he takes them off, according to the view of R. Eliezer. R. Joshua said: On the first and second day he does not put on the tefillin;8 on the third day he puts them on and if people come to comfort him he takes them off.9

RULE 4. If [another] death took place in that city, on the first and second day [of his own mourning] he does not go out with [the other mourners],10 but on the third day he goes out with them and stands in the line to receive condolence but not to offer comfort to the others. This only holds good when there are sufficient people to carry the bier and do the burial, but if there are not sufficient he goes out with them even on the first day.11

RULE 5. If he came from another district to his relatives, on the second and third day he completes [the days of his mourning] with them, but from the fourth day he counts [the remaining period of mourning] on his own.12 R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: If he found them still sitting [as mourners] even if it is the seventh day13 he completes [the period] with them; and if he did not find them sitting [as mourners] even if it be the second day he counts on his own.
RULE 6. On the first and second day, he may not do work even if he is in receipt of charity.14 On the third day he may15 work but in private.

RULE 7.16 He may not work in a field adjoining the city or the road, but he may work privately in his own garden. Likewise a woman may not work on top of the roof or within the courtyard, but she may work privately in her house so long as she is not overlooked by her neighbours.17
RULE 8. [The period of] three days applies to a dog which devoured [some of] the flesh of a corpse and entered a house. If this happened after three days the house is clean, if less it is unclean.18
RULE 9. [The period of] three days19 applies to any of the five species20 [of grain] sown; [if three days] before Passover it is permitted [to be eaten], if less than this it is prohibited.21
RULE 10. One should not go out with a caravan less than three days before the Sabbath.
One may not go out to war,22 if it is of a voluntary nature,23 less than three days before the Sabbath. One may not set out on a ship less than three days before the Sabbath.24

RULE 11. On the first and second day [of mourning] he may not enter the Temple Mount; on the third day he may enter but must go round to the left.25 These are they who must go round to the left: a mourner, an excommunicated person, one who has a sick person in his house, and one who lost an object. [When asked,] ‘Why do you26 go round to the left?’ [he answers,] ‘Because I am a mourner’. They reply, ‘May He Who dwells in this House comfort you’. [If he says,] ‘Because I am under a ban’, [they reply,] ‘May He Who dwells in this House put it into their heart to draw you near’; so said R. Meir. R. Jose said to him, ‘You make out as if they [who banned] passed a wrong judgment on him; but [what they say is,] “May He Who dwells in this house put it into your heart to hearken to the words of your colleagues so that they may draw you near” ’. To one who has a sick person in his house they say, ‘May He Who dwells in this House have mercy upon him’; and if he is barely living27 [they say,] ‘May He have mercy upon him immediately’. It is related of a certain woman whose daughter was ill that she ascended the Temple Mount and went round it, and did not move from there until they came and told her, ‘She is cured’.

To one who lost some object they say, ‘May He Who dwells in this House put it into the heart of the finder to return it to you at once’. It is related of Eleazar b. Ḥananiah b. Hezekiah b. Gorion that he lost a scroll of the Torah which he had bought for one hundred minas. He ascended [the Temple Mount], went round it and did not move from there until they came and told him, ‘The scroll of the Torah has been found’.

RULE 12. From the beginning Solomon built the Temple only on condition that anyone in trouble would come there and pray; as it is stated, If there be in the land famine, if there be pestilence, if there be blasting or mildew, locust or caterpillar; if their enemy besiege them in the land of their cities; whatsoever plague, whatsoever sickness there be; what prayer and supplication soever be made by any man.28 I have here only the case of an individual; whence do we know that it also holds good of a community? The text continues, Of all Thy people Israel. Whence do we know that it holds good of the non-Jew? The text states, Moreover concerning the stranger that is not of Thy people Israel.29 From the words be made by any man you might think that it holds good of one who wants children or possessions which will not be for his welfare; hence Scripture states, For Thou, even Thou only, knowest the hearts of all the children of men30—what is good for him do Thou give to him. And whence do we know that this holds good only if they do not continue in their rebellion? As it is stated, Who shall know every man the plague of his own heart, and spread forth his hands toward this house.31
chapter.ftnote: (1) For a full discussion of what is prohibited to a mourner, cf. M.Ḳ. 15a, b and 21a, b (Sonc. ed., pp. 90ff, 133ff). The law is based on Ezek. XXIV, 17, 23 where the prophet is warned not to observe the usual rites of mourning.
(2) Because the study of the Torah is a joy.
(3) These and covering the head are signs of mourning; cf. 2 Sam. XV, 30, Jer. XIV, 3f, Esth. VI, 12.

(4) Cf. M.Ḳ. 15a, b (Sonc. ed., p. 92): God says, ‘I have set the likeness of Mine image on them and through their sins have I upset it; let your couches be overturned on account thereof’. According to A. Marmorstein the rite served the purpose of warning the mourners against sexual intercourse which is forbidden in the days of mourning; cf. j.Ber. III, 1, 6a.
(5) Cf. Ber. 16b (Sonc. ed., p. 96).
(6) From this point V does not divide the chapters into Rules and the division of H is adopted.
(7) Cf. M.Ḳ. 21b (Sonc. ed., p. 135). The reading of GRA is: ‘On the first, second and third days, he says to them, “I am a mourner”, but from the fourth day onwards he returns their salutation’.
(8) ibid. 21a (Sonc. ed., p. 134). GRA transposes the names of the two Rabbis in agreement with the Talmud.
(9) GRA reads: ‘he does not take them off’; H adds at the end ‘all the seven days’.
(10) To the cemetery to attend the funeral.
(12) ibid. (Sonc. ed., p. 138). So GRA; V reads ‘on the fourth and fifth’.
(13) So GRA according to M.Ḳ. loc. cit. V wrongly ‘third day’.
(14) Heb. תמחוי, the daily distribution of food to the poor supplied by contributors.
(15) GRA omits ‘go out and’ which is in V.
(16) H inserts ‘on the first and second day’.

(18) Ohol. XI, 7 (Sonc. ed., p. 198), Shab. 155b (Sonc. ed., p. 796). Three days is deemed to be sufficient time for the dog to have digested the flesh of the corpse, and therefore there is no longer a question of uncleanness being conveyed by the dog into the house. This and the other extraneous matter which follows is introduced here because of the ‘three days’ which is the time factor.

(19) Cf. Ḥallah I, 1f (Sonc. ed., pp. 317f), Men. 70a (Sonc. ed., p. 414). Grain sown three days before Passover is deemed to have taken root. Hence the Omer brought on Passover renders them permissible to be eaten any time after Passover. But if sown less than three days, it is no longer considered the present year’s produce when it ripens and may not be eaten until the Omer of the following year is brought.
(20) Wheat, barley, rye, oats and spelt.
(21) The last clause is added by GRA.
(22) Cf. Tosiftha ‘Erub. IV, 7, Shab. 19a (Sonc. ed., p. 79). The translation follows H’s reading, יוצאין, V has מוציאין which means ‘we do not lead [troops] out’.
(23) i.e. a war of conquest, the opposite of ‘a war of obligation’, viz. a war commanded to Israel by God.
(24) Cf. Shab. loc. cit.
(25) Since he is forbidden to bring an offering (Deut. XXVI, 14); cf. Mid. II, 2 (Sonc. ed. p. 6).
(26) Reading with GRA and H מה לך for V’s מהלך.
(27) lit. ‘son of existence’, far gone in his illness.
(28) 1 Kings VIII, 37f.

chapter.title: CHAPTER VII
chapter.p: RULE 1. The Sabbath enters into the number of the days of mourning1 but does not interrupt;2 Festivals interrupt3 but do not enter into the number.4 R. Eliezer said: Since the destruction of the Temple, ‘Aẓereth5 is reckoned as the Sabbath [during the period of mourning]. Rabban Gamaliel6 said: New Year and the Day of Atonement are [in this respect] like the Festivals; but the Sages say: The rule is according to the view of neither, but ‘Aẓereth is like the Festivals and the New Year and Day of Atonement are like the Sabbath.

RULE 2. If a man suffered a bereavement one day before a Festival, he interrupts [his mourning] throughout the Festival and counts six days [of mourning] after the Festival; if three days before the Festival he does not need to overturn his couch7 [after the Festival] according to R. Eliezer;8 but the Sages said: Even one day, or even one hour [before the Festival]. R. Eliezer b. R. Simeon said: These are the very words of Beth Shammai, and also the very words of Beth Hillel; because Beth Shammai said, ‘Three days before a Festival’ and Beth Hillel said, ‘Even one day and even one hour’. [46b]

RULE 3. Abba Saul said: If one buried his dead three days before a Festival, the restrictions9 appertaining to the seven days’ mourning cease to apply to him; if eight days before a Festival, the restrictions of the thirty days cease to apply10 (and the ruling is in accordance with this statement).11

RULE 4. [Should the death occur] eight days before a Festival, if he wishes to cut his hair or wash his clothes on the eve of the Festival he may do so; if he did not cut his hair or wash his clothes on the eve of the Festival, he may not do so until the thirty days are completed.

RULE 5. [If the death occurs] two days within the Festival,12 he interrupts [the mourning] for all the Festival and counts seven [days] after it, and people occupy themselves13 with him for the five days after the Festival. [If the death occurs] seven days within the Festival, he interrupts [the mourning] for all the Festival and counts [seven days] after the Festival, and the community do not occupy themselves with him at all after the Festival.14
RULE 6. On the days which he counts after a Festival, neither his slave nor his cattle need abstain from work; only he and his near kin conduct themselves like mourners.

RULE 7. A Festival is reckoned for the mourner into the count of the thirty [days]15 but not into the count of the seven [days]. A mourner is regarded on a Festival as if he were no mourner, but in matters of a private nature he does observe mourning. The general rule is: as regards any [mourning rite] in the carrying out of which others are associated with him,16 a Festival is taken into account with the seven days,17 otherwise it is not taken into account with them.

RULE 8. Thirty are the days of mourning.18 For thirty days he may not put on pressed clothes19 or cut his hair. Thirty days are allowed for the collection of debts; thirty days must elapse before a captive woman of ‘goodly form’20 may be taken to wife; thirty days in the case of betrothal; thirty days in the case of marriage; thirty days within which a charge of lack of virginity can be made; thirty days are granted to a widow about to remarry to make her preparations; thirty days for a sister-in-law [after her levirate marriage to declare, ‘He has not cohabited with me’]. If a man forbade his wife by vow to have any benefit from him [the prohibition lasts] thirty days. The vow of a Nazirite of unspecified duration [remains in force] for thirty days.
RULE 9. Whence [thirty days] for mourning? As it is stated, And the children of Israel wept for Moses in the plains of Moab thirty days.21

RULE 10. How is it with pressed clothes? It is forbidden [for a mourner] to don pressed clothes, i.e. those that came from the press.22 This is the view of Rabbi [Judah the Prince]; the Sages said: [It refers] to dyed but not white garments. R. Meir said: White but not dyed, new but not worn garments. He may put on his money-belt,23 girdle,24 felt-shoes25 and turban.26 It is permitted to take garments to be pressed within thirty days.27

RULE 11. How is it with cutting the hair? [A mourner] is forbidden to remove the hair whether of the head or of his [upper] lip, or of the beard or of the hair on any part of him. A woman is permitted to remove hair28 after the seven days.
RULE 12. How is it with the collection of debts?29 If a person lends his friend money without specifying a date [for repayment], he may not demand it of him until thirty days are completed.

RULE 13. How is it with a woman of ‘goodly form’? [It is stated,] And thou hast a desire unto her, and wouldest take her to thee to wife; then thou shalt bring her home to thy house; and she shall shave her head, and pare her nails.30 [This means that] she shall shave her head and cut her nails, so the view of R. Eliezer;31 R. ‘Aḳiba [takes the meaning to be,] she lets the hair of her head grow long and lets her nails grow. R. Eliezer said: An act is mentioned in respect of the head32 and an act is mentioned in respect of her nails;33 as the former signifies removal of the hair so the latter signifies removal of the nails. R. ‘Aḳiba said: An act is mentioned in respect of the head and an act is mentioned in respect of the nails; as disfigurement is the purpose of the former so is disfigurement the purpose of the latter. There is a support for R. Eliezer [in the verse], And Mephibosheth the son of Saul came down to meet the king; and he had neither dressed his feet, nor trimmed his beard.34 There is a support for R. ‘Aḳiba [in the verse], Till his hair was grown like eagles’ feathers, and his nails like birds’ claws.35

And she shall put the raiment of her captivity from off her.36 If she wore white garments and they were comely for her, black garments and they were comely for her,37 bracelets, nose-rings or rings, they are taken away from her so that she should sit and appear in her disfigurement. And she shall remain in thy house:38 so that while she remains in his house he enters and sees her in her disfigurement. And bewail her father and her mother:39 this means her actual father and mother, in the view of R. Eliezer; but R. ‘Aḳiba explains that her father and her mother refers to the idols [which she worshipped], as it is stated, Who say to a stock: ‘Thou art my father’, and to a stone: ‘Thou hast brought us forth’.40

A month of days41—i.e. thirty days. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: [It means] three months, as it is stated, And bewail her father and her mother a month, i.e. one month, of days signifies [with the former] two months, and after that [is added in the text] to include the third month, [the purpose being] that the holy seed shall not be mingled with that of other peoples. When does this apply? Only if she does not wish to become a proselyte; but if she is willing to become a proselyte, he has her immersed [in the ritual bath] and emancipates her, and is permitted to marry her forthwith. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: Even if she is not willing42 at first, he has her immersed as a handmaid, emancipates her and may marry her forthwith. Why all this [procedure]? In order that the holy seed should not be mingled with that of other peoples.43 It is better for Israelites to eat the flesh of animals about to die, yet ritually slaughtered, than the flesh of dying animals which definitely perished.44
RULE 14. How is it with betrothal? It is forbidden to hold a betrothal feast within the thirty days [of mourning].45

RULE 15. How is it with marriage? It is forbidden to hold a marriage feast within the thirty days [of mourning], but if his meat is prepared46 and his father or mother-in-law47 died, he brings the bride into the bridal chamber, performs the act of consummation and then separates himself from her [until] after the seven days.48 When does this apply? Only if his father or mother-in-law died; but if his wife died, he is forbidden to remarry until three Festivals have gone by. R. Judah said: Until two Festivals have gone by, and he brings [her into the marital chamber] on the third. When does this apply? Only if he has children, but if he has no children or his children are young, it is permitted for him to remarry within thirty days.49 It happened that R. Ṭarfon’s wife died, and he said to her sister within the days of mourning, ‘Be my wife and bring up your sister’s children’. Nevertheless he did not cohabit with her until after the thirty days.
RULE 16. How is it with virginity? Within thirty days he may make a plea of the absence of virginity,50 but after thirty days he cannot.

RULE 17. How is it with a widow?51 If the man [to whom she is betrothed] claims her [in marriage] and she holds back, we allow her thirty days to make provision for herself; and as we allow [that period] to the woman, so too we allow it to the man.52

RULE 18. How is it with a sister-in-law?53 If a sister-in-law declared within thirty days [after the levirate marriage], ‘I have had no cohabitation’,54 [the levir] is compelled to give her ḥaliẓah, but [if her declaration was made] after thirty days, he is not compelled55 to give her ḥaliẓah.

RULE 19.56 Should a man forbid his wife by vow to have any benefit from him, [if the prohibition is to last] not more than thirty days he must appoint a steward,57 but if for a longer period he must divorce her and give her [the amount stipulated in] her kethubah.58

RULE 20. [How is it with a Nazirite whose vow is of unspecified duration?]59 The vow of a Nazirite which is of unspecified duration [remains in force] thirty days.60 Whether he declared, ‘Behold I am a Nazirite’ without qualification, or he declared, ‘Behold I am a Nazirite for one day’, his status as a Nazirite lasts thirty days.61 If he completed his period as a Nazirite outside the land of Israel62 and later returned there, [47a] Beth Shammai said that he remains a Nazirite for thirty days, and Beth Hillel said that he [reverts to the] beginning of his status as a Nazirite.63

RULE 21. One who resides in the land of Israel thirty days is under the obligation to affix a mezuzah, and he who rents a house must do so forthwith;64 but he who resides outside the land of Israel is exempt. One who rents a house for thirty days65 and one who resides in an isolated place66 for thirty days is under the obligation to affix a mezuzah.

RULE 22. If one buys newly born cattle from his neighbour, [he may retain the dam] to suckle them, in the case of small cattle67 for thirty days and in the case of large cattle68 for fifty days. R. Jose said: In the case of small cattle for three months because they need much attention.69 As for attending to the first-born of cattle70 [before handing them over to the kohen], in the case of small cattle the period is thirty days and for large cattle fifty days. R. Jose said: In the case of small cattle the period is three months because they need much attention.

RULE 23. Beth Shammai71 declared an old Sukkah to be invalid; Beth Hillel pronounced it valid (but he must add something new to it).72 What is ‘an old Sukkah’? One which was made thirty days before the Festival [of Tabernacles]; but should he have made it for the purpose of [being used on] the Festival, even [if erected] at the beginning of the year, it is valid.

RULE 24.73 Rice, millet, panic and sesame which took root before the New Year are tithed74 as belonging to the previous year75 and are permitted in the seventh year;76 but if they did not [take root before the New Year] they are forbidden in the seventh year and are tithed as belonging to the next year.77 R. Simeon of Shezur said: Egyptian beans sown from the outset for the purpose of seeds78 are treated in a like manner. R. Simeon said: Large beans are treated in a like manner if they formed pods79 before the New Year. Shallots80 and Egyptian beans which have not been watered within thirty days of the New Year are treated as if a year had passed81 and may be retained in the seventh year; otherwise they are not considered as such and may not be retained in the seventh year.

RULE 25.82 If one plants, bends over83 or grafts a tree within thirty days of the New Year, a year has passed for him [by the New Year]84 and he may preserve the growth during the seventh year; otherwise a year has not passed for him and he may not preserve the growth in the seventh year. R. Judah said: Any grafting which does not take root within three days will never do so. R. Simeon and R. Jose said: Any grafting which does not take root within two weeks is no grafting. The fruit of such a planting is forbidden until the fifteenth of Shebaṭ.85

chapter.title: CHAPTER VIII
chapter.p: RULE 1. We go out to the cemetery and examine1 the dead within three days and do not fear [being suspected of] superstitious practices.2 It once happened that [a man who was buried] was examined [and found to be living], and he lived for twenty-five years and then died. Another3 [so examined lived and] begat five children before he died.

RULE 2. We erect a canopy4 for bridegrooms and brides [who died before marriage] and suspend from it articles which have and have not reached the edible stage; this is the opinion of R. Meir. R. Judah5 said: We only suspend from it articles which have not reached the edible stage.6 These are what are suspended from it: Nuts which have not reached the edible stage,7 loaves of bread which are not edible,8 strips of purple wool, flasks of perfumed oil. And these are the articles which may not be suspended from it: Nuts which have reached the edible stage, pomegranates which have reached the edible stage, loaves of bread which are edible, and flasks of sweet oil. The general rule is: no benefit may be derived from anything that is suspended from the canopy.

RULE 3. We scatter before bridegrooms and brides strings of fish9 and pieces of meat in summer but not in winter; but not pieces of cooked fish, mushrooms, truffles or sesame both in summer and winter; but one takes roasted ears of corn and nuts and throws them. The general rule is: we may not scatter before them anything that is perishable.

RULE 4. We may let wine and oil flow through pipes10 before bridegrooms and brides and we do not fear [being suspected of] superstitious practices; nor do we fear of sinning by putting food to shame.11 It is related that Judah and Hillel, the sons of Rabban Gamaliel, came to Ben Zakkai at Kabul12 and the citizens let wine and oil flow through pipes [in their honour].

RULE 5. We may burn [articles]13 at the funerals of kings and mutilate [their animals], and we do not fear [being suspected of] superstitious practices. Any mutilation which disqualifies the animal as food makes it forbidden to be eaten, but benefit may be derived from it; and when the mutilation does not disqualify the animal it may be eaten and obviously benefit may be derived from it. Which mutilation disqualifies it? From the knee downwards.14

RULE 6. We may burn articles at the funeral of kings but not at the funeral of princes.15 When Rabban Gamaliel the Elder died, the proselyte Onḳelos burnt after him more than eighty Tyrian minas. They asked him, ‘What was your purpose in doing this?’ He replied, ‘It is written, Thou16 shalt die in peace; and with the burnings of thy fathers, the former kings that were before thee, so shall they make a burning for thee.17 And is not Rabban Gamaliel worth more than a hundred useless kings?’
RULE 7. We cover the hair of [dead] brides, uncover the face of [dead] bridegrooms,18 and place ink and pen at their side,19 and we do not fear [being suspected of] superstitious practices.

20(When Rabban Gamaliel the Elder entered [the meeting place of the Rabbis to intercalate the year], he found eight [present]. He asked, ‘Who is it that entered without permission?’ Samuel the Small arose and said, ‘Rabbi, I entered only to inquire about the law [of intercalation]’.21 He answered, ‘O Eldad and Medad,22 all Israel know that if I had ordered that only two should enter, you would have been one [of them] to enter’.)23

We suspend the key and writing-tablet of a dead man from his coffin from grief of soul. When Samuel the Small died, they suspended his key and writing-tablet from his coffin because he had no son, and when Rabban Gamaliel the Elder and R. Eleazar delivered their funeral orations over him, they exclaimed, ‘For this one it is fitting to weep, for this one it is fitting to mourn. When kings die they leave their crowns to their sons; when wealthy men die they leave their riches to their children; but Samuel the Small has taken away with him all the desirable things in the world and has departed’. And thus he24 spoke at the time of his death, ‘Simeon [b. Gamaliel] and Ishmael [the son of Elisha the High Priest]25 are destined for the sword and the rest of the people for spoliation; great distress will befall [Israel] after them’. He uttered these words in Aramaic.

RULE 8.26 When R. Simeon b. Gamaliel and R. Ishmael came [to be tried], it was decreed against them that they should be put to death. Whereupon R. Ishmael broke into tears; and R. Simeon said to him, ‘Abrek,27 why do you weep? Two steps more28 and you will be in the bosom of the righteous, and yet you weep!’ He replied, ‘Do I then weep because we are about to be executed? It is because we are about to be executed [in the same way] as murderers and desecrators of the Sabbath’. He said to him, ‘Perhaps you were having a meal or you were sleeping when a woman came to ask [a ruling] concerning her ritual impurity or her cleanness, and your servant told her that you were asleep. And the Torah states, Ye shall not aflict29 any widow or fatherless child. If thou afflict them in any wise—for if they cry at all unto Me, I will surely hear their cry.30 And what is written after this? My wrath shall wax hot, and I will kill you with the sword’. Some say that it was [47b] R. Simeon b. Gamaliel who was weeping and R. Ishmael who answered him in these words.

When R. Simeon and R. Ishmael were executed and the report reached R. ‘Aḳiba and R. Judah b. Baba, they arose, girded their loins with sackcloth, rent their garments and exclaimed, ‘Our brother-Israelites, if good were destined to come to the world, at first none would receive it but R. Simeon and R. Ishmael; but now that it is revealed before Him Who spake and the universe came into being that eventually great punishments will come upon the world, they have consequently been taken out of the world; [as it is stated,] The righteous perisheth, and no man layeth it to heart,31 and it continues, He entereth into peace, they rest in their beds’.32

RULE 9. When R. ‘Aḳiba was executed in Caesarea and the news reached R. Judah b. Baba and R. Ḥanina b. Teradion, they arose, girded themselves in sackcloth, rent their garments and exclaimed, ‘Our brethren, hearken unto us! R. ‘Aḳiba was not executed for robbery or because he did not labour in the Torah with all his strength. He has only been put to death as a sign,33 as it is stated, Thus shall Ezekiel be unto you a sign; according to all that he hath done shall ye do; when this cometh, then shall ye know that I am the Lord God.34 Within a short while there will be no place found in the land of Israel where no [slain] will be cast forth, as it is stated, Speak: Thus saith the Lord—And the carcasses of men fall as dung upon the open field, and as the handful after the harvestman, which none gathereth’.35 It is reported that it was not long before war came and disturbed the world, and within twelve months the municipalities36 in Judea ceased; as it is stated, Tremble, ye women that are at ease; be troubled, ye confident ones:37 Ye women that are at ease refers to the municipalities in Judea, ye confident ones refers to the fortified towns.38 Confident ones is nothing else than a term for walled cities.39 It is reported that twelve months had not passed before what had been said was fulfilled.

RULE 10. R. Meir illustrated it by a parable. To what is the matter like? To a king who prepared a banquet and invited guests without fixing a time when they should leave. The shrewd among them left at the ninth hour,40 returned home and went to bed while it was still light; others left at sunset while the shops were still open and the lamps burning, entered their homes and went to bed by the light of the lamps; still others left at two or three hours in the night when some shops were open and some shut, some with their lamps alight and some with their lamps extinguished, entered their homes and went to bed in the dark. Those remaining at the banquet became intoxicated, and wounded and killed each other; as it is stated, I saw the Lord standing beside the altar; and He said: Smite the capitals, that the posts may shake; and break them in pieces on the head of all of them; and I will slay the residue of them with the sword.41

RULE 11. When R. Ḥanina b. Teradion was arrested42 on the charge of heresy,43 [the Romans] sentenced him to be burnt, his wife to be executed and his daughter to be consigned to a brothel. He asked, ‘What have they decreed against that poor woman?’ They replied, ‘She is to be executed’. Thereupon he recited of her the verse, The Lord is righteous in all his ways.44 She asked, ‘What have they decreed against the Rabbi?’ They replied, ‘He is to be burnt’. Thereupon she recited of him the verse, Great in counsel, and mighty in work.45

When they burnt him, they wrapped him in a scroll of the Torah and burnt him. His daughter wept, wailed and threw herself before him. Whereupon he exclaimed, ‘My daughter, if for me you weep, if for me you throw yourself down, it were better that a fire which [a man] has fanned should consume me and not one which [a man] has not fanned;46 as it is stated, A fire not blown by man shall consume him.47 If, however, you threw yourself down because of the scroll of the Torah, behold, the letters are flying upwards and only parchment is being consumed. For even great servants of the king are punished by inferior servants, [as it is stated,] Therefore have I hewed them by the prophets, I have slain them by the words of My mouth’.48

RULE 12.49 R. ‘Aḳiba said: A king had four sons. One was silent when punished, another protested when punished, another begged for mercy when punished, and another when punished said to his father, ‘Go on punishing me’. Abraham remained silent when punished, as it is stated, Take now thy son, thine only son, whom thou lovest, even Isaac … and offer him there for a burnt-offering.50 He could have argued, ‘Yesterday You said to me, For in Isaac shall seed be called to thee!’51 Then it is stated, And Abraham rose early in the morning.52 Job protested when punished, as it is stated, I will say unto God: Do not condemn me; make me know wherefore Thou contendest with me.53 Hezekiah besought God for mercy when punished, as it is stated, Then he turned his face to the wall, and prayed unto the Lord, saying,54 etc. Some say that Hezekiah protested when he was punished since he later added, And have done that which is good in Thy sight.55 David [when punished] said to his Father, ‘Continue to punish me’, as it is stated, Wash me thoroughly from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin.56

RULE 13. We do not interrupt the study of the Torah until the soul departs from the dying man.57 When R. Simeon, the son of R. ‘Aḳiba, fell ill, the latter did not interrupt his expositions in the Academy but made inquiries after him through a messenger. The first messenger came and reported, ‘He is very ill’. He said to [his disciples], ‘Continue to ask questions’. Then a second came and reported, ‘He has grown worse’. R. ‘Aḳiba resumed the study of the Torah. A third came and reported, ‘He is dying’, and he said [to his disciples, ‘Continue] to ask questions’. A fourth came and reported, ‘He is dead’.58 Whereupon he arose, removed the tefillin,59 rent his garments and said to them, ‘Our brother-Israelites, hearken! Until now we had the duty to study the Torah; but from now onward we have the duty to occupy ourselves with honouring the dead’.

A large assembly gathered to bury R. ‘Aḳiba’s son, and he said to them, ‘Bring a bench60 for me to the cemetery’. He stood61 upon it and expounded, ‘Our brother-Israelites, hearken! Not because I am a scholar [have you come here], there being greater scholars here than I; not because I am a rich man [have you come here], there being richer men here than I; the men of the Darom62 know R. ‘Aḳiba, but how should the men of Galilee know him?63 Men know him, but how should women and young children? I know, however, that your reward is great because you have only taken the great trouble to come here for the honour of the Torah and for the sake of the commandment [to attend the dead to the grave]. I should be comforted though I had seven sons whom I [now] buried. Not that a man desires to bury his children, but I know that my son is destined for the World to Come because he caused the many to be righteous, and64 whoever causes the many to be righteous, sin occurs not through him, and whoever causes the many to sin, they do not afford him the faculty to repent. Moses was righteous and caused the many to be righteous, [therefore] the righteousness of the many was [considered] dependent on him, as it is stated, He executed the righteousness of the Lord, and His ordinances with Israel.65 Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, sinned and caused others to sin, [therefore] the sin of the many was [considered] dependent on him, as it is stated, For the sins of Jeroboam which he sinned, and wherewith he made Israel to sin’.66

RULE 14. Further [R. ‘Aḳiba] sat on the bench [and taught]: Good things are brought about through the agency of good men.67 Even if Moses and Aaron had not arisen, Israel would still have been worthy to be redeemed from Egypt,68 as it is stated, And afterward shall they come out with great substance.69 Had not Moses and Aaron and the Generation of the Wilderness arisen, Israel would still have been worthy to receive the Torah, as it is stated, He layeth up sound wisdom for the upright.70 The section of ‘the judges’71 would have been worthy to be promulgated even if Jethro had not arisen. The section of ‘the smaller Passover’72 would have been worthy to be promulgated even if the ‘unclean’ had not arisen, as it is stated, We are unclean by the dead body of a man; wherefore are we to be kept back, so as not to bring the offering of the Lord in its appointed season among the children of Israel?73 The section of ‘inheritance’74 would have been worthy to be promulgated even if the daughters of Zelophehad75 had not arisen. The Temple would have been worthy to be built even if David and Solomon had not arisen, as it is stated, The sanctuary, O Lord, which Thy hands have established.76 Israel would have been worthy to be redeemed in the days of Haman even it Mordecai and Esther had not arisen, as it is stated, And yet for all that, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject them, neither will I abhor them, to destroy them utterly,77 etc.

Israel were destined to be enslaved even if Pharaoh had not arisen in Egypt, as it is stated, And [they] shall serve them; and they shall afflict them four hundred years.78 Israel were destined to serve idols even if Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, had not arisen, as it is stated, And this people will rise up, and go astray after the foreign gods of the land.79 The section of ‘the blasphemer’80 and of ‘the gatherer of sticks’81 would have been worthy to be promulgated even if the son of the Israelitish woman and the gatherer of sticks had not arisen. Israel would have been destined to be destroyed by the sword even if so and so82 had not arisen, as it is stated, All the sinners of My people shall die by the sword;83 and it declares, By sword and famine shall they be consumed.84 Israel would have deserved to be destroyed even if Nebuchadnezzar and his companions had not arisen, as it is stated, Therefore shall Zion for your sake be ploughed as a field, and Jerusalem shall become heaps, and the mountain of the house as the high places of a forest.85

RULE 15. And further [he expounded]: Reward is brought about through persons of merit and punishment through persons of guilt. 86When Trajan was about to execute Pappus and his brother Lulianus in Laodicea, he said to them, ‘If you are of the people of Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah, let your God come and deliver you from my hands, in the same way as He delivered Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah [from Nebuchadnezzar]’. They replied, ‘Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah were worthy men and Nebuchadnezzar was a worthy king, and it was fitting that a miracle should be wrought through their agency; but you are a wicked king and are not worthy that a miracle should be wrought through your agency. As for us, we deserve death at the hand of God, and if you do not slay us, the Omnipresent has many other agents of death; He has many demons, many bears, many leopards, many snakes, many venomous serpents, many scorpions which will come and attack us; but when we die you will learn that we are the descendants of Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah’. It is reported that before they died they witnessed his eyes gouged out.87

RULE 16. The allegorical interpreters88 of Scripture said: And ye shall break down their altars:89 wherein have the trees and the stones sinned?90 Because they were a stumbling-block to man Scripture decreed, And ye shall break down. This is an argument from minor to major: if with trees and stones, which are capable neither of merit nor guilt, neither of good nor evil, because they were a stumbling-block to man the Torah declared, And ye shall break down, how much more [will a man be punished] who causes his neighbour to sin and turns him away from the way of life to the path of death! Similarly, And if a woman approach unto any beast, and lie down thereto, thou shalt kill the woman, and the beast.91 If a human being sinned, how has the animal offended?92 Because evil came to a human being through it, and so that the animal shall not pass through the street and people say, ‘This is the animal on account of which So-and-so was stoned’. This is an argument from minor to major: if with an animal, which is capable neither of merit nor guilt, neither of good nor evil, because it was a stumbling-block to a human being the Torah declared, It shall be stoned, how much more [will a man be punished] who causes his neighbour to sin and turns him from the way of life to the path of death!

Similarly Scripture declares of the stones of the altar, Thou shalt lift up no iron tool upon them,93 and elsewhere it states, For if thou lift up thy tool upon it, thou hast profaned it.94 Wherein is iron different from all other metals to be unfit for [the building of] the altar? Because the sword is a symbol of curse and the altar an agent of atonement; so we remove the symbol of curse on account of the agent of atonement. This is an argument from minor to major: if with the stones of the altar which do not see and speak, eat or drink, because they make peace between Israel and their Father in heaven the Torah declared, Thou shalt lift no iron tool upon them, the children of the Torah,95 who are an atonement for the world, how much more [should they not lift an iron tool against each other!] Similarly Scripture declares, Thou shalt build the altar of the Lord thy God of unhewn stones96—stones that bring peace to the world. This is an argument from minor to major: if with stones which do not see or hear, speak or eat or drink, because they make peace between Israel and their Father in heaven they must be ‘whole’ [48a] before [the Holy One, blessed be He], how much more the children of the Torah, who are an atonement for the world, must be ‘whole’ before the Holy One, blessed be He!

chapter.title: CHAPTER IX
chapter.p: RULE 1. One does not rend [his garments] for the dead1 except for his teacher who taught him wisdom.2 R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: When a Sage dies, all present at his death rend [their garments] for him, but all those who are not present do not rend them.

RULE 2. For a Sage who died3 one bares the right [shoulder]; for an ’Ab Beth Din who died one bares the left [shoulder]; for a Nasi’ who died one bares both shoulders.4 It is related5 that when R. Eliezer died, R. ‘Aḳiba bared both shoulders and kept on beating his heart6 until the blood flowed, and he cried out, ‘My father, my father, the chariots of Israel and the horsemen thereof!’7

RULE 3.8 One does not bare [the shoulder] for the dead in general but only for his father and mother; and if they are not worthy,9 he does not rend even for his father and mother. It is related that when R. ‘Aḳiba’s father died, those present bared [the shoulder], but he did not.
RULE 4. For the dead in general one rends [the garments] with a knife,10 but for his father and mother he does not rend with a knife.11
RULE 5. For the dead in general one does not bare his chest, but for his father and mother he bares it.12

RULE 6. For the dead in general one does not divide13 the [upper] selvage-border [of his garment],14 but for his father and mother he does divide it. R. Judah said: Any rending [of a garment] which does not divide the selvage-border is mere make-believe. R. Judah said:15 Any initial rending must be [to the extent of] three fingers, while the extension may be as small as he cares.16 One only rends as far down as the region of the navel.17 In the case of children, others rend for them.18 One who rends [not as a relative but] from respect [for the dead] may stitch [the edges] forthwith. The rending of one’s undershirt is not indispensable.19 R. Benjamin said in the name of R. ‘Aḳiba: One must rend the undershirt.

RULE 7.20 For the dead in general one rends only the uppermost [garment], but for his father and mother he must rend [all] even though he be wearing a hundred. A woman only rends her uppermost [garment]. R. Judah said: A woman rends her undergarment, turns it front to back, and then rends the remaining [garments].21

RULE 8. For the dead generally one tacks22 the rent together after seven days, and [completely] restitches [the edges] after thirty; but for one’s father and mother one never restitches [the edges]. A woman tacks the rent together after seven [days] and restitches [the edges] after thirty. R. Judah said: A woman tacks the rent together immediately23 and restitches [the edges] after seven [days].24

RULE 9.25 For the dead generally one expedites26 the bier and does not occupy himself unduly with their affairs;27 but in the case of his father and mother, whoever greatly occupies himself with their affairs and does not expedite the bier is praiseworthy. But if time is pressing, or the Sabbath-eve is approaching, or rain falls, he may expedite the bier for his father and mother and does not unduly occupy himself with their affairs.

RULE 10. For the dead in general it is forbidden to wear pressed clothes until thirty days [are completed], but in the case of his father and mother it is forbidden until the [next] Festival occurs and then only if his companions rebuke him.28

RULE 11.29 For the dead generally it is forbidden to trim one’s hair until thirty days are completed; but in the case of his father and mother, one lets the hair grow long until his companions rebuke him.

RULE 12. For the dead generally one is forbidden to engage in trade30 until thirty days are completed; but for one’s father and mother until his companions rebuke him and say to him, ‘Come out with us’.

RULE 13.31 For the dead generally it is forbidden to go to a house of feasting until thirty days are completed; but for one’s father and mother, all the twelve months unless it is for a sacred cause.32

RULE 14. If news reached him that his father died and he rent, but [in fact] it was his mother, he has done his duty.33 [If news reached him that] his mother died, but it was his father and he rent, he has done his duty. [If news reached him that] his father died and he rent, but it was one of his near relatives, he has done his duty. [If news reached him that] one of his near relatives died, but it was his father, he has not done his duty.34

RULE 15. If one’s father and mother died [at the same time], he makes only one rent for the two of them.35 R. Judah b. Tema said: He rends for each separately. If one’s ten children died at the same time, he makes one rent for all of them.

36If after he had made a rent [for another] news reached him that his son died, he continues to rend until it [reaches down] to the navel; when it has reached the navel he turns [the garment] front to back.
If his son died and he rent [and news of another death reached him], he leaves a space of three fingers and again rends.

RULE 16.37 The rent must be made only between the two borders;38 one who makes the rent along the border or at the side has not done his duty.39 R. Judah said: He has done his duty. R. Judah said: It happened in the days of Ḥarsum40 that people used to make the rent at the lower end [of the garment] and at the side. His colleagues retorted, ‘No proof may be adduced [from a practice adopted] in a time of danger’.

A man dressed in torn garments does not rend.41 R. Judah said: One who rends a cloak of Birrus,42 a Brundisian cloak,43 a Poenula,44 a stitched garment or a veil,45 has not done his duty.46 One who rends a basted garment47 has done his duty. What constitutes a basted garment? [When its tear] has been completely basted.

RULE 17. These are the rents which may not be basted: [When it was done] for his father or mother, for his teacher who instructed him in wisdom, for a scroll of the Torah which has been burnt, for the ruined Temple, for evil tidings, [on hearing] the Divine Name blasphemed, on seeing Jerusalem from Mount Scopus,48 and [on the death of] a Nasi’. Some add: [On the death of] a High Priest, a prophet, or an ’Ab Beth Din. As regards the burning of a scroll of the Torah, [the garment is rent] not on hearing of this happening but only when he stands by while it burns. As for the ruined Temple, [he rends his garment] even if he heard that it has been destroyed; similarly with evil tidings because they are as grievous as the destruction of the Temple.

One who sees Jerusalem from Mount Scopus must rend; when he enters [the city] he extends the rent, and if he goes up [again to Jerusalem] he must extend it further. ‘If he goes up again’—this is to teach that he is obliged to make a rent every time he goes up [to Jerusalem] during each period [of thirty days].49 If he came up [to Jerusalem] and settled there, he rends once and has thereby done his duty.

RULE 18. One who buys a tunic which has been rent [by a mourner] from50 his companion may not baste it unless he knows that the rent is of the kind which may be basted. One who sells a tunic which has been rent [by a mourner] to his companion must inform him whether the rent is of the kind which may be basted or not.51 All rent [garments] which may not be basted must not be sold to non-Jews52 or stitched together or be reversed from top to bottom, according to the view of R. Simeon; but R. Eliezer permits it to be done. 53One who borrows a tunic from his companion to go and visit his father and when he arrives finds that his father died, he rends it, bastes it and returns it to his companion. If, however, he borrowed it without specifying for what purpose he needed it, he is not permitted54 to rend it.

RULE 19.55 One who goes out before the bier of the dead with a garment already rent robs the dead [of his due]. More grievous is the robbing of the dead than robbing the living, because one who robs the living can appease him by making restitution, but one who robs the dead cannot appease him by making restitution.

56Likewise you may say: One who honours his father and mother after their death57 is as if he honoured them in their lifetime, since one who honours them while they are alive may do so from fear or for the sake of an inheritance; but he who honours them after their death does so in the name of Heaven only.58

RULE 20. He who made a rent for one [presumed] dead and he revived, if he dies immediately afterwards [the man who made a rent] has fulfilled his duty, but if [death occurred] after some time he has not done his duty.59

RULE 21. Whosoever rescues garments from the dead60 robs the dead. There are times when a man may rescue them and times when he may not. [48b] If the garments have not touched the bier he may rescue them, but if they have touched the bier he may not. We, however, instruct people not to seize them.61 And whoever piles up garments on the dead commits a transgression because of the law which forbids wilful destruction,62 according to the view of R. Meir. R. Eliezer b. Ẓadoḳ said: It disgraces him. Rabban Gamaliel said: He causes maggots to breed upon [the dead]. R. Nathan said: The garment which goes down with him to the grave will come back with him in the time to come,63 as it is stated, It is changed as clay under the seal; and they stand as a garment.64

(2) i.e. Torah. Cf., however, M.Ḳ. 25a (Sonc. ed., p. 154), Shab. 105b (Sonc. ed., p. 509) where it is taught that one rends the garments on the death of any worthy man.

(23) From a sense of self-respect (M.Ḳ. loc. cit.).
(24) So GRA and H; V reads ‘three’.
(26) i.e. hastens the interment.
(27) viz. their business affairs before the funeral (Rashi). R. Ḥananel, on the basis of a passage in j.M.Ḳ. III, 8, 83d, explains ‘reduces the funeral expenses and the lament to a minimum’.
(28) On his untidy appearance.
(30) Not ordinary trade which is permissible after seven days of mourning, but to set out on a business journey to distant lands, because that might be interpreted as an indication of callousness.
(31) Cf. M.Ḳ. loc. cit.
(32) e.g. a wedding.
(33) He has not to rend again.
(34) He has to rend again.
(36) ibid.
(37) The text is corrupt, and the translation follows the version of Nachmanides (cf. N.Y.).
(38) On either side of the front opening of the shirt or tunic.
(39) Because the rent is hidden.
(40) The name of a High Priest who lived in a time of persecution. GRA reads ḥerum which means ‘prohibition to travel’, e.g. in a time of war.
(41) Since his garments are already torn, the new rent will not be distinguishable.
(42) ‘A cloth named after a Celtic people, Burri’ (Krauss); ‘a cloak of thick woollen material’ (Jastrow).
(43) A cloak thicker than the previous material (Jastrow); a cloth named after a Celtic people, the Burridens (Krauss).
(44) A travelling cloak (Jastrow).
(45) Jastrow emends חרוד to רדיד, a garment of fine texture.
(46) These materials are either too thick or too fine for the rent to be distinguishable.
(47) i.e. one sewn with large stitches.
(48) Because from there the ruins of Jerusalem are visible.

(49) [The meaning is illustrated by j.Ber. IX, 2, 13d: R. Simeon Ḳamṭraya asked R. Ḥiyya b. Abba, ‘Since I am an ass-driver and go up to Jerusalem throughout the year, how is it about rending my garment?’ He replied, ‘Within thirty days [after a visit] it is unnecessary for you to rend’.]
(50) So GRA and H; V has ‘for’.
(52) Lest they resell it to a Jew.
(53) Cf. M.Ḳ. loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 172).
(54) This is the reading of GRA and H.
(55) Cf. M.Ḳ. loc. cit.
(56) This sentence and the next Rule are transposed in accordance with GRA. A better sequence is thereby obtained.
(57) Cf. Ḳid. 31b (Sonc. ed., p. 154).
(58) To fulfil God’s command and without a motive of self-interest.
(59) Cf. Ned. 87a (Sonc. ed., p. 268).

(60) Cf. Sanh. 48a, b (Sonc. ed., pp. 321f). If parents piled on the bier garments belonging to their child as an expression of grief and as a sign that they renounced everything that belonged to him. Saving the garments constituted an act of returning lost property; but when the articles touched the bier they were regarded as designated for the dead.
(61) V inserts ‘but did not [the Sages] say’ which GRA deletes.
(62) The Rabbis derived a law against the wanton destruction of articles from Deut. XX, 19; cf. Shab. 129a (Sonc. ed., p. 644, n. 1).
(63) In the Resurrection; cf. j.Keth. XII, 3, 35a, Sanh. 90b (Sonc. ed., p. 607).
(64) Job XXXVIII, 14; לְבו·שׁ, a garment, is homiletically read as לָבו·שׁ, ‘as he is dressed’.

chapter.title: CHAPTER X
chapter.p: RULE 1. A mourner, as long as his dead is lying before him,1 is exempt from reading the Shema‘ and Tefillah and from all the commandments prescribed in the Torah. Even if he desires to place himself under greater restrictions [than the law requires] he should not do so out of respect for the dead.

RULE 2.2 When the time comes for reading the Shema‘, all the people [present] read it but he remains silent; when they stand to read the Tefillah, all read it but he justifies for himself the divine decree. What does he say? ‘Sovereign of all the universe, I have sinned before Thee; I have repaid but few of my obligations; I merit much more punishment than this; may it be Thy will to repair our breaches and to comfort us’. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: He also prays for all the needs of the dead person.

RULE 3.3 A mourner eats [his meal] in the house of his neighbour, and if he has no neighbour he eats it in another room; and if he has no other room [than that in which the dead is lying], he puts up a partition and eats; and if he is not able to put up a partition, he turns his face away from the dead and eats. But he must not eat in a reclining posture,4 eat as much food as he needs, eat meat or drink wine. He is not included in the Zimmun, others do not say Grace on his behalf, and we do not request him, ‘Say Grace’.5 When does this apply? On week-days, but on the Sabbath6 he eats as much as he needs, he may eat meat and drink wine, and is included in the Zimmun. Rabban Gamaliel said: A mourner [is regarded] on the Sabbath as if he were not a mourner.
RULE 4. We do not remove the body [for burial] near [the time of] reading the Shema‘, unless it is an hour before.7

RULE 5.8 Once the bearers of the bier have carried [the body] out—such as are before the bier9 and such as are behind it10—those who are before the bier, whose services are still needed, are exempt from reading the Shema‘ and are forbidden11 to wear shoes. All alike are exempt from the Tefillah and from putting on the tefillin.

RULE 6.12 Having buried the dead and returned [from the graveside], if they are able to begin and complete [the reading of the Shema‘] before arriving at the row,13 they read14 it and afterwards stand in the row; but if not, they stand in the row and afterwards read [the Shema‘] and the Tefillah.

RULE 7.15 The inner row [of the comforters] who can see the mourners is exempt [from reading the Shema‘], but the outer row is under the obligation. R. Judah said: Even if there be [only] one row, those who stand for the sake of [comforting] the mourner are exempt, but those who stand for the sake of [their own] honour16 [are under the obligation].17 If they came to the memorial address,18 those who can see the mourners are exempt and those who cannot see them are under the obligation.

RULE 8. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: Rabban Gamaliel had a borrowed grave19 in Jabneh where they brought the dead and locked the door behind it. Men came, stood in the row and comforted the mourners and the public was thereby exempt [from this duty]. Later [the bodies] were conveyed to Jerusalem [for burial].

RULE 9. After [the tomb] was closed with the top stone, [the mourner] muffles his head.20 Should he take his stand in the row,21 he unmuffles his head and exempts others [from standing in the row for him]. When he leaves the row he muffles his head. After he has entered his house, should others come to comfort him, he unmuffles his head and exempts them.

RULE 10.22 When a Sage or a disciple suffers bereavement, people come and sit down before him and discuss the laws relating to mourners. Should they make a mistake he corrects them in a low tone, but he does not ask questions.23 If he so desire he may speak personally to them, and if not he appoints someone to be his spokesman. It is related that when his son died, R. Judah appointed someone to be his spokesman. It is related that when his son died, R. Jose the Galilean appointed someone to be his spokesman. It is related that when his son died, R. ‘Aḳiba continued his discourse all the day.24 The same is also reported of Rabbi [Judah the Prince]; he continued his discourse all the day.

RULE 11.25 In the first week a mourner does not enter the Synagogue; in the second week he enters but does not sit in his [usual] place; in the third week he enters and sits in his [usual] place but does not speak; in the fourth week he is like any other person. R. Simeon said: In the first week26 people come up to him to comfort him; the second week is treated like the first, the third like the second, and in the fourth week he is like any other person. R. Meir said: In the first and second week he does not enter the Synagogue, in the third he enters and sits in his [usual] place, and in the fourth he is like any other person. To what does this apply? To a Synagogue, but as for a House of Study he may enter it even in the first week.

27On the Sabbath-eve at dusk he unmuffles his head; at the termination of the Sabbath he muffles it again. On the Sabbath-eve at dusk he turns back [the garment which is] rent; at the termination of the Sabbath he turns it to the front.

RULE 12.28 When a Sage dies, his Beth Hammidrash goes into vacation and all the others change their place. When an ’Ab Beth Din dies, all the other Houses of Study in his city go into vacation and the others change their place. When a Nasi’ dies, all the Houses of Study go into vacation; people do not walk about in the street but enter [their homes] and sit in silence overcome by distress like men without a leader. When the time of rising arrives, they stand up and reduce their affairs to a minimum. The people of the Synagogue enter the Synagogue [on the Sabbath] and seven persons read the weekly portion of the Torah and go away.

RULE 13.29 Neither Halakah nor ’Aggada should be expounded in the Beth Hammidrash of a mourner. Should a question be raised, they begin with the laws relating to mourners, pass on to other themes and revert to and end with the laws relating to mourners.

30R. Ḥanina b. Gamaliel said: We may discourse upon an aggadic theme in the Beth Hammidrash of a mourner. In Judea they greeted mourners [on the Sabbath] on their entry and departure to indicate that there is no mourning on the Sabbath.
