chapter.title: CHAPTER XI
chapter.p: RULE 1. In a city where there are two dead, they take out the first1 [for burial]; and if2 they keep the first overnight3 they take out the second, because [the Sages] said, ‘Whoever keeps the dead overnight disfigures him’.4 But if [the delay] is to dig a grave for him, or to procure shrouds for him, or to enable his relatives to come from another place, he may be kept overnight and there is no wrong done.5

When a Sage and a disciple die, they first take out the Sage [for burial]; a disciple and an ‘am ha’areẓ, they first take out the disciple. If both were Sages or disciples or an ’am ha’areẓ they take out the one who dies first. If a man and a woman [died], they first take out the woman because a woman is apt to become disfigured more quickly.6

RULE 2. The differences between man and woman7 are: [the bier of] a man is set down in the broadway8 but not that of a woman;9 for a man they go up with the ḥeber ‘ir10 but not for a woman; for a male [mourner] the mourners’ meal11 is provided but not for a female [mourner].12 R. Judah said: If she has young children, a meal is provided [for her] together with them.

RULE 3. If they have taken out the first [body] and buried him, they do not stand in the row for him, nor do they recite for him the benediction of mourners until they have taken out the second and buried him. When they have taken out the second and buried him, people come and stand in the row and comfort [the mourners], and they thereby exempt the community [from their duty in this matter]. We do not offer consolation to two mourners13 at the same time unless they are of equal status.

RULE 4. We do not take out two dead on one bier unless they are of equal status and [merit] equal praise. It is related of a certain man in Usha14 that the house collapsed on his two sons and daughter. People went and inquired of R. Judah [49a] who said, ‘Take out the three of them at the same time’.15 They placed the bridegrooms16 at one end [of the bier] and the bride17 at the other and they lamented, ‘Alas, alas, bridegrooms! Alas, alas, bride!’

RULE 5. We do not deliver two memorial addresses [at the same time] in one city unless there are sufficient to attend each. We do not bewail two brides [at the same time] in one city unless there are sufficient to attend each. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: Even then it is forbidden because of ill-feeling.18

RULE 6. When a dead person and a bride are being honoured and [the two processions] approach one another, we cause the funeral procession to make way for the bridal procession,19 because the honour of the living takes precedence over the honour of the dead. In the case of a royal procession and a bridal procession, the latter makes way20 out of respect for the king. King Agrippa made way for a bride and the Sages praised him. They asked him, ‘What was your reason for doing this?’ He replied, ‘I wear a crown every day but she wears a crown for one hour only’.

RULE 7. We do not21 interrupt the study of the Torah for the sake of a funeral or bridal procession. Abba Saul said: [Good] deeds22 take precedence of the study of the Torah. R. Judah acted as follows: Whenever he saw a dead person or a bride being honoured, he used to look at his disciples and exclaim, ‘Deeds before study’.

RULE 8.23 A woman who is bereaved of her father-in-law or any of her husband’s relatives may not paint her eyelids with kohl or adorn herself, but conducts herself as [her husband] does.24 Likewise if [her husband] is bereaved of his father-in-law or any of his wife’s relatives, he cannot compel her to adorn herself but conducts himself as she does.
RULE 9.25 Sweeping the floors, washing dishes and making beds do not constitute work for a mourner.26
RULE 10.27 A dargesh28 is tilted up29 and not overturned. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: He loosens its step30 and leaves it as it is.

RULE 11. Should five brothers eat at their father’s table and he dies, if each of them [usually] goes to his own home to sleep, he overturns [the bed] in his house; but if not, he overturns it only in the house which is used [for sleeping].

RULE 12. If a man possesses five houses, should he be making use of all of them he overturns [the bed] in all of them; if not, he does not overturn it in all of them but only in the house which is used [for sleeping].
RULE 13. If one resides with his friend as a guest, should he be very intimate with him he overturns [the bed there], and if not he does not overturn it.

RULE 14. If one is on a journey and news reaches him that he suffered a bereavement, should he be able to overturn [the bed] with the consent of others he overturns it, and if not he does not overturn it.

RULE 15. One overturns his bed [which is laid] on two benches or on four stones even if there be five mattresses on it, and even though it be [only] four handbreadths31 above the ground, so long as its legs are tilted upwards.
RULE 16. So long as his dead is lying before him, a mourner may not sleep on a bed [in an erect position] or on an overturned bed.

RULE 17.32 One who sleeps on a bench or on a bench for water-jugs33 is subject to the duty of overturning.34 If he declares, ‘I will not overturn the bed but sleep35 on the bench’, we do not listen to him but say, ‘It is subject to [the law of] overturning’.

RULE 18. The bed has to be overturned six times, five times, four times [or] three times, neither less nor more. How is this? If the death took place close to dusk,36 [it is done] six times; if close to dusk on the Sabbath-eve five times; if a Festival occurs on the day following the Sabbath four times; in the case of the two days of the New Year [after a Sabbath] three times.37

RULE 19.38 When does one overturn the bed? From the time the corpse is taken out through the door of the house, according to the view of R. Eliezer. R. Joshua said: From the time the slab closes the tomb. It is related that when Rabban Gamaliel the Elder39 died, as soon as he was taken out through the door of his house, [R. Eliezer] said to them,40 ‘Overturn your beds’; and when the slab closed the tomb R. Joshua said, Overturn your beds’. They replied, ‘We have already overturned them by order of the Elder’.41

chapter.title: CHAPTER XII
chapter.p: RULE 1.1 The day of hearing2 [the news of the death] is regarded as the day of burial3 for rending [garments], mourning and the observance of the seven [days] and thirty [days]; but as for eating sacred flesh4 he is only regarded as one who gathers bones.5 Both of them may not eat sacred flesh.6

RULE 2. R. Eliezer said: [On receiving] ‘near tidings’,7 [that is to say, if news reached him] within thirty days [of the death], one observes [mourning] for seven [days] and thirty [days]; [if the news reached him] later than this he observes [mourning] for only one day. R. ‘Aḳiba said: On receiving ‘near tidings’ [that is to say, if news reached him] within twelve months [of the death], one observes [mourning] for seven [days] and thirty [days]. The Sages said: Whether it be ‘near tidings’ or ‘distant tidings’,8 he observes [mourning] for seven [days] and thirty [days]. It is related that when R. Ẓadoḳ’s father died at Ginzaḳ9 in Media and the news reached him after three years, he observed [mourning] for seven [days] and thirty [days].

RULE 3. Any [dead person] for whom one rends [the garments] on his death, one also rends for him when his bones are gathered. For [a dead person] for whom one may not baste [the edge of his garments] on his death, one may not baste them when his bones are gathered.

RULE 4. The gathering of bones must be done only during one day; therefore one only gathers them towards dusk.10 If he gathered them throughout the day and11 it became dark, it is permissible [to continue] on the following day. We do not stand in the row for them, nor do we recite over them the benediction of mourners, nor offer consolation to the mourners12 [in public], but we may do so in private. We do not hold an assembly for them in the broadway,13 but we do bring the mourners’ meal into the mourner’s home.14 R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: During the day he lies15 on an overturned bed and at dusk he straightens it.

RULE 5. The following was the practice of the Brotherhoods16 in Jerusalem: Some went to the house of mourning, others to the house of feasting,17 some went to a circumcision18 and others to gather bones. [In the choice between going] to the house of mourning and the house of feasting, the house of feasting takes precedence; to a circumcision and to gather bones, the circumcision takes precedence. The pious men of olden days, however, gave precedence to the house of mourning over the house of feasting, for it is stated, It is better to go to the house of mourning, than to go to the house of feasting; for that is the end of all men, and the living will lay it to his heart.19 Whoever follows the bier should say, ‘I, too, will follow this one [to the grave]’.
RULE 6. We do not break the bones nor sever the sinews [of a corpse] unless the bones were already broken of their own accord and the sinews severed of their own accord.

RULE 7. A man may gather all bones except those of his father and mother,20 in the view of R. Joḥanan b. Nuri. R. ‘Aḳiba said: Bones may not be gathered until the flesh dissolves; once the flesh is dissolved the appearance [of the person] is no longer recognizable.21

RULE 8. One may gather the bones of two dead persons at the same time; he then places one collection at one end of the sheet [49b] and the other at the other side of it, in the view of R. ‘Aḳiba. R. Joḥanan b. Nuri said: [If this is done] the sheet may in the end decay and the bones be mixed together; so we gather them and place them [separately] in cedar22 [boxes].

RULE 9. We sprinkle wine and oil upon [the bodies], in the view of R. ‘Aḳiba; R. Simeon b. Nanos said: Oil but not wine because wine causes deterioration;23 and the Sages said: Neither oil nor wine because they breed wood-worms,24 but we place dry clods of earth upon them. R. Eliezer b. Ẓadoḳ said: When my father was dying he gave me this instruction, ‘On my death bury me first in a valley, and later gather my bones and place them in a cedar25 coffin, but do not gather them with your hands’. And I did so for him. R. Joḥanan entered [the cave] and spread a sheet over [the bones]; then I entered, rent [my garments] and spread dry clods of earth [over the bones].26 As [my father] did for his father so I did for him.

RULE 10. A man bandages27 and binds [the limb] of a man but not of a woman; a woman bandages and binds both a man and a woman. A man attends to a man suffering from disease of the bowels but not to a woman;28 a woman attends both to a man29 and a woman suffering from disease of the bowels.
RULE 11. Abba Saul b. Bothnith30 used to say to his sons, ‘Bury me at the feet of my father and remove the thread of blue from [the ẓiẓith of] my cloak’.

RULE 12.31 One may enter a [public] bath with all except32 his father, father-in-law, stepfather and his teacher who taught him wisdom. R. Judah said: If his father is old or ill, he may enter and bathe him because that is a way of honouring him.33

RULE 13. We do not take out [the dead on] a bier unless his head and the greater part of his body are there. R. Judah said: The spinal column and the skull constitute the greater part. It is related of the son of R. Ḥanina b. Teradion that he took to evil ways and robbers seized and killed him. After three days his swollen body was found; they placed him in a coffin,34 set him on a bier, took him into the city and paid him a eulogy35 out of respect for his father and mother. His father quoted over him the verse, And thou moan, when thine end cometh, when thy flesh and thy body are consumed, and say, ‘How have I hated instruction, and my heart despised reproof; neither have I hearkened to the voice of my teachers, nor inclined mine ear to them that instructed me! I was well nigh in all evil in the midst of the congregation and assembly.’36 When he had finished he went back to the beginning of the verse. His mother quoted over him the verse, A foolish son is the vexation to his father, and bitterness to her that bore him.37 His sister quoted over him the verse, Bread of falsehood is sweet to a man; but afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.38

chapter.title: CHAPTER XIII
chapter.p: RULE 1. One who gathers or guards bones is exempt from reading the Shema‘, the Tefillah, from tefillin and all the commandments prescribed by the Torah. Should he desire to impose a strict view upon himself, he may not do so because of the honour of the bones.1 R. Joḥanan b. Nuri said: He should withdraw a distance of four cubits and read [the prayers]. R. Simeon b. ‘Azzai said: If he was travelling on a ship with the bones, he should remove them to another part [of the vessel] and read.2 R. Isaac said: If they are the bones of a near relative he is exempt, but if of strangers he is under obligation. R. Simeon said: On the Sabbath he is under obligation,3 but on week-days he is exempt. R. Nathan said:4 If the bundle [containing the bones] is with him, he is not exempt5 because the obligation of guarding [the bones] rests upon him but not the obligation of guarding the bundle.

RULE 2. One who is removing bones or sacred books from one place to another may not place them on a wagon or a ship or an animal and6 sit on them; but if it is for their benefit7 or to escape paying ransom to robbers it is permissible.8
RULE 3. If one passes through graves he should not wear the tefillin or carry sacred books in his hand, because it is disrespectful [to the dead].9

RULE 4. If one is constructing a burial chamber10 [in a cemetery] and the time for reading the Shema‘ arrives, he should not read the Shema‘ or the Tefillah but withdraw to a clean place and read; after that he re-enters [the chamber].
RULE 5. If one finds a dead body in a grave he may not move it from its place,11 unless he knows that the place was lent to it.12

RULE 6. If one finds bones in a grave he should place them in mounds,13 in the view of R. ‘Aḳiba; but the Sages said: He should not move them from their place. If he found them in a burial chamber or in a cedar-wood coffin,14 he should not move them from their place.

RULE 7. We may not transfer a dead body or bones from one place of honour to another, or from a place of shame to a place of honour,15 and needless to say from a place of honour to a place of shame; but within [the dead person’s] property it is permissible [to transfer] even from a place of honour to a place of shame, because it is to his honour.16

RULE 8. We do not bury two dead bodies in close proximity to each other, or a dead body in close proximity to bones, or bones in close proximity to a dead body. R. Judah said: Whoever sleeps with him in his lifetime17 is buried with him in his death.18

RULE 9. One may derive benefit from a grave which has been cleared,19 but he may not turn it into a magazine for straw, a stable, a store for wood or a depot. If one clears a burial chamber he may not make use of it [for any other purpose]. If one prepares a grave for a living person20 he may sell it; but if he prepared it for the dead he may not sell it. Stones which were hewn21 for one still living may be sold, but if for the dead they may not be sold. If one clears a coffin he may not make use of it; but if it was made of stone or earthenware it must be broken up, and if of wood it must be burnt. If one finds boards in a cemetery22 he may not move them from their place.
chapter.ftnote: (1) His obedience of laws, from which he is exempt, would result in delay in the burial of the bones.
(2) The text is in disorder and the translation follows the version of GRA.
(3) Because if he does not read the prayers he would appear to be mourning on the Sabbath which is not permitted.

(4) The text is corrupt and emended by GRA. R. Nathan agrees with the ruling that one who guards bones is exempt from the Shema‘, etc., because his concern about their safety may not allow him to concentrate on his religious devotions; but where he carries them in a bundle the question of their safety does not arise and he should be able to concentrate.
(5) In his note on the text GRA reads ‘is exempt’, but in his annotation to Y.D. ch. 403 he rules that, in the circumstances here described, the man is obliged to read the prayers, etc.
(6) So GRA and H. V has ‘and not sit’.
(7) i.e. for the protection of the bones.
(8) V inserts here a sentence in brackets which is irrelevant to the subject and is omitted by GRA and H.

(9) In Ber. 18a (Sonc. ed., p. 108) he is said to transgress the teaching, Whoso mocketh the poor blasphemeth his Maker (Prov. XVII, 5), because the dead are ‘poor’ in that they cannot acquire merit by the study and performance of the Torah.
(10) Vaults were made in the graves for receiving the dead; cf. Ber. 14b (Sonc. ed., p. 85).
(11) The dead acquire possession of the spot wherein they are buried. Cf. Sanh. 47b (Sonc. ed., p. 316).
(12) Cf. above X, 8. The word ‘lent’ is according to the text of GRA and H.
(13) Reading מהמורות defined as ‘mounds used as burying places of executed criminals’ (Jastrow). GRA reads: ‘One who finds bones in mounds should place them in a grave’.
(14) So Jastrow. GRA has ‘or in a ravine’.
(15) The translation follows GRA who alters the text in agreement with j.M.Ḳ. II, 4, 81b.
(16) To be buried within his own property.
(17) i.e. young children.
(18) i.e. in close proximity to him.
(19) Since it is no longer considered the possession of the dead.
(20) In preparation for his death.
(21) To be used for a sepulchre.
(22) So emended by GRA. V reads ‘if one carries out boards to a cemetery’.

chapter.title: CHAPTER XIV
chapter.p: RULE 1. A watercourse should not be diverted through cemeteries,1 a path should not be cut through them, cattle should not be grazed on them, one should not take a walk there2 for pleasure, and one should not gather wood or grass from there. If he gathered them he may not make use of them, and if he gathered them for the benefit [of the cemetery]3 he burns them on the spot.
RULE 2. Inherited lands may be conveyed from one [party] to another or alienated from one family to another, but a grave cannot be so conveyed or alienated.4

RULE 3. A new cemetery5 may be measured6 and sold or divided;7 an old one may not be measured, sold or divided. A new cemetery may sometimes be regarded as old and an old one as new. An old cemetery in which ten bodies have been buried without the consent of the owners is regarded as new; it may be measured, sold or divided. A new cemetery in which one premature child8 lies buried with the consent of the owners is regarded as old; it may not be measured, sold or divided.9

RULE 4. No right of legal ownership can be claimed in respect of a cemetery of exiles;10 in time of pestilence or war no right of legal ownership can be claimed in respect of cemeteries.11 Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: Premature children do not acquire possession of their grave.12 One who has buried without the consent [of the owner of the land] possesses no right of legal ownership.

RULE 5. A woman who inherited a grave-space is buried therein as also her issue, in the view of R. Meir; R. Judah said: She [is buried there] but not13 her issue. R. Judah admits that any offspring whom she saw in her lifetime are buried with her [if they die] after her death.14

RULE 6. If her father says, ‘Let her be buried by my side’ and her husband says, ‘Let her be buried [50a] by my side’, she is buried by the side of her father; but if she had children, she is buried by her husband’s side, and if she says, ‘Bury me by the side of my children’, she is buried by their side.

RULE 7. If her father says, ‘She is not to be buried by my side’ and her husband says, ‘She is not to be buried by my side’, she is buried by the side of her husband because her husband has the obligation to support her, redeem her [from captivity],15 bury her and provide all that is necessary16 for her funeral, [for example,] a bier, pipers17 and wailing women.18 Where it is customary to have a memorial address, he has a memorial address delivered over his wife. If her husband does not attend to her [burial, her father] attends to it and the expenses are recovered from [the husband] by force.

RULE 8.19 Consequently you say that there are three kinds of graves: a grave which has been found may be cleared,20 and if cleared its site is [ritually] clean and it is permitted to make use of it. A known grave may not be cleared,21 and if cleared its site is [ritually] unclean and it is forbidden to make use of it. A grave which injures the public22 may not be cleared, and if cleared its site is [ritually] clean but it is forbidden to make use of it.

RULE 9. As regards a cemetery which is enclosed by a city on three sides or on two opposite sides, if it is more than fifty cubits distant from one side [of the city] and more than fifty cubits distant from the other side, it is not23 cleared and if less it may be cleared.

RULE 10.24 All graves may be cleared except that of a king or a prophet. R. ‘Aḳiba said: The grave of a king or prophet may also be cleared. R. ‘Aḳiba was asked, ‘Were not the graves of the house of David and of Huldah the prophetess25 [situated] in Jerusalem and no man ever touched them?’ He replied, ‘Can you adduce a proof from [Jerusalem]? There was an underground passage there and the uncleanness was conveyed to the brook of Kidron’.26

RULE 11. If one sells to another the path [leading] to his grave, this is no sale.27 If one sells to another his place of mourning,28 it is no sale. If one sells29 to another his halting place,30 the elders of the ’Ab Beth Din estimate it as an area of four ḳab.31 A private path [has a width] of four cubits, a public road [a width] of sixteen cubits, the king’s highway has no limits. The path of a funeral cortège has no limits.32 and the path of [a place of] mourning has no limits.

RULE 12.33 One who sees a mourner within the thirty days speaks to him words of consolation but does not inquire after his welfare; after thirty days he inquires after his welfare but does not speak to him words of consolation; within the twelve months he inquires after his welfare and then speaks words of consolation to him; after twelve months he speaks to him words of consolation and then inquires after his welfare.

R. Meir said: One who sees a mourner within the thirty days speaks to him words of consolation and then inquires after his welfare; after thirty days but within twelve months he inquires after his welfare and then speaks to him words of consolation; after twelve months he makes no reference at all [to the bereavement]. For R. Meir illustrated the matter by a parable. To what may it be compared? To one who has a wound and was cured of it, and a physician came and said to him, ‘Pay me a fee and I will lance your wound and cure you’. Likewise, whoever reminds a mourner after twelve months [of his bereavement] is accounted as if he had stirred up his wound again. Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: To one whose wife died and he remarried within twelve months we speak words of consolation in the street but not in his home.34

RULE 13. All bring to the house of a mourner loaves of white bread, meat and fish, and where an assembly in the broadway35 is held also vegetables, peas and fish. Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: Where it is customary also cooked dishes.36

RULE 14.37 Ten cups of wine are drunk in the house of a mourner: two before the meal, five during the meal and three after the meal, namely one for the benediction of mourners,38 one for the consolation of the mourners and one [in honour of] charity.39 Three more [cups of wine] were added later, namely, one for the Chief of the Synagogue,40 one for the Synagogue attendant41 and one for Rabban Gamaliel.42 When, however, the Beth Din found that people became intoxicated they restored the status quo.43

RULE 15. He who recites the Grace after meals in the house of a mourner does not say the fourth benediction,44 in the view of R. Jose the Galilean; R. ‘Aḳiba said: [He recites] ‘Who art kind and dealest kindly’; the Sages said: [The benediction to be recited is, ‘Blessed art Thou] Who art the true Judge, Who rulest over Thy works, Judge of all generations in righteousness, Whose people and servants we all are; and for all this it is our duty to thank and bless Him’.
RULE 16.45 He who sees a place where miracles were wrought for Israel says, ‘Blessed be He Who wrought miracles for our fathers in this place. O give thanks unto the Lord, for He is good’.46
chapter.ftnote: (1) Out of respect for the dead; cf. Meg. 29a (Sonc. ed., p. 177).
(2) It should not be used as a short cut.
(3) To clear the ground for more graves. The words in brackets are inserted by GRA and H.
(4) Cf. below, §11.
(5) In which only a few have been buried.
(6) To find out how much land had already been used for burials as a guide for further interments.
(7) Among heirs.
(8) Under thirty days old; how much more an adult!
(9) ‘Or divided’ is added by GRA and H.
(10) Who in time of pestilence or war move from place to place.
(11) This clause is explanatory of the preceding.
(12) If buried without the consent of the owners.
(13) So GRA and H. V reads ‘and all’ incorrectly.
(14) But not a posthumous child. V has ‘on her death’ and the reading of H is adopted.
(15) Cf. Keth. 46b (Sonc. ed., p. 266).
(16) So GRA.
(17) To play at the funeral; cf. B.M. VI, 1 (Sonc. ed., p. 437, n. 3).
(18) Cf. M.Ḳ. III, 9 (Sonc. ed., p. 185). They are mentioned in Jer. IX, 16.

(19) The text is in disorder. The translation follows the emendation of GRA on the basis of Sanh. 47b (Sonc. ed., p. 316). Higger (Introduction, pp. 49f) points out that the text is not in agreement with the parallel passage in Tosiftha Ohol. XVI, 9 or with the Babylonian Talmud loc. cit. or with the Jerusalem Talmud, Nazir IX, 3, 57d. He suggests that the compiler of Semaḥoth must have had before him various passages dealing with the uncleanness of the grave and the prohibition of using graves and he mixed them up. The introductory phrase ‘consequently you may say’ points to the fact that there must have been a discussion on the subject and the statement in the text sums up the conclusion arrived at.
(20) i.e. the bones are transferred to another place. A person had been buried there without the knowledge and consent of the owner.
(21) As a precautionary measure against persons contracting defilement.
(22) Reading המזיק, i.e. a grave which lies in a public thoroughfare and so communicates uncleanness to people who are overshadowed by something which also overshadows it.
(23) The negative is inserted by GRA and H.
(24) The text is reconstructed in agreement with Tosiftha B.B. I, 11.
(25) Cf. 2 Kings XXII, 14.
(26) East of Jerusalem.
(27) Because the sale is a slight on his family; cf. B.B. 100b (Sonc. ed., p. 420).
(28) When, on the return from the cemetery, the cortège halts and the mourners receive condolence; cf. B.B. Sonc. ed., p. 416, n. 8.
(29) V reads ‘buys’ which is corrected by GRA.
(30) Where, on returning from the funeral, ceremonial halts were made to offer consolation to the mourners.
(31) An area sufficient for sowing four ḳab of seed.
(32) The followers may even tread upon cornfields if there is no room for them on the public highway.
(34) Not to embarrass his second wife.
(36) Cf. B.B. 16b (Sonc. ed., p. 84). When Abraham died, Jacob made a broth of lentils to comfort his father Isaac.
(37) Cf. Keth. 8b (Sonc. ed., p. 42), j.Ber. III, 6a. The text here is similar to that of the Jerusalem Talmud.
(38) The Jerusalem Talmud reads ‘for the Grace after meals’.
(39) i.e. in honour of those who came to comfort the mourners and performed a pious act.
(40) An official who administered the external affairs of the Synagogue (cf. Yoma VII, 1, Sonc. ed., p. 322, n. 2).
(41) An official who seems to have been next in rank to the Chief of the Synagogue.
(42) Who introduced a simple style for funerals to lessen the expense and relieve poor mourners; cf. M.Ḳ. 27b (Sonc. ed., p. 178), Keth. 8b (Sonc. ed., p. 43).
(43) i.e. that ten cups only should be drunk.
(44) Cf. P.B., p. 283. In Ber. 46b (Sonc. ed., p. 281) the decision is that the benediction is not omitted.
(45) Cf. Ber. 54a (Sonc. ed., p. 327).
(46) Ps. CVII, 1.
